PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to Senator Boswell's dispute with the Prime Minister in regard to his claim that Mr Howard's 10‐point plan failed to deliver on promises made to the Nationals and his challenge to Mr Howard to produce the notes of his meeting with the Federal President of the National Party, Mr McDonald. I ask: did Mr Howard deliver on the promises made to the Nationals and, if so, why do the Nationals insist that he did not? Will the notes of the meeting be released so that we can tell whether it is the Prime Minister or Senator Boswell who is telling the truth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —What I can tell Senator Faulkner is that the coalition government is working constructively towards a fair and just response to the Wik case. We had a very constructive party meeting today on that matter, in which the Prime Minister's 10‐point plan was very firmly and overwhelmingly endorsed. I think that is a good sign for the Australian people.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no doubt that many in the community have felt the strain post‐Wik, particularly pastoral leaseholders. We have talked about that in this place before. They were basically misled by the previous Labor government. When they found that the law was not what they had been assured of by the previous government, they naturally felt somewhat distressed by that.

The Howard government has answered that challenge; in particular, by the Prime Minister working through the alternatives with great care with all the major stakeholder groups. The response that he has developed is, as I said, fair and equitable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I take a point of order. I asked Senator Hill if Mr Howard delivered on his promises made to the Nationals and, if he did so, why they insisted he did not. I asked also whether the notes of the meeting would be released. I ask you to direct him to answer the questions that I have asked.
—I think Senator Hill is dealing with the questions. There are certainly some aspects of the multiple‐ part question that perhaps have not yet been dealt with to your satisfaction.

—I am trying to explain to Senator Faulkner that he is suffering from a fundamental misunderstanding. I am trying to explain to him that this very difficult issue has been constructively worked through between the Prime Minister, all stakeholders and the parties of our coalition, including the National Party. As I said to Senator Faulkner, the proposals of the Prime Minister, a fair and just package, have been overwhelmingly endorsed by the coalition party room today.

ANSWER.PARA: What Senator Faulkner should be doing is applauding the way in which the Prime Minister has acted in this very complex and difficult matter. It was not his fault that he inherited the consequences of Labor misleading the Australian people and he has made a great effort, as I said, to find a response that is fair and equitable, in the interest of all Australians. That response will go through further processes now—the development of legislation and an exposure draft. It will ultimately be brought to this place and I hope will then be overwhelmingly endorsed by all senators in this place because it is in the national interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Hill might ask himself why I would applaud when the National Party, as part of his own coalition government, are in open revolt. Senator Hill, if you are not willing to comment on whether Mr Howard delivered on the promises he made to the National Party, perhaps you could explain to the Senate why Mr Fischer wrote to Mr McDonald after the cabinet meeting on 7 May claiming that cabinet had agreed to include the Nationals' amendments in the 10‐point plan?

—The Prime Minister delivers on all his promises. What Labor should now do is study the 10‐point plan, study the obvious merit in that plan, understand and appreciate how it is fair to all Australians, including indigenous Australians, get behind us and help give some certainty to the Australian people. Do something constructive for a change—support the government in finding a solution that meets the problems of Wik in a fair and just way. Then they will be performing a useful function for the benefit of the Australian people.

—I direct my question to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, in advance of tonight's budget, can you remind the Senate of the economic problems confronting Australia when the Liberal and National parties won office just over a year ago? What steps has the new Liberal and National Party government taken to put Australia firmly back on the path to greater economic prosperity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam President, and thank you, Senator Chapman, for the question that you have asked. It is an important question and provides some perspective on the debates which will flow over the next couple of days. It is true that Labor left office with Australia facing substantial economic and fiscal problems, the most obvious of which—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Conroy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —And we are not blaming you for that, Senator, as you were not here, but we blame all these failed ministers on the front bench. Labor left office with a $10 billion underlying budget deficit. In fact, in their last five years in office Labor racked up deficits of some $70 billion in total. Under Labor, of course, Australia suffered the worst recession since the 1930s. What was it that Paul Keating said? It was the recession that, according to him, we had to have. Unemployment under that recession rose to some 11 per cent. Labor could not find a solution to unemployment despite its 13 years in office.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, under Labor, mortgage rates for the average family at one stage reached a staggering 17 per cent, and rates for small business were even higher. Of course, it is well known that, when Labor left office, the current account deficit was out of control. Under Labor, the current account deficit reached six per cent of GDP—the highest of any industrialised country. You would think that there would be some hint of apology from this front bench, from the people who in fact presided over this dreadful record.

Labor let government outlays get out of hand. Between 1989‐90 and 1995‐96 annual outlays went up from $89 billion to a whopping $132 billion. Of course, it is well known that Labor kept putting taxes up and up and up.

The coalition is proud of the efforts it is taking to right Labor's wrongs and to put Australia on the path to greater prosperity and greater security. The job clearly is not complete. We do not pretend, and we have never pretended, that it will be easy to turn around a ship that has been travelling in the wrong direction for 13 years. We have never pretended it is easy. But we are making good progress. We are tackling very effectively Labor's unsustainable budget deficits and we are reducing the debt which our children will have to repay.

We are taking the pressure off interest rates. Official interest rates have fallen three times since the election, and some home loan rates are at their lowest since the 1960s. We are helping one million Australian families with our family tax initiative. We are helping to create a better environment for small business and job creation by, among other things, providing tax relief, including through cuts in the provisional tax uplift factor; capital gains rollover relief and reduced FBT costs; cutting red tape on small business and abolishing Labor's job‐destroying unfair dismissal laws—although I notice that Labor today, again, in a press statement opposed the government's change in this area. That is a great pity and a great tragedy for small business. Of course—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Develop ment. Can you confirm that in March of this year there were 278 take‐offs and landings in Sydney when cross‐winds were stronger than that allowed by international standards? Were these safety breaches a direct result of your government's policy of spreading noise impact and, hopefully, not passengers, across Sydney? Is it a fact that the pilots association is now refusing to put passenger safety at risk by refusing to comply with your government's policy of spreading noise across Sydney's suburbs? In other words, are the pilots being significantly more responsible than the government is being?
—It's not your portfolio.
—Yes, it is.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I think he does have a portfolio. As we all know, he got a very big demotion in the last massacre. I think he is now basically just the local member for the Northern Territory looking after a bit of regional Australia.
—And proud of it.
—You could have volunteered it a lot earlier and saved John Anderson 12 months of not having any opposition.
—I have always regarded being a senator for the Northern Territory as important, Senator.
—Well, why did you ever put yourself forward for the front bench? Acknowledge it was a colossal mistake from the Australian public's point of view. You could have saved us all a lot of trouble.
—Order! Senator Alston, you should be answering Senator Collins's question.

—Senator Collins asked a number of tendentious questions obviously designed to try and excuse the inexcusable, which was Labor's deliberate policy of concentrating the noise in particular electorates that they thought made some sense in the lead‐up to the last election. The fact is we have taken decisions that have ameliorated the problem. If you are aware of particular prob lems, then you can bring them to the attention of the relevant authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: The use of the operational mode involving aircraft take‐off to and landing from the south over Botany Bay has been somewhat limited. There have been safety concerns raised over the use of this mode following an incident on the morning of 5 January involving an international B747 and a domestic A320. These are being investigated by the bureau. There has been some increase in the use of these procedures recently. During February 1977 there was a significant drop in the level of usage of the east‐west runway due in part to persistent southerly weather, but also due to the level of traffic using the airport.

Airservices Australia introduced new procedures on 28 March to increase the use of the east‐west runway. These involved increasing the capacity of the runway modes and relaxing certain time restrictions.

Whether or not you have figures that the number of take‐offs have increased and whether or not you are accurate in saying that the pilots have taken it upon themselves to make judgments about safety, the fact remains that there are responsible third parties who are charged with that responsibility. They are the ones that ought to make those judgments. If you have any other information to the contrary, you ought to pass it on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question following that piece of utter nonsense delivered by Senator Alston. Can I remind him that this particular policy of configuration of traffic at Sydney airport was imposed by the coalition against the views of the safety regulator at Sydney airport? I thought that the minister for transport was in fact the appropriate authority, Senator Alston, so I am bringing it to your attention. Will you guarantee, Senator Alston, the safety of all passengers at Sydney airport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had some egregious nonsense trotted out by Senator Collins, and the high-water mark of that was yesterday in estimate committees when about 30 public servants had to sit there and listen to mindless meanderings from Senator Collins about some Panorama magazine he had read on the way down from Darwin and had somehow thought was relevant. He was not particularly interested at all in addressing the issues before the committee. The fact is that the government is not in the business of giving guarantees on air safety—nor could your government and nor did it ever seek to do it.
—There are no guarantees.

—That is dead right, there are no guarantees. That is right. There are no guarantees in this life, right? But what you do is take the best possible steps to minimise difficulties, minimise risks, to make sure as best you can that accidents do not occur.

ANSWER.PARA: On that basis, there will be a responsible approach taken to these issues, not the highly motivated political approach you took in a desperate effort to somehow try to quarantine a few electorates in the lead-up to the last election. Our approach will put safety first, not election outcomes. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. Earlier this year the government introduced the landmark Workplace Relations Act to free up the industrial relations system. In addition, the Prime Minister's small business statement in March this year contained a provision to further reduce the compliance burden on small business by excluding from federal unfair dismissal laws new employees of small businesses with 15 or fewer employees for their first 12 months of service. I ask the minister: what impact will the Labor Party's decision today to oppose this vital initiative have on small business and employment generally?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Watson for that question. If anything highlights the immense gap between Labor and the coalition, it is their vastly different attitudes to small business. You would have thought that Labor would have learnt something after what happened to them on 13 March 1996. Madam President, nothing changes.

BREAK.PARA: One of the gems of 13 years of Labor was the draconian unfair dismissal laws that Labor introduced to terrorise small business and penalise their attempts to employ people. Senator Cook had some words to say about this after the election. The direct result was that small business was afraid to employ anybody, and Labor scored their place in political history by achieving one million unemployed.

If small business has any view that somehow the surviving Labor team had got the message, then today's news shows that Labor's vendetta against small business is as strong as ever. To put it more kindly, all I can say is that, even after this stage, there is no way in the world that Labor even pretends or gets anywhere close to understanding what small business is all about.

Small business has welcomed the coalition's move to return fairness to employment and to end Labor's crippling employment bias against small business. But Labor wants nothing to do with fairness, and now it declares it will block coalition moves to exclude workers employed in firms with 15 or fewer employees from federal unfair dismissal laws if those workers have less than a year's continuous service.

The Workplace Relations Act took effect from 1 January this year. It swept away Labor's complex and job destroying unfair dismissal laws. The new system itself is less legalistic, less costly and emphasises conciliation and protects employers from frivolous and malicious claims. Already we have seen a dramatic tapering off in unfair dismissal cases that have been lodged. But it has not stopped there.

A key initiative in the small business statement announced by the Prime Minister on 24 March was to further reduce the compliance of burden on small business by excluding from federal unfair dismissal laws new employees of small business with 15 or fewer employees in their first 12 months of service. That particular measure was unanimously endorsed by small business and small business associations throughout Australia as it removed a major disincentive for small business to employ.
It is interesting to note what Senator Cook himself, in fact, said. On 24 March, after the Prime Minister's announcement—and it is worth listening to—Senator Cook said:
At today's doorstep I may have said the opposition will try and block the small business unfair dismissals in the Senate. This is not what I meant to convey.
`This is not what I meant to convey', says Senator Cook. He goes on to say:
Any comment that the opposition will block this legislation in the Senate is not correct.
I am happy to go on if you like. He goes on to say:
The correct position is that the opposition has not yet sighted the actual proposals—
although they were pretty clear, I would have thought—
and we will consult small business and consider its response in the appropriate time.

You obviously have not consulted small business, Senator. If you had, they would have made perfectly clear to you their position with regard to the unfair dismissal provisions for those small business people with 15 employees or fewer. In fact, any criticism that we may have received on this issue which came to me from small business was: why did we limit it to 15?

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer to the blockage by the ALP that the minister referred to in relation to this initiative. Does this mean, Minister, that Australia could end up reverting to the days of Labor's ridiculous unfair dismissal legislation? Surely that would not be the case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid, Senator, that that is the situation. The Labor Party has never learnt. This is yet another stunt. Obviously Senator Cook, one of the more sensible people on that side, has been done over again.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I note the interjections. Let me say it is all relative. I applaud the Queensland government's announcement of 9 May that it will mirror the federal government's exemption from the unfair dismissals initiative. So the exemption will now apply to small business in the federal jurisdiction, in the ACT, in the Northern Territory and in Victoria by virtue of the referral of the industrial relations jurisdiction to the Commonwealth. Only New South Wales has so far refused to adopt this initiative. But do not hold your breath—they may well go along with us, if only, Senator, for political reasons. But now we have the Labor opposition deciding to deny small business access to the exemption provisions.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement that his 10-point plan will require state and territory governments to charge pastoralists a betterment fee to upgrade their pastoral leases to freehold. Minister, will the government require pastoralists to pay the full commercial value of that upgrade?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is firmly of the view that the plan meets the legitimate concerns of pastoralists while respecting native title. It will achieve a fair, practical and workable resolution of the uncertainties created by the Wik decision. Broadly speaking, the plan will allow pastoralists to get on with their business without being impeded by native title.

ANSWER.PARA: Regarding any potential for disruption of pastoral operations, the High Court has already said that any co-existing native title rights must yield to the rights of the pastoralists. Pastoral interest will prevail to the extent of any inconsistency, and there will be no right to negotiate on those activities.

The publicly released 10‐point plan is a framework of principles for the Commonwealth's proposed response to the Wik decision. We are now moving into the stage of legislative drafting and close consultation with various interest groups, including pastoralists' organisations. Regardless of the final shape of the Commonwealth's response to the Wik decision, land management, including regulation of operation on pastoral leases—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. Again, it appears that the minister for Aboriginal affairs is unable to answer a very specific question that was directed to him. He was asked whether the 10-point plan requires that state and territory governments charge pastoralists a betterment fee to upgrade their pastoral leases to freehold. He was asked whether the government would require the pastoralists to pay the full commercial value of that upgrade. That was the question that was directed to him. I think it is reasonable, given that it was a specific question within the minister's portfolio responsibilities, that you direct this incompetent minister to answer it.

—Madam President, on the point of order: the 10-point plan is an integrated plan which relates to pastoral leases and a range of other titles. The matter of transferring pastoral leases to freehold leases is but one part of the plan. It is an integrated plan. You need to answer the question adequately—the minister is doing so more than adequately—to describe to the Senate the integrated aspects of the 10-point plan.
—If you thought he was doing it more than adequately, why did you get up to defend him?
—It is the prerogative of a leader to take a point of order.

—Madam President, on the point of order: I was answering the question. It was an intentional attempt disrupt the answer because those on the other side do not want to hear the answer. If he had waited perhaps 10 seconds longer, he would have had a substantive answer to his question. This is a constant tactic from the other side to which I am not going to respond. I will give the answer in my own time and in the fullness that the senator requires. But intentional disruption will not achieve anything in this regard.
—There are still three minutes for the question to be answered. I am sure that Senator Herron is aware of the question and I draw his attention to it.

—Thank you, Madam President. I will resume where I was answering before. I said that, regardless of the final shape of the Commonwealth's response to the Wik decision, land management, including regulation of operations on pastoral leases, will remain the responsibility of state and territory governments. State and territory environmental and land management requirements for pastoral leasehold land are unaffected by the 10‐point plan. As in the past, practical goodwill and commonsense will continue to be needed in using and managing pastoral lease land.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the government require pastoralists to pay the full commercial value of that upgrade? Could the minister also indicate whether the revenue gained from the betterment fees go towards compensation for native title holders?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in my answer, which the senator obviously did not hear, land management is entirely the responsibility of the state and territory governments. It is not up to us to determine what they should do. That should be obvious even to the ill‐witted and dim‐witted senators on the other side who cannot even comprehend it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Can the minister confirm that the government will not proceed with its election promise to extend the Privacy Act to the private sector? Can the minister explain what considerations are relevant now that were not relevant on 12 September 1996, when the Attorney-General announced an intention to extend the Privacy Act to the private sector? Can the minister assure consumers that their personal information is adequately protected, especially when personal information is being provided to the Commonwealth and being processed by the private sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Stott Despoja for her question, of which she was kind enough to give my office some notice. She recognises, as this government does, that personal freedoms, such as an individual's right to privacy, are important. However, while it is an important issue, it is not the only one.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Stott Despoja rightly identifies that a discussion paper was released by the Attorney on 12 September last year outlining a possible approach to privacy protection in the private sector. It was made clear at the launch of the discussion paper that its purpose was to enable the business community and the community generally to provide concrete comments on those issues. It was not an indication that the government had taken a view on how these matters should be dealt with; rather, it was a basis for discussion, as I am advised.

Responses to the discussion paper have provided the government with very clear guidance as to the real concerns of business and industry on possible government approaches to privacy protection. It has been put to the government in some of these responses that there is no need at this time for a legislative response to privacy concerns. This government, as you understand, Senator, is committed to reducing the regulatory burden on business, and it is against this background that our response to the privacy concerns has been developed.

The message that business and industry are alarmed at the growing potential for a patchwork of state laws in relation to privacy has been clearly received by the government. At the recent Premiers Conference on 21 March, the Prime Minister urged the states to take heed of these concerns by business and industry, and the Attorney has similarly put these concerns to the state and territory attorneys. The government has decided that the Privacy Commissioner will be available to assist business in its endeavours to meet privacy standards and will be available to assist business with the development of voluntary codes of conduct.

Some business and industry sectors have already taken steps to introduce good privacy practices on a voluntary basis. The Privacy Commissioner's office has assisted with this process and is therefore experienced in working with the private sector. I understand that the Privacy Commissioner will, in the near future, be initiating a range of meetings with industry and consumer groups as a starting point for developing the codes.

The short form answer of that is: yes, of course privacy is of concern to the government, as I think it is to all senators, whatever their party in this chamber. Yes, it is a matter of concern that people's privacy is protected, whoever holds the information. No, we do not believe it is appropriate at this stage to proceed by legislative path. We do believe that it is appropriate to try the voluntary code of conduct path first, and we hope that you support that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer, and I ask: given this so-called concern for privacy, what assurance do you give, if any, to consumers that their information will be adequately protected? And given your comments regarding a reduction of regulatory arrangements, does this mean that the government has no plans to regulate the trade of personal information with regard to the private sector, with institutions such as banks, supermarkets, insurance companies, doctors, telephone companies, et cetera? Do you have no plans to ensure that they are covered by some rules whatsoever when they exchange or cross‐match their customers' information for profit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, your first question: `Can you give an assurance?' is a bit like the rather facile question some journalists ask: `Can you guarantee that in 10 years time XYZ will not happen?' It is rather childish. No individual minister, no government, can guarantee anything. So it is a futile question for you to put.

ANSWER.PARA: What I can assure consumers of is that this government is concerned about protection of their privacy. We do, however, have some faith in the private sector that their attempts to take care of their customers through voluntary codes of conduct will be successful. That is the path we intend to produce first. It is not always the case that the appropriate thing to do is to legislate. Some people get elected here and they think, `I'd better keep passing bills, otherwise I will not look like I am doing anything.' We simply have a concern for the problem to try and find the most reasonable and sensible way to fix it. In this instance we happen to think that voluntary codes of conduct are the way to go in the first instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, are you aware that the University of Sydney's highly sought after veterinary science faculty has reduced its HECS liable undergraduate quota for 1998 by 15 per cent in order to accommodate fee paying undergraduates? Is this action within your fee charging guidelines? If not, is this action in breach of the Higher Education Funding Act which forces you, under section 108, to reduce the level of Commonwealth financial assistance to compensate for these breaches of the guidelines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Carr for the question, because it gives me an opportunity yet again to make clear the government's intention with respect to fee paying places at Australian universities. I can answer you directly in the first instance, Senator, and say: no, I have not looked at the specific load targets in each course at each of the 37 universities. Now that you have raised that one with me, I will have a look at it and I will come back to you specifically on that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me repeat what I have told you in this place time and time and time again. The government has a very, very clear intention that universities will have to limit their fee paying places to 25 per cent, and we will be looking very carefully at universities that seek to rearrange their affairs or in any way circumvent the guidelines.

Senator, you raised the matter of the guidelines and it is worth repeating, because some people would not have understood the confusion created by your now shadow education spokesperson either failing to read the guidelines, failing to understand them—he being a bit thick—or deliberately trying to mislead people as to the intention in those guidelines. What you will understand, Senator, that your Labor shadow education spokesperson did was march around the country pointing to one word—transitional—saying, `See, this means they are going to let in more than 25 per cent after the year 2000.' He clearly had not read them.

As I am sure you understand, the element of the guidelines that is transitional is the element that deals with the build‐up to the year 2000. Without that transitional element there in the build‐up to the year 2000, what would happen is that some of the more prestigious universities would be able to cream off final year students from other universities in the first two years of operation of fee paying. That would disadvantage smaller, regional, less prestigious universities. We had no intention of letting that happen and that is why we put a transitional mechanism in there. But your shadow education spokesperson ought to know, as Australians do know, that the 25 per cent limit is there in legislation and cannot be changed unless the lower House and the Senate agree that that limit should be changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I take it that you will investigate this matter; I appreciate that. I ask you: isn't it also the case that the minutes of Sydney University's veterinary science faculty of 5 March reveal that the faculty believes that such action is in fact essential to restore the financial viability of the faculty which your policies have destroyed? Isn't this evidence that your fee charging regime will actually deprive undergraduate students of access to HECS funded student places in this course?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —You do tempt me, Senator. You tempt me sorely to give you another bracket of what you richly deserve with your doomsaying about what would happen to higher education. You know full well that universities have got more money this year than they had last year. You know that and I know that, and it is just a pretence to say otherwise. They have, I think, about $51 million more this year than they had last year. So the changes we are making to universities have not encouraged Sydney University to do anything of the sort.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environ ment. I refer the minister to his speech to the National Environmental Law Association conference last month and in particular to his suggestion that the Commonwealth's role should be focused on issues of national environmental significance. Given that the federal government has shown no apparent interest in banning oil exploration in the Shark Bay world heritage area or in intervening to protect an important area of old‐growth forest in the Giblett block that is interim listed on the register of the National Estate, what hope do the people of Western Australia have that the federal government will play any meaningful role in protecting our national and natural heritage? Minister, is it not true that by minimising the Commonwealth's role in environmental protection you are abrogating your responsibility and leaving those matters to state governments, which are prepared to sacrifice environmental standards in the interests of short‐term economic gain?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not true. Your fundamental mistake is that you state that it is our intention to minimise the Commonwealth's role. That is not correct. Our intention is to find a formula between Commonwealth‐state responsibilities that will best protect the Australian environment. In doing that, it is our view that if the Commonwealth concentrated on matters of national environmental significance, with appropriate powers and responsibilities, there would be a better outcome.

ANSWER.PARA: It logically follows that we have more faith in state governments than you do. That will just have to be as it is. Principally, the state governments I liaise with in this role I find are responsible in relation to their environmental responsibilities. They are also looking to join with us in finding a better mix of responsibilities in this very important area.

This process, of course, was initiated some years ago under COAG. In July of this year, COAG has invited from the state and the Commonwealth a paper that addresses these issues. That is what we have been working on in recent months and that was the subject I was referring to in that speech in Adelaide.

You have asked me that question in relation to Shark Bay before. I have said to you that I am addressing the issue of the petroleum permits that have been granted. When Shark Bay was listed, there were petroleum permits at that time and they were accepted under the then regional plan. There is nothing particularly new in that; nevertheless, I have my views on that subject which I have put down here and which, as you know, I am dealing with the Western Australian government to further.

In relation to the Giblett block in Western Australia, it is true that, as I understand, it is under the National Estate. It was found, under the regime set up by the previous Commonwealth government, not to be necessary for the purposes of a comprehensive, representative and adequate reserve, the values in that block being well represented elsewhere in the Western Australian forests.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister may have not understood what the issues are in either of those areas. He said that he has `discussed' issues in petroleum exploration—and not done anything. We are just wondering what national significance is. The most significant area in Giblett that your own Heritage Commission advised was the area in Giblett to avoid is the one that CALM is targeting.

QUESTION.PARA: Your claims on these matters are best addressed, you say, cooperatively in intergovernmental agreements. But surely the situation in Giblett, where CALM is totally ignoring the advice from the Australian Heritage Commission and deliberately targeting for logging those areas considered by the AHC to have the highest conservation values and most likely to be adversely affected by logging activity, highlights the need for Commonwealth intervention. Just what is nationally significant if you are forgetting that the states are ignoring your advice? When do you step in?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is quite a bit in that supplementary question. As I recall it, the Australian Heritage Commission itself said that those forests were not necessary to achieve a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve in Western Australia. Isn't that correct, Senator?
—They said that coupe continuity is the most valuable.

—The trouble with the Greens is they always exaggerate. In relation to Shark Bay, there is not actually petroleum exploration taking place at all. If you wanted to tell the full story, you would come in here and say, `Before exploration takes place these companies would have to go through a Western Australian environmental impact study process.' But permits were granted. I have my views on those, I have put them down in this chamber and I have negotiated with Western Australian authorities in relation to that.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Given that the minister has decided to set up three new programs in Defence—logistics, personnel and training—by what processes will the services bid for the resources in those three new programs? Will these processes involve the services competing against each other for resources? What remedies will be available to the various service chiefs to object when they believe they are receiving an unfair allocation of resources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I imagine that such matters will continue much as they have before with, I think, eight programs in the Department of Defence. There has always been a need to bid for resources.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the most important part of your question was the latter part where you referred to the service chiefs. As I understand it, Minister McLachlan is very keen to make sure that he is made aware by the Chief of the Defence Force, his primary adviser on all matters military, if and when any of the service chiefs have a different point of view so that he as the minister can ask for that to be made known to him directly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. There were dire predictions that the number of students enrolled in Australian universities would collapse with the introduction of both higher and differential HECS contributions in 1997. The Democrats spokesman claimed in a February press release that enrolments were down. Will the minister inform the Senate whether Senator Stott Despoja's predictions have been proven true or false?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Abetz. I am pleased to inform the Senate that he who is often referred to as Chicken Little over there has been proved wrong. The sky, in fact, is not falling in on higher education in Australia. Universities have more places for Australians than ever before.
—More places?
—Yes, it is true. Their enrolments and revenues are thriving. Australians have shown a strong and growing appreciation of the value to them of higher education.

ANSWER.PARA: The changes to HECS, both the increases in the levels and the introduction of a differentiated band, have had no significant impact on enrolments. In fact, there were more government-funded undergraduate places this year than last year and universities have accepted 26,000 more students over and above the government-funded places available.

Senator Carr said our changes would mean fewer opportunities for Australians to attend a university. That has clearly been rubbished by this data. Senator Stott Despoja predicted a drop in university enrolments. In one of the hundreds of press releases she put out—she spends every day putting three or four out—she has been proved wrong again. They had not even finalised the enrolments at the time, yet there was a claim we would have fewer enrolments.

Peter Baldwin, the then education spokesperson, claimed that there would be unfilled places and a general decline in demand for university courses in another February press release. Did it happen? No, it did not. Demand for law and medicine have not collapsed—in fact, medicine and dentistry have increased. Engineering is over‐enrolled. So are teacher education, the performing arts and business courses. There are increases in mathematics, in computing science and in a whole range of areas.

The partial information and rumours on applications that were circulated late last year touted the collapse of higher education. It is not the applications, rumours of application levels or reports about numbers of offers that matter. What matters is the number of people who are on the books at 31 March when they become liable for HECS. These are the figures we are talking about. This is the real evidence.

But there is more. The figures also mean that there are more opportunities for Australians to go to university. They mean that Australians recognise the value of the opportunity and are willing to make an investment in their future. The increase in fee paying postgraduate places will add an estimated $12 million to university revenues. Increased Commonwealth operating grants over and above last year will add $67 million to the funds universities received last year.

Senator Stott Despoja yet again said that overseas students have expressed concern about the government's cutbacks and the impact on higher education—prophesying doom and gloom for the export market of higher education. She will be pleased to know that there are increased enrolments of international students, which will add an estimated $92 million to the level of revenue which was available in 1996. Overseas students clearly know the state of Australian universities and are voting with their feet.

Increases to Commonwealth funding of research will add a further $23 million in 1997—altogether another $194 million in revenue for Australian universities over what they had last year. So the truth is finally out: there are more students; there is more revenue for universities; the sector is thriving.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Have the Bollinger Bolshevik, Senator Carr, or Peter Baldwin or Senator Stott Despoja apologised for their misleading statements?
—Senator Abetz, I ask you to refer to Senator Carr differently.
—Senator Carr is often referred to by a number of titles, but I will not do so on this occasion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Abetz because he does remind me that Gary Gray, the National Secretary of the Labor Party, indicated that one reason Labor had done so badly was that they could never bring themselves to say they were sorry. They never said they were sorry for the recession we had to have or for what they did to unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Carr has not said he is sorry for misleading the Australian public or misleading Australian students. Senator Stott Despoja never says she is sorry for misleading the students, for using them in her political barrage to take over the Democrats. As far as Senator Stott Despoja is concerned, there is not room for two blondes down there and she is working on it. She will use anybody. She will misuse Australian students or anybody she can to get there.

She will not say she is sorry. She should because she is one of the key people who have been trying to tell students that they will not be able to go to university unless they have got a lot of money. What an atrocious lie for an education spokesperson to tell students you need money to go to university! You should be ashamed of yourself and you should apologise. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, given that it has been confirmed that your cabinet duties were completed by 1 p.m. on 3 March, do you persist with your claim: `Senator Colston was nowhere near my office at all on that day'? Do you continue to assert that your first knowledge of Senator Colston's defence for his bogus travel allowance claims occurred when you visited him in his office approximately in the week prior to 24 March? Have you checked with Senator Colston to ascertain whether he recalls being in your office on 3 March or was your last contact with him the telephone conversation he had with you on 8 April when he rang you to say that Mrs Christine Smith had recanted her statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a lot of assumptions in that question, of course. The fact is—
—The timing is right. That is the evidence from Senator Hill.
—You tell me that the cabinet meeting finished by 1 o'clock. I do not remember your being there.
—He said it at estimates.

—All right, so he said it at estimates. I was not at estimates, so I did not know that, did I? What I did say the other day—let us be precise—was that I read that article in the newspaper which said that Senator Colston was in and out of my office all day on Monday, the 3rd.

ANSWER.PARA: I checked with a number of members of my staff. They had the same recollection as me, and that was that Senator Colston had been nowhere near my office at all on that day. That remains my recollection. I have no reason subsequently to think that he was, and I cannot do any better than that. There is no-one else that I need to be checking my memory with. I am perfectly confident in my own mind that that was a day on which not only cabinet matters preoccupied the morning but there were other matters in the afternoon. I am not sure precisely what commitments I had, but those who would be in a position to notice who came into the office are those whom I have spoken to.
As far as your suggestion about a bogus defence is concerned, once again there you go prejudging issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that at all.
—You asked me about when I knew in relation to the bogus defence.
—No, the bogus travel claims.

—All right. Sorry—the defence of a bogus travel claim. If that is not prejudging the issue, I do not know what is. There you are at it again. There is no pretence at all of objectivity or impartiality. We know your agenda. You have been transparent. You are probably more honest about it than most of your colleagues. The fact is you are determined to hound Senator Colston come hell or high water. You are prepared to assert assumptions of guilt when we are not. We note the facts of the matter, and the facts of the matter are that there have been two statements now tabled in this chamber over the name of Christine Smith, which have been contradictory to a certain extent. If those are the facts—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am saying not in every respect but in some respects. Those are matters, therefore, that are properly to be scrutinised by the Federal Police. Beyond that, we make no judgment. You clearly do make a judgment, and I take the strongest issue with you.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that you asked me about the events of 8 April, and I seem to recall that you were saying the other day that you were aware of those events at 6 p.m. on that night. I think the Senate would be very interested to know how you came by that knowledge, which presumably is well in advance of the matters going public. As far as I am aware, the first time that anyone made them known in public was when Mr Howard called his press conference at around 9 o'clock. The leaders of the parties—Senator Hill was overseas at the time—were provided with the material which enabled Mr Howard to make that statement. As I understand it, Mr Howard did not come into possession of that information until some time around 8 o'clock.

So, if you got that information at around 6 o'clock, you ought to be up here telling us how you did that because, to the extent that you suggest there is anything sinister about people having advanced knowledge, you are up to your eyeballs in it. I would have thought it would be very interesting to know precisely what role you have played in all of these matters and to what extent you had that sort of advanced knowledge. But, at the end of the day, there is nothing improper in being advised of those sorts of matters. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I make the shameful admission that it was the News Ltd bureau that rang me at about 6 o'clock to ask me whether I knew anything about it. The relevant issue is not a pursuit of Senator Colston here, Senator Alston. It is your statements and whether you have either deliberately or inadvertently misled the Senate. That is what you are being asked about today.

QUESTION.PARA: There are two cruxes of the matter. The first is: have you checked thoroughly that the statement you made here at question time is correct? You said you have checked with your staff. I asked you—and you have not answered—whether you have checked with Senator Colston as to whether he can recall being in your office on that day to help refresh your memory. The second is: you in an answer here said the first you knew about the Christine Smith defence was when you were introduced to her in Senate Colston's office in the week before the 24th. I am asking you whether you had knowledge before that, presumably from meetings—if they occurred—that you cannot remember on 3 March?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I have made it abundantly clear that as soon as I read that suggestion in the newspapers I did check with my staff. What I have told the Senate now on two occasions is entirely consistent with that recollection. I do not need to go beyond that. I do not need to go off and test my own recollection. The fact is that I have made it perfectly clear—
—You can't even remember if you signed off the ABC submission.

—The people in my office would be in the best position to know, even if I had forgotten. I am simply saying to you that, on the face of it, if you accept that I was at a cabinet meeting until 1 o'clock in the afternoon, I would have thought that makes it plain that Senator Colston could not have been in and out of my office all day on 3 March. So the fact is that even the suggestion itself is questionable. I have taken the matter as far as I need to. I have made it perfectly plain that I have exhausted my memory on the subject.

BREAK.PARA: As far as when I first became aware of it, again I have made it plain that I have no knowledge of being made aware of it until such time as I spoke to those in Senator Colston's office. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, the Council of Intellectual Disability told a New South Wales parliamentary committee yesterday that almost 1,000 young disabled people in New South Wales are forced to live in nursing homes with elderly residents. Minister, do you consider nursing homes to be appropriate permanent accommodation for young people with disabilities and mental illness? How many young disabled people are there throughout Australia in such accommodation? Why does the Aged Care Bill not mention people with disabilities or how they will be affected by the nursing home entry fees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe personally that they are ideal places for people with severe disabilities, if they are young, to spend years in. However, that has been a point of last shelter, you might say, for many years for people for whom there was no other appropriate accommodation. That means that under the previous government that was the situation too.

ANSWER.PARA: I know that Mrs Moylan has been having a lot of discussions in recent times with the states to see what we can do better for people in Australia with disabilities. I know that this government has been across portfolios focusing very much on improving the lot of people with disabilities, and their carers. Beyond that, obviously, at this stage of the day, I am not able to say any more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her response. However, we would like to know what the government is prepared to do, particularly in the case where we end up with a two‐tier system in nursing homes, as many people believe we will with your so-called reform? What sort of accommodation and services can we expect for these young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to take that on notice to the minister responsible, Madam President.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, I refer to your earlier rather garbled response to a question Senator Mackay asked about the 10‐point plan. You stated that the Commonwealth has no role in land management and that this is exclusively a matter for the states. Can you then confirm that the Commonwealth government will not be requiring pastoralists to pay the full commercial upgrade of their pastoral leases to freehold? Does this mean the states will be able to charge whatever they want, even a nominal fee, for these upgrades? Won't this create a massive windfall gain for pastoralists, including for many of your coalition colleagues? What benefit can this possibly have for Aboriginal people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another example of the confusion that exists around the community, and certainly in the Labor Party. Stories have been put out by the Democrats as well that there is suddenly a massive windfall gain for somebody. There is no massive windfall gain. There cannot be a massive windfall gain. You really have no idea of what exists both in the territories and in the states.
—Tell us. You have four minutes.
—It would require, Senator Collins, as you know, a clear understanding of the laws that exist in each of the states and the territories, so there is no massive windfall gain.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator West asked me a question on 7 May regarding expenditure on the defence efficiency review. Based on information supplied to me by the Department of Defence, I advised the Senate that total expenditure on the review had been $240,000 up until mid‐April. I have subsequently been advised that this information provided to me was incorrect to the extent that the figure was in the order of $260,000 up until mid‐April. Since 7 May, further expenditure has been brought to account which makes the current cost of the defence efficiency review the sum of $282,151.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to a question without notice asked by Senator Margetts today, relating to environmental responsibilities of the Commonwealth.

I rise to take note of the answer that Senator Hill gave to my question in relation to the Commonwealth's responsibility in terms of the environment and the Commonwealth's lack of responsibility that has been clearly shown at the moment. The minister gave me information which is clearly incorrect. Perhaps if the minister listened to my answer instead of wondering around the chamber he might be able to respond in time and let the Senate know why he gave me incorrect information.

Today, the minister, Senator Hill, who has not actually been listening to my response, indicated that he received advice from the Australian Heritage Commission. He did preface that remark with `I believe'. I think he ought to check back on the advice he has received from the Australian Heritage Commission in relation to the Giblett block.

The advice indicates that, given the totality of the Giblett block, more than 10 per cent of which the Department of Conservation and Land Management is proposing to trash and which is currently being resisted in as many ways as possible by the wider community, that particular coupe which is currently about to be bulldozed and trashed is the area which the Australian Heritage Commission indicated should not under any circumstances be logged, because of its ecological values. The minister ought to re‐advise the Senate of his actual information.

BREAK.PARA: The advice of the Heritage Commission indicated that there may be a coupe within the Giblett block which has less ecological value than the one CALM are currently targeting at the moment. However, that is not the one that has currently had its undergrowth bulldozed and that has been damaged. This is the trashing of old-growth forests which have been recognised as having important significant values and which had interim listing on the heritage list. Basically, the minister owes the Senate an apology. The minister needs to get better advice in relation to this.

We are talking about the proposed harvesting operations in Giblett Hawke. Of particular concern is the location of coupes in the centre of large areas of old-growth forest in the north‐east Carey Brook subareas, Gibletts 7A and 7B, and the fragmentation of large areas of old-growth forests in the lower Donnelly subarea of operations in the Hawke block.

This is the Australian Heritage Commission's advice. This was the advice to the previous minister David Beddall. The minister obviously did not check back on his advice or did not have an answer ready, but remembered possibly that there might have been an area in the Giblett which they said might have been better. He has actually misled the Senate in indicating that the area that they are currently about to cut is somehow or other not considered to be important and not considered by the Australian Heritage Commission to be worth saving. The Australian Heritage Commission certainly gave exactly the opposite advice to the former minister. Nothing that I have seen indicates that anything has changed since that advice was given on 5 December 1994 to change the nature of that advice.

If, Minister, you are coming in and claiming that you can give to the states—throw away—your power to overrule on the basis of national significance then it is about time you worked out exactly what national significance is. If you dismiss concerns of the community as well as advice from your own Australian Heritage Commission and then come in here and say that, somehow or other, you are looking after environmental values on a national scale, that is disgraceful. It is time that you explained to this chamber exactly what you are doing as Minister for the Environment. What does national heritage consist of when you are even prepared to allow war games on the Great Barrier Reef, and to trash Shark Bay and Giblett interim heritage listed areas? What is sacred in the environment and when does this government, and you as minister, actually stand up and do something? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts has cogently put the case for the minister—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FERGUSON

TALK.START.PARA: —You may as well sit down then.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Patterson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The members opposite, including Senator Ferguson and Senator Patterson, think this is a joke. But the Australian public that are concerned about the forests have a much more serious point of view. They believe that these forests should be protected, and that is why there are a number of citizens, enduring a great deal of discomfort and the risk of worse, doing the job of the failed Minister for the Environment, Senator Robert Hill, down in the forests of Western Australia as we sit here.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be all right for the coalition members opposite, in their comfortable position, as we all have in this Senate, to dismiss what those people are doing down there. Those people are carrying out the real work that this Senate ought to be doing, and that is protecting this nation's heritage, not least this nation's forest heritage. Having been to Giblett block two years ago when similar protests were taking place under the past government—

TALK.START.PARA: —I've been there too.

—Senator Collins says that he has been there too, and I accept that. What is remarkable is that the previous government was also in the business of allowing logging to take place in this magnificent piece of forest. Some of the tallest hardwoods and some of the most grand living creatures on the face of the planet, in the form of the Giblett block karris and jarrahs, are being cut down to be taken to the wood chip mills and exported to the rubbish dumps of the Northern Hemisphere for a quick dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: In those circumstances there is a heavy responsibility on the shoulders of the Minister for the Environment to intervene in the national interest. But instead of that we find that he is an agent of destruction; we find that he has ignored advice from his own advisers which says, in part:
It is the Commission's—
This is the Australian Heritage Commission—
view that this proposal—
to log the area—
will have a regionally significant adverse impact on old‐growth forest within the Southern Forest Region,—
of Western Australia—

and a localised adverse impact on site expressions of a range of national estate values, including: representative vegetation communities; vegetation assemblages; vegetation community diversity values; biotic and abiotic processes; and wilderness characteristics.

The minister says to Senator Margetts, `Leave it to the Western Australian government because it is going to destroy those values,' and he gets up and misleads the Senate by saying that he has not had advice that this area be protected. He has had advice, and he stands indicted yet again for his failure to do his job; for his failure to stand with the majority of Australians in seeing that these forests are protected for their inherent national and international values and for their importance to the future of this nation.

It is a pretty disgraceful situation that we face. It is a dereliction of duty by a minister whose actions are reprehensible, not for what he is actually doing but for what he is failing to do. He is failing to stand up for key parts of this nation's heritage. He is going to be taken on by the Greens all the way down the line as he fails to do the job he is charted to do, as he fails to carry his responsibility into the cabinet to speak up for and defend the environment and as he fails his commission as chief environmentalist in this country: to advocate for the environment—not to be against it as he is; and to protect these forests—not to be part of actions by this government leading to their destruction. He has become an agent of destruction rather than an agent of protection and he is a disgrace as far as the environment is concerned. He is welshing on his responsibilities to protect the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I ask you to ask the honourable senator to withdraw that remark that he made about the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It is unparliamentary, and he knows it.
—Senator, would you withdraw the words, please?
—He can have that withdrawal.
—Unconditionally, thank you.
—He can have that withdrawal, but the fact is—
—Order! Your time has expired, but I would like an unconditional withdrawal, thank you.
—He has got that withdrawal. That is what I said. Look at the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond briefly to Senator Margetts. I do not think Senator Brown added anything of use to the debate. In fact, I have not seen him make a useful contribution to the environment in the 13 months that I have been in this job. There is still a lot of shrill noise but very little constructive contribution to useful environmental outcomes.

SPEECH.PARA: The sad story is that the Greens are about 20 years out of date now. They are still throwing themselves in front of bulldozers, and climbing trees, when most of Australia has gone on to develop the principles of sustainable development and to look at ways in which we can gain material benefit while at the same time protecting the environment and passing it on to future generations in a better state than that in which we inherited it.

That is what most Australians are interested in. That is why landcare has been so successful, and coastcare, and all those thousands of community groups representing hundreds of thousands of Australians who do not just throw themselves in front of bulldozers; they get out there at weekends planting trees, getting rid of the weeds and doing useful things.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're getting rid of weeds while you're destroying the forests.
—Senator Brown, you could do it too. You could get out there on a weekend and do something constructive and help the environment. It would be much more useful than what you do in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the harvesting of native timbers, your position is fundamentally different from the major parties in Australia, because the major parties are not opposed to any harvesting of native forest. The major parties believe that there should be a balance. You are opposed to all harvesting of native forest, come what may. If that is your starting point, then you have to oppose all of this harvesting, come what may.

But the major parties basically have decided, as you know, under an agreement which is not only historic but which leads the world, to try to find a good balance between providing a sustainable resource for harvesting that can provide people with the material benefits they need, whilst at the same time developing a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system that is as good as anything that has been developed anywhere on the globe. It is that commitment that we are putting into practice.

Under the previous government, before the process got politically corrupted, my memory is that the DFA that was prepared—the scientifically based assessment as to what would be necessary for a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve, to which the AHC contributed—did not include the Giblett block. That is the basis of my answer, Senator Margetts. I will check that, but I think that is correct. Then, as you know, the process got corrupted and Labor decided to expand the DFA to include the whole of the national estate.

When we came to government we said that for purposes of progressing the CRA it was necessary to get back to the scientifically agreed area. We went back to the previous boundaries, but we did it through negotiation with the Western Australian government. It agreed that for a period, anyway, in excess of what they were obliged to do under the scientifically based agreement, about two‐thirds of Giblett block should continue to be protected, until the CRA process was finished and we could determine absolutely what was necessary for that comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve. They are now progressing to harvest a small part of what was left.
Senator Margetts interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Giblett—is this right?—is a 5,000 hectare block. In agreement with us, Western Australia agreed to take out about two‐thirds of that. Out of the balance, they are seeking to harvest about 500 hectares. So that is about one‐tenth of the whole of the Giblett block. As I understand it, firstly, the AHC agreed that it was not necessary for a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve; and secondly, the Western Australian government is only harvesting one‐tenth of it in any event.
—It's the best part.

—I have been there; I know it is a beautiful area, but, in all the circumstances, that seems to be a reasonable balance between providing jobs, providing material welfare for people, and on the other hand, protecting the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) to questions without notice asked by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) and Senator Mackay today, relating to the Prime Minister's 10point plan in response to the High Court decision in the Wik case.
There is currently a serious dispute on foot between the coalition partners over the question of alleged commitments given by the Prime Minister to his coalition partners, on which he failed to—

BREAK.PARA: Senator Ellison interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are at liberty to tell us about that. Madam Deputy President, The question of extinguishment of native title on pastoral leases and the representations made by the National Party led to what I found to be a very strange amendment produced to the 10‐point plan. I do not know who it was that was playing members of the National Party for mugs—I do not know whether it was the Prime Minister or whether it was, indeed, the National Party's own leadership—because immediately after this debacle came about, the Prime Minister released an amendment to the 10‐point package in respect of extinguishment of native title on pastoral leases which changed it to the extent of saying that there would be extinguishment on pastoral leases which provided for exclusive possession.

BREAK.PARA: I just thought that change was hilarious, because it was no concession whatsoever. It was no change whatsoever to the position. It was, in fact, what the High Court has said from day one. I wondered that day just who it was that was playing members of the National Party for mugs—the people who were, in fact, intended by that change to believe there had been some kind of shift in respect of the 10‐point plan. If they were not intended to believe that, then why was that silly change made?

The High Court, ever since Mabo and including the Wik decision, has made it absolutely clear that where, legally, exclusive possession exists in a title, then native title is excluded. So I am not quite sure who it was that was playing National Party members for mugs. But I am not surprised, because, as I said in the Senate yesterday, never has a decision of the High Court of Australia been so deliberately distorted and misrepresented as the Wik decision.

I refer to something that Senator Boswell has had to say, and he has repeated this many times. In respect of this real attempt at a land grab—which is the significant upgrading of the actual lease conditions themselves—let me tell you one thing that I can guarantee from a personal perspective. When this legislation comes before the Senate, if indeed it does contain provisions that will result in some massive change in the Crown's current position in respect of leasehold land across Australia, then I will want to see the relevant Senate committee examine it in very close detail.

In fact, it would be a great vehicle to use for actually having a look at who really does own Australia at the moment and under what conditions. I would be personally interested in pursuing that because I am genuinely angry about the way in which the High Court decision has been distorted in recent weeks to suggest that somehow or other pastoralists have been economically disadvantaged in respect of the value of their properties as a result of the Wik decision. Senator Boswell has made that claim many times. He has said that this upgrading of leases is needed so that the value of pastoral leasehold land could be restored and, to quote Senator Boswell, be put back to square one after it had been devalued by Wik.

In this flood of misrepresentation, I draw the attention of all honourable senators to just one of a number of interviews given by Mr John Sheehan, a representative of the Australian Institute of Valuers and Land Economists. This is the institute that provides advice to banks and lending institutions about the value of land. This particular interview was on 25 April, Anzac Day. In response to a question about the institute's position on the value of land, Mr Sheehan said that in:

. . . the decision of the . . . institute . . . nothing has changed. The case and the decision that came out of the case clarified the rights that were held by the pastoral lessees and probably, at the end of the day, little more than that.
He went on to say:

. . . the judgment in the Wik decision indicated that there were certain rights that were held by pastoral lessees, there may have been some anticipation by the holders of those leases, that they had something that was equivalent to freehold, but certainly that wasn't the case. I mean, they were holding leasehold.

They were holding leasehold land. As the institute has said previously, the rights that were held by pastoral leases are unchanged as a result of the Wik decision. I might add that is also the position of the Australian Bankers Association. It made a statement to a Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation meeting last year to that effect. I have checked with the association today and it has confirmed that its position has not changed. The Wik decision has not devalued pastoral leases. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will begin by refuting the suggestion that this change to the 10‐point plan is a silly change or that there was any attempt to play anybody in our coalition for mugs. It was a very sensible explicit statement of what is in fact the common law, that we wish to clarify and confirm by statute—that is, that any title that confers exclusive possession, including pastoral leases that confer exclusive possession, will extinguish native title. That is quite accurately, as Senator Collins said, a statement of the common law, and we wish to confirm it in legislation and thus give certainty to those lessees who have exclusive possession that they do not have any native title interfering with their leases. It is a great pity that that was not made clear in the Native Title Act a great deal earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with this outrageous proposition that there is some sort of land grab going on in relation to the 10‐point plan. It seems that many senators and members of the Commonwealth parliament are completely ignorant of the fact that land management in this country has been and is a function of state governments for the whole of the federation. It should and will remain a function of the state and territory parliaments. What has introduced the Commonwealth parliament into the arena is, of course, native title matters and the Racial Discrimination Act. But the states and territories have responsibility for land management. That enables them to upgrade leases. They have had that power and continue to have that power.

They also have powers of compulsory acquisition, and the Native Title Act passed through this parliament by this Senate provides for the continuation of compulsory acquisition powers by state parliaments and state governments. They can, as provided for in the Native Title Act now, compulsory acquire native title rights where they exist on any land. That is provided for in the Native Title Act. The Native Title Act does set out that the compulsory acquisition must involve the payment of just‐terms compensation—quite properly—and if it involves the compulsory acquisition of those rights, for the benefit of a third party, it must go through a right to negotiate process. So all that we are proposing in a 10‐point plan is to build on that very proposition and that very system provided for in the Native Title Act passed by this parliament—no more and no less.

We will continue to allow state and territory governments to compulsorily acquire native title rights where they believe that is appropriate and within their powers over land management. If there is any proposition to upgrade a title—which, of course, those state governments have always had power to do—and that involves the acquisition of native title rights, then, as provided for in the Native Title Act now, they can do it. However, they must pay just‐terms compensation for the acquisition of those native title rights and they must follow due process. They must give the native title holders the same procedural rights as any other title holder on the land in question. We have said as a Commonwealth government that, in relation to the compensation that is paid by the state government, we will meet 75 per cent of the cost. That again is a continuation of the arrangements made by the Keating government where it committed itself to paying 75 per cent of compensation for past acts.

We will pay 75 per cent of compensation in relation to future acts, which includes compensation resulting from compulsory acquisition. However, we have a very clear caveat on that payment of the 75 per cent compensation: that is, if it involves the upgrading of any title of the kind that has been described, the state or territory must charge a betterment factor that must reflect the increase in the commercial value of the title granted to the title holder.
