SPEECH.PARA: There is already a high degree of consultation between the States/Territories and the Commonwealth in the context of the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs (MCEETYA) which is responsible for developing strategic policy at the national level for pre‐primary, primary and secondary education, vocational education and training, adult and community education, youth policy programs and cross‐sectoral matters.

MCEETYA plays an important planning and coordination role by bringing together State, Territory and Commonwealth Education Ministers to consider issues of mutual interest and to coordinate collaborative activity. One of the MCEETYA Subgroups, the Languages Other Than English (LOTE) in Schools Subgroup of the MCEETYA Taskforce on the Australian Language and Literacy Policy, completed a collaborative strategy in February 1995 which outlines the main objectives and tasks which need to be addressed co‐operatively by States and Territories to ensure that the teaching and learning of languages in Australian schools are strengthened.

The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has also been active in supporting a review of the situation in relation to low candidature languages in the Higher Education Sector. The Department recently published a report produced by the National Languages and Literacy Institute of Australia Ltd. entitled The Viability of Low Candidature LOTE Courses in Universities . The purpose of the report was to map the situation relating to low candidature languages in Australia and to develop low cost recommendations about strategies which institutions might pursue in order to preserve a national capacity to deliver low candidature languages.

The Government does not support this recommendation as it would involve duplication of the existing consultative arrangements between the State/Territories and the Commonwealth, in particular, the planning and coordination role of MCEETYA in the development and coordination of language teaching in Australia. However, the findings of the Report will be brought to the attention of MCEETYA.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs formally examine the capacity and effectiveness of Thai studies institutions other than the National Thai Studies Centre, with a view to promoting the teaching of integrated Thai studies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DEETYA) has through its various programs supported more integrated Thai studies courses in Australia. However, DEETYA does not have responsibility for decisions regarding the structure and content of language courses at the tertiary level. Decisions regarding course content are the responsibility of the relevant higher education institutions. On this basis the Government does not believe it would be appropriate for DEETYA to undertake a review of Thai studies institutions in Australia to examine their capacity and effectiveness with a view to promoting the teaching of integrated Thai studies.

That in relevant forums such as the Ministerial Council on Employment, Education , Training and Youth Affairs, education authorities recognise the need to assist small candidature languages such as Thai by:

PARA.EMPHASIS: placing greater emphasis on strengthening the links between the teaching of Asian languages at primary, secondary and tertiary levels; and
ensuring attention is given to linking language studies with the teaching of history and culture.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is keen to promote the articulation of the teaching of Asian languages between the different sectors as it creates the opportunity for students to increase the actual hours of language learning available to students in Australia.

However, one of the main problems with achieving this articulation between the sectors is the limited number of schools that actually offer Thai language study. While DEETYA has been involved in a project to develop curriculum for Year 11 and 12 Thai language teaching and has been providing funding to encourage Thai language teaching, there are still very few schools in Australia that offer the subject.

The Government is seeking to encourage the school system to consider Thai as a possible language alternative by offering schools access to qualified Thai language teachers. This is being pursued under the Memorandum of Understanding with the Thai Ministry of Education. The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs is currently negotiating the development of a teacher exchange between Thailand and Australia. The exchange program has the potential to provide Australian schools with high quality native Thai language speakers while providing opportunities for their own teachers to be involved in a valuable staff development activity.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Task Force established to implement the recommendations of the Council of Australian Governments' report entitled Asian Languages and Australia's Economic Future give appropriate emphasis to the crucial importance of teacher training and proficiency to the success of Asian studies in schools, and to the particular needs of languages such as Thai.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government believes that the Taskforce established to implement the recommendations of the Council of Australian Governments' report entitled Asian Languages and Australia's Economic Future has to date given the appropriate emphasis to the importance of teacher training and proficiency.

The Government accepts that a high standard of teacher training and proficiency is an important element of the success of all studies in schools in Australia, including Asian studies and will bring the Committee's recommendation to the attention of the Taskforce.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That AusAID be encouraged to maintain a development assistance program in Thailand which makes maximum use of the range of Australian skills and technology to help in resolving the range of problems confronting that country. (See also

SPEECH.PARA: The development assistance program in Thailand will continue to be focused on key needs and mutual interests. It will reflect Thailand's rapid economic development and will maximise the use of Australian skills and technology.

In response to Thailand's phenomenal economic growth and diminished need for funding from aid sources, the assistance program will decline, but it will continue to reflect the close political relationship, and the need to further enhance Australian/Thai relations through development cooperation.
The objectives of the transition program are to assist Thailand maintain its strong economic and social growth by providing technical assistance targeted at key constraints to development.
The program will focus on five key sectors:

PARA.TAB: education, to assist with Thailand's shortage of trained human resources and the constraints that increasing skills shortages pose;
health, focused on the HIV/AIDS pandemic;
energy, to assist with Thailand's pressing need for expanded and efficient energy production and use;
the environment, to deal with the key developmental issue of effective environmental planning and management; and
social security and good governance, providing assistance to meet Thailand's targets for fully implementing its social security system.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Australian Government continue to encourage and support the Government of Thailand to reduce tariffs as agreed at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation group meeting at Bogor in 1994 .

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government will continue to support and encourage Thailand to reduce tariffs, both bilaterally and in regional and multilateral fora.

Thailand's 1996 Individual Action Plan (IAP) contains a commitment to reduce average tariffs from 30% in 1994 to 17% in 1997. The IAP also includes liberalisation commitments for non‐tariff measures (including expansion of tariff quotas for skim milk powder beyond Uruguay Round commitments) and some service sectors and a commitment to consider amending the Alien Business Law to allow greater foreign participation in Thai businesses. Australia will use all opportunities to press Thailand to include commitments to liberalise all its barriers to trade and investment in its IAP. The Government will continue to liaise closely with the Thai Government on the development of their 1997 Plan, and in particular will encourage Thailand to outline measures to reduce high applied tariffs in the agricultural, mining and industrial sectors, including the automotive sector. Australia will also encourage Thailand to liberalise its services trade, particularly financial and professional services.

In addition, through the APEC Support Program (ASP), AusAID is actively encouraging the participation of developing countries (including Thailand) in progressing the APEC agenda of trade liberalisation and trade facilitation. The purpose of the ASP is to support small high impact requests from Australian Government departments and statutory authorities for assistance aimed at supporting APEC. The ASP provides a flexible funding mechanism aimed at facilitating and strengthening links between Australian Government bodies and developing economies in the APEC region.
In the first three rounds of the APEC Support Program a number of activities involving Thai participation have been approved for funding. These include:

PARA.TAB: an APEC Competition and Consumer Officials Technical Assistance Program;
a study which aims to develop a database for analysis of the Asia‐Pacific regional labour market;
participation in the APEC Small and Medium Enterprise (SME) Ministerial Meeting and the APEC Opportunity Business Matching Forum;
provision of training in Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) for Thai health inspectors; and

participation in the Telecommunications Skills Standards project which aims to identify the areas in telecommunications where skills standards will have impact and develop draft competency or skills standards, and propose implementation strategies for education and training deliverers. Efforts are being made by the Department of Communications and the Arts to obtain funding for a study visit for staff from the Telephon Organisation of Thailand under the guidelines of the Personnel Exchange Program of the Telecommunications Working Group of APEC.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will continue to encourage the participation of Thailand in activities in support of trade facilitation and liberalisation through available mechanisms, including the ASP.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Australian Government urge the Government of Thailand to renegotiate documents such as the Treaty of Amity and Economic Relations with the United States of America to remove discrimination against third party countries in trade and commerce.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the preferential treatment accorded to US companies in Thailand has directly disadvantaged Australian companies competing for contracts. In both bilateral and multilateral fora, the Government has regularly encouraged Thailand to pursue all its trade relations on a MFN or non‐discriminatory basis and will continue to do so as appropriate.

The issue of the 1966 Treaty of Amity and Economic Relations with the United States of America was raised in December 1995 in discussions under the auspices of the Trade Policy Review Board of the World Trade Organization. Thailand's MFN exemption is expected to be reviewed by the WTO Council for Trade and Services in about four years. The Australian Government will seek to utilise this occasion to urge renegotiation of the Treaty. Thai Ministers have on a number of occasions confirmed that the Thai‐USA Treaty of Amity will be replaced in view of Thailand's obligations to international trade regimes.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That, in planning trade and industry missions to Thailand, Austrade should liaise with such bodies as the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Australian Chamber of Manufactures to ensure such missions have more focused objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees that there should be consultation with key industry bodies to ensure that trade missions are focused on developing commercial relationships in targeted industry sectors.

In 1994 Austrade organised an Australian Ministerial Business Mission to Thailand in cooperation with the Australia Thailand Business Council (ATBC) which exists under the umbrella support of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. This mission was focused on five key industry sectors which offered commercial opportunities for Australian companies. In the selection of these targeted industry sectors Austrade worked in close consultation with the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

Austrade and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade will continue to liaise closely with peak industry bodies, and in particular with the ATBC and the Australian Thai Chamber of Commerce (ATCC), to ensure that future trade missions and other related activities are focused and relevant to the needs of industry. Most recently, the ATBC has been closely involved with the holding of the inaugural Australia Thailand Ministerial Economic Commission in February 1997.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That a review be initiated to determine the relevance and effectiveness of the training and financial programs supporting Australian exports to Thailand.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government provides assistance through a number of agencies to support Australian firms' international competitiveness and market development activities. For example, the Australian Trade Commission provides assistance to Australian companies seeking to do business in the Thai market through the Export Market Development Grants Program (EMDG). Other programs, including the International Trade Enhancement Scheme (ITES), the Innovative Agricultural Marketing Program (IAMP) and the Asia Pacific Fellowship Program (APFP) were cut in the context of the 1996/97 budget. Austrade's business assistance programs are subject to on‐going internal and external reviews. The Government considers that as such assistance programs are provided to Australian companies on a global basis, a Thailand specific review would be inappropriate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the report of the tri‐partite Working Party on Labour Standards be provided to the Joint Standing Committee, with specific reference to any recommendations which might deal with:

PARA.TAB: promulgation of a code of conduct governing the operations of Australian businesses overseas; and
arrangements for appropriate training in the provisions and implementation of that code.

SPEECH.PARA: The Report of the Tri‐partite Working Party on Labour Standards has been presented to the Government, which has publicly circulated it to assist public discussion of the key issues dealt with.

The role of the Working Party was to examine ways in which Australia could promote and protect adherence to core labour standards in the Asia‐Pacific region. Given that the JSCFADT refrained from making recommendations on areas that it felt were in the Working Party's Terms of Reference (and that it expected the Working Party to make recommendations on) it seems appropriate to provide the JSCFADT with the Working Party's Report and Recommendations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chapter 6: Australian Development Assistance to Thailand

That the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and AusAID examine Thailand's needs for development assistance in the context of its economic progress and the commencement of Thailand's own assistance program to nations in its region.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government has examined Thailand's need for development assistance in the context of its economic progress and its own assistance program to regional nations. As noted in the response to Recommendation 7, Australia's development cooperation program is now in a transition phase reflecting Thailand's diminished need for aid funding. Future aid program activities will be responsive to Thailand's changing needs and capacities and to Australia's evolving major interests. The strategy being followed will result in a much smaller program by the turn of the century.

The Government is aware of Thailand's strong interest in regional cooperative activities. Thailand is keen to cooperate with Australia in the sub‐region and this presents opportunities for broadening the relationship. The Mekong Sub‐Region is the target of an expanded program of development assistance. As a sub‐regional program it has the potential to deliver mutual benefits to both Australia and Thailand. This program offers opportunities for Australian organisations to derive benefits from the development of the region and to help address, through cooperation with Thailand and other donors (eg the Asian Development Bank and the World Bank), the development constraints of the region.
Opportunities for funding projects on a tripartite basis with Thailand will continue to be explored. Such joint initiatives are seen as part of a partnership based on equality and shared interests.

Potential projects include the development of good governance practices and the implementation of a comprehensive social security scheme in Thailand, including an aged pension system and child allowance programs.
Projects currently taking place include:

PARA.TAB: development of regionally integrated national Geographic Information System (GIS) databases for the access and processing of information as a basis for multidisciplinary studies in most sectors; and

regionally integrated advanced geoscientific mapping by relevant Governments to provide a framework of geological information as a basis for area selection and exploration by mineral and petroleum companies—for the long‐term development of the relevant industries and associated socio‐economic benefits.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That AusAID examine the relevance of the present development assistance program in dealing with the urgent needs of the Thai people, especially those in the north and north east of the country, in fields such as health, trafficking in women for the purposes of prostitution, urban pollution, waste disposal and water quality. (See also Recommendation 7.)

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government is closely involved with the provision of assistance to Thailand, particularly in the fields of health, trafficking in women and children and environmental conservation. The Australian Government also strongly supports international cooperation to address the problem surrounding prostitution, including trafficking in women and children for the purpose of prostitution.

In the health sector AusAID's programs currently focus on the HIV/AIDS pandemic. Ongoing projects funded by AusAID in Thailand are targeted towards high risk groups such as intravenous drug users, commercial sex workers, youth and health workers, and include activities in border camps for displaced Burmese. The South East Asia Regional Health Initiative has supported a pilot immunisation program in Thailand, and also the integration of Hepatitis B vaccines into a national expanded program of immunisation. A health training project for displaced Burmese women in border camps was started in 1995/96. AusAID is also funding family planning and women's and children's health activities in the southern provinces of Thailand, targeting the Thai Muslim population.

In the environment sector Australia has contributed to the alleviation of urban pollution and waste disposal and water quality problems through a Solid Waste Management project. This project provided solid waste management, engineering and planning advice to Thai authorities for 12 regional cities and other regional municipalities. It has also assisted in the formulation of a solid waste and waste water program for the Thai Eighth National Plan (1997‐2001) to service a further 60 cities. Under the ASEAN‐Australia Economic Cooperation Program (AAECP) Phase III Australia is contributing to several regional projects involving activities in priority sectors agreed between ASEAN and Australia, such as environmental management including energy efficiency, conservation and energy demand management, biotechnology, telecommunications and information technologies and agriculture. Thailand, as a member of ASEAN, will derive substantial benefits from these activities.

In addition to the Projects Stream of the AAECP there is a Linkages Stream which aims at promoting economic cooperation between Australia and ASEAN through funding joint activities involving the private, research, academic and government sectors in ASEAN countries and Australia. Thailand has derived benefits from a range of Linkages Stream projects.

The proposed major development of the Quadrangle area (incorporating northern Thailand, parts of China, Burma and Laos) offers scope for an initial environmental impact study by relevant Australian agencies.

At the recent United Nations Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing, the Australian Government expressed its concern over international trafficking in women, particularly in the Asia Pacific Region, as a form of violence against women which needs to be addressed internationally as a priority issue.

There is scope to provide assistance towards the elimination of trafficking of women and children for prostitution under the Australian aid program via various NGO programs active in Thailand, and through a Small Activities Scheme administered at the Australian Embassy in Bangkok. In addition, the Australian Government supports the activities of End Child Prostitution in Asian Tourism (ECPAT) which seeks to help overcome child prostitution and trafficking through public awareness activities and creation of places in schools for children from target communities. The aid program's overall poverty alleviation and income generation activities will also help to overcome the economic basis for human trafficking and prostitution in source communities.

In the social sector, the Australian Government has assisted the Royal Thai Government in setting up its social security system. This has comprised the provision of expertise and the transfer of knowledge between Australian and Thai officials. There is capacity for the Australian Government to provide further assistance to Thailand to fully implement its social security system by 1998. The social stability afforded by a comprehensive income support system should assist the Royal Thai Government in its endeavours to alleviate poverty and, consequently, among other things, should reduce the need for families to resort to delivering girls and women into prostitution.
The Government will continue to examine further development assistance options in this area, particularly in relation to:

PARA.TAB: an increased emphasis on aid aimed at poverty alleviation, especially in rural communities;
developing a coordinated approach to the problem of trafficking in women and children which addresses the various aspects of the issue;
the monitoring and prevention of trafficking, including working with the Thai Government to develop strategies aimed at reducing the problem;
minorities and refugees in Thailand who are especially vulnerable to exploitation by the drug and sex industries;
the continued promotion of the equal participation of women in development cooperation projects; and
increased employment opportunities for women, especially in the north, to reduce the likelihood of dependence on prostitution.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chapter 7: Australia's Defence Relationship with Thailand
That the current military exercise and training links between Australian and Thailand continue and, if possible, be expanded.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government considers that military exercise and training links are an important part of the overall bilateral defence relationship with Thailand. This is reflected in the substantial program of training and exercise activities currently being conducted. The Department of Defence expects that the level of training activity with Thailand will continue at current levels.

The Government is also cognisant of the high resource cost of exercises and training activities and the imperative to ensure that maximum value is obtained from each activity. The Department of Defence continues therefore to regularly review its exercise and training activities, in consultation with the Royal Thai Armed Forces, to ensure that these activities contribute to our defence policy objectives and broader mutual interests in the most effective and efficient way.

The Department of Defence is exploring the possibility of increasing the frequency of the Army sub‐unit exchange, Exercise TEMPLE JADE, to biennial (currently triennial), thus alternating with Exercise CHAPEL GOLD, the annual training deployment to Thailand of the Rifle Company Butterworth. The Department of Defence is also planning to extend the scope of the next iteration of the Fleet Concentration Period KAKADU in 1997 by holding concurrent airforce‐to‐airforce talks.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Department of Defence examine ways to build and maintain an effective alumni network in Thailand of the graduates of Defence professional development, education and training courses in Australia. (See also Recommendation 19.)

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees that the formal creation of an alumni network could reinforce the personal and institutional links which are established between Australian and Thai defence personnel as a result of training together. The greatest value would be obtained from alumni networks based on cadet officer training institutions and command and staff colleges. These courses bring together personnel of high potential for a long period in which firm professional relationships can be nurtured.

Thai graduates of the Joint Services Staff college and the Army Command and Staff College already meet together in an informal network. The Depart ment of Defence will review the scope for widening this practice to the graduates of other cadet officer training institutions and staff colleges.

There could be resource implications in the establishment of additional alumni networks, depending on the level of support provided by the Department of Defence. These resource implications would need to be considered fully before detailed commitments of support could be made.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chapter 9: Employment, Educational and Training Relationships

That the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs investigate whether useful assistance could be provided to the technical and vocational education system in Thailand, given it has a widely acknowledged shortage of skills.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has already undertaken action in line with this recommendation.

Under the Memorandum of Understanding on Educational Cooperation with the Ministry of Education in Thailand, Australia has been assisting Thailand in developing a framework for the reform of the technical and vocational education (TVE) system. A report of Thailand's TVE system was prepared by a joint Thai/Australia project team in late 1995. The project team was jointly funded by AusAID and the then Department of Employment, Education and Training.

The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DEETYA) will be giving careful consideration to assisting the Ministry of Education to implement the recommendations of the report to undertake a 2 to 3 year program of activities aimed at introducing a cost effective, flexible national training system responsive to the needs of industry in Thailand. Activities under the program will include the establishment of a tripartite national committee for the TVE sector, a standards sub‐committee to oversee the introduction of competency standards into Thai industry and to assist with training for the development of competency standards including appropriate assessment procedures.
Where appropriate, DEETYA will continue to seek AusAID cooperation in this area.
AusAID has funded a range of activities to assist the technical and vocational education system in Thailand, including funding to support DEETYA's initiatives such as the one mentioned above.

In addition, a range of collaborative activities between Thai and Australian technical and vocational education institutions have been funded through AusAID's Private Sector Linkages Program (PSLP). These include funding to support the relationship described in Chapter 9 of the Committee's report between the South Australian Department of Technical and Further Education, SAGRIC International and the Rajamangala Institute of Technology. Other PSLP projects include: upgrading tourism and hospitality training through joint activities between the Casey College of TAFE and the Tourism Authority of Thailand's Hotel and Tourism Training Institute; and funding for the establishment of links between the NSW TAFE Commission and a number of private Thai vocational colleges in the areas of business studies, computing and English language. PSLP funding for technical and vocational education activities was $133,000 in 1994/95, $121,000 in 1995/96 and commitments for 1996/97 are currently $182,000.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs examine, with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Australian Vice‐Chancellors' Committee and the peak bodies of other interested educational bodies the effectiveness of the operations of the Australian International Education Foundation and report back to the Joint Standing Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Recent consultations with peak education bodies including the Australian Vice‐Chancellors' Committee, Australia TAFE International, Schools' International Group and the ELICOS Association indicate that there is a high level of satisfaction with progress being made by the AIEF.

However, in the context of the 1996‐97 Budget process, the AIEF, like other DEETYA programs, is under review. Consideration of the views of the Australian Vice Chancellors' Committee and other peak bodies is integral to this process.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Defence and Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs:

PARA.TAB: review current arrangements for the support given to alumni organisations in Thailand and estimate the human, financial and other resources which would be necessary to maintain contact with alumni of Australian universities there, with a view to introducing an effective and continuing system as soon as practicable; and
report the findings of this review to the Joint Standing Committee. (See also Recommendation 16.)

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government believes that a coherent and coordinated approach in support of alumni activities is important to the development of the education and training relationship between Australia and Thailand.

In 1993 under the aid program Australia established a Thai‐Australian Alumni Network, and supported a program of associated activities for alumni development. These arrangements were supported under Australia's aid program until 1995 when it was handed over to the Australian Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs to manage.

In May 1995, the Australian International Education Foundation (AIEF) National Alumni Secretariat was established in Canberra to enable the development of a national strategic approach to alumni activities. A ``Team Australia'' approach to alumni activities is being developed by the AIEF, AusAID, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Austrade.

In conjunction with the establishment of the new Secretariat in Canberra, the AIEF Education and Training Counsellor in Bangkok took on overall responsibility for alumni development and activities in Thailand in July 1995. The Counsellor has re‐oriented existing alumni activities into a self‐funding network called the Thai‐Australian Association (TAA). Support, encouragement and liaison with Australia's education and training community is provided to the TAA by the AIEF.

In addition to helping Thai alumni members keep in touch with each other the TAA also helps members develop contacts with the Australian community in Thailand, raises the profile of Australia as a provider of quality education and fosters commercial relationships between Thais and Australians.

Given the AIEF's recent efforts to develop this coordinated approach the Government believes that it is unnecessary for a review of current support given to alumni organisations to be undertaken at this stage. However, relevant reports of current alumni activities between Australia and Thailand could be provided to the Committee if required.

As stated under recommendation 16, the Department of Defence also supports the formal creation of an alumni network which could reinforce the personal and institutional links which are established between Australian and Thai defence personnel as a result of training together.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade provide office space and adequate secretariat and other support services for an officer of the Department to commence preparatory work on developing contact networks and information holdings which could form the basis for the later, formal creation of an Australia‐Thailand Institute.

SPEECH.PARA: Given current fiscal imperatives, the Government is not in a position to commit funds to support the establishment of an Australia‐Thailand Institute.

At the same time, the Government recognises the importance of broadening and deepening Australia's links with Thailand, including through stronger cultural, educational, scientific, sports, and other people to people connections. The Government will, therefore, continue to accord Thailand high priority in its international endeavours in these fields.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade encourage the simultaneous establishment of an Australia‐Thailand Institute and a Thailand‐Australia Institute:

PARA.TAB: to foster mutual knowledge and understanding between Australia and Thailand; and
to strengthen the cultural, educational and other links between Australia and Thailand.

SPEECH.PARA: See Recommendation 20.

That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation keep the programs shown in Asia by Australia Television under constant review, to ensure they are presenting a reasonable picture of Australian life and attitudes and that they are appropriate to the different cultures and life experiences of Asian nations .

The programs transmitted to the region through Australia Television are under regular review to ensure they are appropriate for the service and its audiences. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation's (ABC) program policies for its international service specify that program selection and scheduling will take into consideration regional cultural sensitivities, particularly in entertainment programs such as drama and comedy. (Further information is contained in ABC Editorial Policies, Section 7.2.)

That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the Special Broadcasting Service and the commercial television networks be encouraged to present a greater number of television programs made in Thailand to Australian audiences. Australian Broadcasting Corporation

ABC Television would be happy to consider programs from Thailand for screening on the network. However, experience in the past has been that limited programming is available in English, and that it has been comparatively unsophisticated in content and production.
The ABC would be willing to assess additional programs. The ABC Head of Program Purchasing is aware of this recommendation and will monitor available programming from Thailand for audition.
The ABC would require programs submitted for audition to be subtitled in English.
The Special Broadcasting Service (SBS)

SBS policy in relation to its television programming is to aim to provide 50% of the television schedule in the common language (English) and 50% in a wide range of community languages reflecting the changing composition of Australian society, having regard to:

PARA.TAB: the quality of available programs;
the number of speakers of a language resident in Australia; and
the obligation of SBS Television to be relevant to all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: SBS attempts to proportion the amount of airtime in each language to the number of people that speak that language at home in Australia. At the last census (1991) 0.39% of the people who speak a language other than English at home identified that language as Thai. Given that the proportion of Thai speakers is relatively low, the SBS is unlikely to significantly increase the number of hours transmitted annually in Thai. The SBS does, however, actively pursue its commitment to show programs from Thailand and the SBS maintains regular contact with suppliers in that country.
Commercial broadcasting sector

The commercial broadcasting sector is regulated by the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 . One of the objects of the Act is to "promote the availability to audiences throughout Australia of a diverse range of radio and television services offering entertainment, education and information" (Section 3(a)). The commercial television industry encourages and promotes cultural diversity through an advisory note attached to its Code of Practice. The relevant note states that "television management and producers should be concerned to reflect Australia's complex and culturally diverse society".

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Minister for Communications and the Arts, in considering the report of the inter‐departmental review of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's international services:

PARA.TAB: recognise the increasingly important role of Australian Television in projecting a favourable image of Australia to other countries of our region, including Thailand;
accept that without significant Commonwealth funding the service provided by Australia Television will not survive; and

in consultation with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, develop strategies to provide increased sponsorship for Australia Television from, in the first instance, Australian public sector organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the inter‐departmental review of ABC international broadcasting services the previous Government agreed to provide additional funding of $6.2 million (1995‐96) to the ABC in 1996‐97; 1997‐98 and 1998‐99 for the operation of the Australia Television (ATV) service—that is a total of $18.6 million over the next three years. Australian public sector organisations will continue to be able to support ATV under the new arrangements as sponsorship will continue to be accepted by ATV.

In the context of the 1996‐97 Budget the Government has decided that the services provided by ATV should be contracted out to the commercial sector. The government will discuss with the ABC Board ways in which this could be achieved while ensuring maintenance of ABC program content, particularly news and current affairs, on the service.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's Market Australia Unit used Australia Television to promote Market Australia's Inventive Australia campaign to enhance perceptions in East Asia (including Thailand) of Australia's capabilities in sophisticated goods and services. Market Australia concluded a cost‐effective agreement with ATV for the production and broadcasting of appropriate advertisements as part of the Inventive Australia campaign. However due to the budgetary climate, Market Australia's funding ceased at the end of financial year 1995/96. Given the constraints of the current economic climate the role of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in advancing the profile of Australia through media such as the ATV will be severely curtailed.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the expertise and resources within Radio Australia which were formerly dedicated to Thai language programs be retained within the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Broadcasting Corporation advises that while Radio Australia has reduced its Thai staff to two and has ceased shortwave broadcasting to Thailand, it continues to feed selected Thai radio stations with news and information about Australia.

In July 1996 the Government appointed Mr Bob Mansfield to undertake a review of the role and functions of the ABC with a view to refining the focus of current ABC services and activities, including ABC international services. His report, entitled The Challenge of a Better ABC , was presented to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Richard Alston on 24 January 1997. The report recommended

PARA.TAB: that the requirements for the ABC to broadcast programs to audiences outside Australia should cease;
that the ABC should retain the ability to transmit programs outside Australia if it chooses;

that the ABC should be permitted to apply net savings from the closure of Radio Australia to the achievement of its savings target—this should include any transmission savings, consistent with the Government's commitment to fund the ABC directly for its transmission costs; and
that if an appropriate commercial arrangement for the operation of Australia Television is not entered into before June 1997, the service should be closed down.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has indicated that it will consider these recommendations in the 1997‐98 budget context.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That AusAID examine, with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), the Australian International Agricultural Research Centre and relevant industry bodies, current planning and funding arrangements for the delivery of technology‐based development assistance to ensure:

PARA.TAB: Australia's objectives in Thailand and the region are being achieved; and
the capabilities of Australian agencies and industry bodies are being utilised.

SPEECH.PARA: As activities are developed in the priority sectors agreed with Thailand, AusAID will consult with CSIRO and other relevant bodies to ensure that Australian capabilities are utilised to the maximum extent practicable. In particular, consideration will be given to establishing a regular pattern of consultation between AusAID, CSIRO, ACIAR and other industry bodies in relation to the delivery of technology‐based development assistance.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade review, with other interested bodies such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), Australia's commitment to the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific to establish whether the resources devoted to it are appropriate, given the importance of the region to Australia and the competing demands of other regional bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government contributes to the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP) through assessed contributions to the United Nations regular budget under the Australian aid program. The Australian Government is one of the most active regional members of ESCAP and a leading technological and scientific force in the Asia Pacific Region. Over recent years Australia has formed coalitions of like‐minded member states to strengthen the activities of the Commission and has initiated a series of reforms which have made it more efficient and responsive to members' needs.

The Government believes that the resources devoted to ESCAP are appropriate at this time, given the progress of the reform agenda within the Commission. However, there may be greater scope for positively, but selectively, projecting Australia's capabilities via ESCAP. The Government will continue to consult other interested bodies to ensure that the resources devoted to ESCAP are appropriate in relation to demands of other regional bodies such as Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) mindful of the fact that some members of ESCAP are not represented within APEC.

The Government also funded extra‐budgetary projects valued at $400,000 in 1995 under the Australian aid program. ESCAP extra‐budgetary projects funded by Australia are in the priority sectors of environment, health, drug abuse, transport, poverty alleviation and statistics.

Two officers from the Bangkok Embassy fulfil the responsibilities of Australia's Permanent and Deputy Permanent Representatives to ESCAP as required. Through further consultation between the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Australian Agency for International Development and other interested bodies such as CSIRO, consideration will be given to exploring possibilities for future staff secondments, short term visits and joint workshops.

Other key areas of interest to Australia in which ESCAP has a considerable standing commitment include environmental monitoring, hazards amelioration and space technologies, including space science, communications and remote sensing. CSIRO is participating in a number of regional initiatives to establish effective and efficient network services for the provision and distribution of Earth observation satellite data. Space agencies in Thailand including ESCAP's Space Technologies Applications Section are working cooperatively with Australia, Japan, China, the Philippines and Indonesia to support the Global Research Network System. ESCAP has also contracted CSIRO scientists to assist with the development of ESCAP's Earth Space Information Network for Asia and the Pacific.

Australia will continue to press the ESCAP Secretariat to devote more resources to issues such as women in development, handicapped and Pacific island country issues and will use the review of the conference structure of the Commission scheduled for 1997 as a vehicle for achieving substantive reform of the Commission.

Data and information systems, including human, physical and electronic networks, could provide an attractive basis for enhanced cooperation between CSIRO and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in the promotion of Australian goods and services throughout the region.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Department of Industry, Science and Technology examine the 1987 Memorandum of Understanding with Thailand on Scientific and Technological Cooperation with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and relevant industry bodies to establish:

PARA.TAB: whether the scientific and technology assistance being given to Thailand is currently being managed in the most effective manner;
whether reactivation of the 1987 Memorandum of Understanding with Thailand would make the process more effective;
whether there should be an approach to the Government of Thailand about its views on reactivating the Memorandum of Understanding; and
whether consideration should be given to Market Australia taking over the provision of science and technology assistance to Thailand.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth's implementation of international arrangements for science and technology collaboration occurs on a pluralistic basis. Many Commonwealth agencies, departments, research institutions, educational institutions and other organisations advance science and technology activities with other countries where in their judgement there is benefit in doing so. The Department of Industry, Science and Tourism (DIST) coordinates activities where necessary and practicable. However, most of the assistance Australia gives to Thailand comes from the aid budget and is administered by AusAID under a 1989 Memorandum of Understanding on development cooperation between Australia and Thailand. Further, given Thai priorities, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research organisation (CSIRO) works primarily with Thailand through the Australian Council for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR).

The Australian Government made a major contribution to the ASEAN S&T Week held in Bangkok in 1995 and the then Australian Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry Science and Technology, accompanied by the then Chief Scientist, met their Thai counterparts and key officials. A number of bilateral collaborative activities were discussed. An arrangement was signed by the National Science and Technology Development Agency of Thailand (NSTDA) and the Australian Academy of Technological Science and Engineering in August 1995. This arrangement will encourage an exchange of visits by scientists and researchers. The head of NSTDA will lead a delegation from a number of universities and research institutions in Australia in 1996 and is being assisted in the organisation of this by the Academy which is itself supported by the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism (DIST).

DIST has only very modest funding to foster international scientific collaboration and even more limited staff resources. Faced with increasing constraints and competing priorities, DIST does not believe a more structured or elaborate approach to Thailand is warranted at this stage. Nor does it consider that there is a need to do more to activate the Memorandum of Understanding. There is a very real prospect that any further approaches to the Government of Thailand will raise expectations beyond those that can be delivered. However, some of the expectations could be met by educational institutions for training and research and development. Currently NSTDA has scholarships available for undergraduate and postgraduate students to study abroad.

Due to budgetary constraints, the Market Australia program, which participated in a number of activities in Thailand promoting awareness of Australian achievements in science and technology, has been abolished.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chapter 12: Transport, Infrastructure and Environmental Issues

That the Department of Industry, Science and Technology and AusAID examine the possibility of making greater use of Australian alternative and renewable technology in development assistance projects in Thailand.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth is committed to the establishment of a viable renewable energy industry in Australia. To this end the Renewable Energy Industry Program (REIP) was established to fund projects that contribute to the development of the renewable energy industry. Under the program, projects that develop the renewable energy market in countries such as Thailand may be supported.

Some work in the area of renewable energies is already being undertaken by Australia in Thailand. The West Australian based Centre for the Application of Solar Energy (CASE) has attracted funding from AusAID to install a solar power supply system in Thailand. Funding was provided through AusAID's Private Sector Linkages Scheme (PSLP) and this program and the Government Sector Linkages Program (GSLP) will continue to support Australian companies and Government agencies to seek modest funding support for demonstrating alternative and renewable technologies in appropriate circumstances.

PARA.TAB: adopt an integrated approach to health industry exports by encouraging cooperation between relevant departments;

through the Health Industry Development Forum, augmented by representation from Austrade, review the scope for the activities under the 1993 Memorandum of Understanding on Health Cooperation with Thailand; and
provide appropriate funding for the activities it might recommend.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government strongly supports an integrated approach to health industry exports through cooperation between relevant departments with respect to Thailand and other countries in the region.

In recent years there has been increasing growth in the interest and collaboration of Commonwealth Government agencies in the facilitation of health exports. At the Commonwealth level there are health units in Austrade, the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism (DIST), AusAID and the Department of Health and Family Services (HFS) which work closely together. There is also growing collaboration between State health agencies on health export development, and export promotion is being further pursued through the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council.

Since its establishment eighteen months ago, the Australian Health Industry Development Forum (AHIDF) has played an important role in supporting Austrade, the Department of Health and Family Services and the private sector to network and develop a national strategy from the bottom up. DIST, HFS and Austrade have ex officio membership of the Forum's Executive Committee.

Australian Health Ministers have entered into Memoranda of Understanding (MOU) on health cooperation with their counterparts in Indonesia, Thailand and China. The development of a detailed plan of action under the MOU with Thailand was foreshadowed in bilateral discussions at senior officials level in 1995 and the Government anticipates that formal discussions will commence following conclusion of the Indonesian Plan of Action. Already a number of specific initiatives have occurred which fit within the broad framework of the MOU.

Health has been a major area of activity in Australia's aid program to Thailand over the last 5 years, particularly in the HIV/AIDS field. It has involved a wide range of engagements with Australian and Thai NGOs, the private sector and arms of the Royal Thai Government. Health, particularly HIV/AIDS, is one of the four sectors on which the Australian aid program to Thailand will focus over the next 4 years. AusAID's APEC support program has also provided funding to strengthen cooperation and training programs between the Department of Health and Family Services' Therapeutic Goods Administration and the Thai Ministry of Health's Food and Drug Administration.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Department of Human Services and Health, with AusAID, review their working arrangements on international health activities:

PARA.TAB: to ensure a more integrated approach is adopted in their joint activities in this field;
to examine the extension of existing collaborative health arrangements in conjunction with assistance provided by other countries; and
to gauge the effectiveness of Australian development assistance for health programs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government recognises the need for AusAID and the Department of Health and Family Services to coordinate their international health activities, with respect to Thailand and other countries of the region.

A joint AusAID and Department of Health and Family Services (DHFS) response to the 1993 House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs report on Australia's International Health Programs was tabled on 30 November 1995. This response positively addressed various recommendations by the Committee aimed at improving consultation and collaboration between AusAID and Health and Family Services.

AusAID, in consultation with the DHFS, has reviewed the role and functions of the Advisory Group on International Health, and as a consequence revised its terms of reference to reflect the broad strategic priorities for health policy. Membership of the committee was expanded to include representation from institutions and peak bodies in the health sector, including the Executive of the Australian Health Industry Development Forum. Discussions have taken place on how DHFS can utilise AusAID funding programs, such as the APEC Support Program which supports relevant initiatives of Australian government departments, to advance the objectives of its bilateral MOUs.

Liaison between DHFS and AusAID's Indonesia Section in relation to the Department's identification of cooperative activities to be carried out under its Indonesia MOU serves as a model for prospective work under the MOU with Thailand. The primary health care focus of AusAID's health assistance programs and DHFS's interest in the development of commercial links across the whole of the health sector leads to some divergence in the two agencies' priorities for international health cooperation. But their efforts are nonetheless complementary, and coincide in some important areas flagged by the Committee's report such as health promotion and health policy reform.

DHFS staff provide technical guidance to AusAID on a variety of international health issues and have taken part in health project identification missions and consultant selection. Cooperation has been most extensive in the area of HIV/AIDS assistance, where it has covered staff secondments between the agencies, collaboration in project design and appraisal and formulation of international assistance policy guidelines. There is continuing close liaison in formulating Australia's policy position on the development of the UN Joint and Co‐sponsored Program on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS), as well as on other multilateral health issues. A planned review of AusAID's overall HIV/AIDS assistance programs will be conducted in consultation with DHFS.

DHFS has already participated in evaluations of the effectiveness of AusAID's health aid programs, and most recently took part in the OECD Development Assistance Committee evaluation of Australia's aid program.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That, in considering specific development assistance projects in health, AusAID consult the Government of Thailand about giving greater support to community‐based programs in preventative health for rural areas, poverty alleviation in rural and urban centres, women's health issues, anti‐trafficking campaigns relating to women and children and educational programs to combat the interconnection between prostitution, substance abuse and HIV/AIDS.

SPEECH.PARA: As noted in the response to Recommendation 7, the health sector will be given priority during the transition phase of AusAID's development cooperation program.

Australia has provided support for community based programs in poverty alleviation and HIV/AIDS prevention and care in Thailand through AusAID since 1992‐93. The Thai‐Australian Community Assistance Program (TACAP) provides grant assistance and project support for community based development projects aimed at raising the living standards of the poorer sections of Thai society, particularly rural areas and to assist and strengthen the role and capacity of local NGOs in the development process.

The Northern Thai‐Australian HIV/AIDS Prevention and Care Program (NAPAC) has provided grant assistance to community based organisations and indigenous NGOs in three northern Thai provinces for activities such as preventative education, counselling, community and family based care, research and social development activities. NAPAC has been a highly effective mechanism to engage a broad cross section of the Thai community in the task of combating the HIV/AIDS pandemic.
In addition to these programs, AusAID's South East Asia Regional Program provides funding to Thailand in the following three categories:

PARA.TAB: Health Initiative—Community based developments focusing on women and children's health, specifically a pilot immunisation program and assistance to integrate Hepatitis B vaccine into the national expanded program of immunisation;

HIV/AIDS Initiative—community based approach involving Australian NGOs in partnership with Thai NGOs targeting high risk groups such as intravenous drug users, prostitutes, youth and health workers and carers of HIV positive people.
Population Initiative—supports family planning and women's and children's health activities in the southern provinces of Thailand.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government is considering the potential for education programs which are aimed at severing the relationship between prostitution, substance abuse and HIV/AIDS. The scope for such activities will be assessed in the context of Federal Budget outcomes.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Department of Human Services and Health and AusAID examine the possibility of greater input from Australian non‐government organisations to collaborative activities with Thailand on health promotion, preventative health measures and in‐country training of Thai health industry personnel.

SPEECH.PARA: Collaborative activities between Australian NGOs and Thailand in the health sector have primarily been supported through AusAID's South East Asia Regional Program (see response to recommendation 32.)

Australian NGOs have not been particularly active in Thailand and their counterpart relations have not been developed in any significant way. AusAID's development cooperation program in Thailand has, therefore, focused on increasing the indigenous capacity of NGOs in Thailand, which has occurred through the TACAP and NAPAC programs (see response to recommendation 32). The decision to support local NGO's was based on issues of cost effectiveness and a desire to increase indigenous capacity in the context of Thailand's eventual graduation from being a recipient of grant aid flows.

The need to increase the capacity of Thai health personnel is being addressed through the development of an AusAID funded program on HIV/AIDS involving collaboration between the NSW Department of Health (Albion Street Centre) and the Thai Ministry of Public Health, with the goal of establishing a regional training centre for the treatment and care of HIV/AIDS sufferers, their carers and their families. A major component of the project will be the training of Thai health personnel to provide a full range of ambulatory care services and the institutional strengthening of the Bamrasnaradura Hospital in Bangkok with the aim of using the hospital as a regional training facility for the treatment and care of HIV/AIDS sufferers and their carers.Recommendation 34:

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Australian Government exert pressure on the World Health Organisation:

PARA.TAB: to realign its regional boundaries so that Australia and its neighbours in South East Asia, such as Thailand, Laos, Cambodia and Indonesia are included in the same zone; and
in conjunction with the United Nations High Commission for refugees, to develop and implement programs directed towards alleviation of the health problems of:
Thailand's nationals and refugees within its borders; and
its immediate neighbours Burma, Laos and Cambodia.

SPEECH.PARA: The WHO has two regional groupings that incorporate countries in the Asia‐Pacific region. Australia is a member of the Western Pacific Region along with some 32 others including Cambodia and Laos, while Thailand and Indonesia are members of the neighbouring South East Asian Region with eight others. The regional structure of the WHO is governed by Article 44 of the Constitution of WHO, which states that
(a) The Health Assembly shall from time to time define the topographic areas in which it is desirable to establish a regional organisation.

(b) The Health Assembly may, with the consent of a majority of Members situated within each area so defined, establish a regional organisation to meet the special needs of such an area. There shall not be more than one regional organisation in each area.

All countries are assigned to a region. Where a country wishes to transfer from one region to another, as occurred in 1995 when Mongolia transferred from the South East Asian Region to the Western Pacific Region, the transfer is authorised by a vote of the World Health Assembly. This is the principal governing body of WHO made up of all member states.

There is currently a review underway of the Constitution of the WHO including the issue of membership and composition of the WHO regions. A report on progress of the review will be presented to the World Health Assembly in May 1997.

In the past, it has proven difficult to alter the established regional groupings, given the interests at stake, particularly in terms of representation on the Executive Board and other representational entitlements which are allocated to the regional groupings. Any redistribution of regional boundaries would need to be undertaken on a global basis in the context of the wider review of the WHO.

The Australian Government will continue to support changes to the WHO which increase its efficiency and effectiveness in program delivery, enabling the WHO to maintain its position as the preeminent body in international health in the 21st century.
The Government will also continue to work in conjunction with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, to develop and implement appropriate health improvement programs for the region.
On 20 March 1996, the Foreign Minister Mr Downer announced that AusAID would provide a further $A1 million package of assistance to Burmese refugees living on the borders of Thailand and Burma :

PARA.TAB: In Thailand, the National Council of Churches will receive $A844,000 to support the Burma Border Consortium (BBC) which coordinates relief supplies to the refugee camps. A further $A156,000 will go to Austcare to support medical programs provided by Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF);

The provision of medical assistance to refugees in camps along the Thai‐Burma border is currently being met by the non government organisation, Medicins Sans Frontieres (MSF). Australia has been a generous donor to MSF over the past five years and intends to continue providing assistance so long as the needs remain. The Thai government has currently not given UNHCR permission to operate in these camps.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chapter 14: Human Rights, Legal and Law Enforcement Issues
That, at the meetings of the Asian Attorneys‐General forum, the Australian Government encourage common regional standards for the quality of justice and legal processes.

SPEECH.PARA: At the Commonwealth Law Ministers meeting in Kuala Lumpar, held from 15‐19 April 1996, Australia put forward a proposal aimed at enhancing the independence of the judiciary in Commonwealth countries. Ministers, having unanimously endorsed the proposal, appointed a working group of senior officials from representative regional countries to progress a study on independence of the judiciary.

A comparative study of Commonwealth countries will be undertaken to identify matters fundamentally affecting the reality of judicial independence and the actual and perceived status of the judiciary. It is hoped that the study will point to best practices and thereby assist member countries which seek to advance and accelerate the development of their own judiciaries beyond their present state of development.

Naturally a fundamental basis of the study will be that each country should be free to structure its judiciary as it sees fit and that there does not need to be uniformity on matters affecting the status and independence of the judiciary.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade encourage Thailand to formulate a national action plan on human rights, with a view to signing and ratifying such important human rights documents as the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights as a matter of priority.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government supports the desirability of maintaining close contact with the Thai Government regarding formulation of a national action plan on human rights and Thailand's ratification of key UN human rights instruments, including the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (ICESCR).

At the 1993 World Conference on Human Rights, Australia put forward an initiative calling on states to prepare "National Action Plans" as a means by which they could, in a practical way, improve their observance of human rights standards. The proposal was endorsed by the World Conference and is now one of the recommendations contained in the Vienna Declaration. It invites states to draw up a written plan of action identifying steps it could take to improve its observance of human rights in accordance with international obligations. It was envisaged that such National Action Plans could, among other things, form the basis of proposals under UN programs of technical assistance in the field of human rights. Australia prepared its own national action plan in 1994 and national action plans are currently being prepared in both the Philippines and Brazil.

National action plans are increasingly being recognised as a valuable tool to promote domestic adherence to international human rights principles and standards. At the 1996 session of the UN Commission on Human Rights, National Action Plans were referred to in both UN High Commissioner for Human Rights' report on World Conference follow‐up and in the report of the UN Secretary‐General on Advisory Services in the Field of Human Rights. At a UN Workshop on Regional Human Rights Arrangements in the Asia‐Pacific region in February 1996 attended by over 30 countries (including Australia and Thailand), national action plans on human rights were identified as an issue on which countries of the region should cooperate further to promote regional human rights observance.

Australia has actively promoted the concept of national action plans internationally and played an active part in ensuring that these plans were given prominence at the UN Workshop on Regional Human Rights Arrangements in Asia‐Pacific. We will continue to encourage all countries, including Thailand, to formulate national action plans on human rights. Where possible, Australia would be willing to use its knowledge and experience to assist in the preparation of plans.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Australian Government encourages Thailand to establish the National Commission on Human Rights and an Ombudsmen Office.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government gives a high priority to encouraging the establishment and strengthening of national human rights institutions in countries in the region including Thailand. National institutions provide a practical and constructive means to translate international human rights obligations into domestic practice. Moreover general improvements in human rights are inextricably linked to advances in specific areas, including the elimination of trafficking of women and girls. Through the Australian Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) and the Australian Embassy in Bangkok, Australia has provided advice and assistance on the possible establishment of a national human rights institution in Thailand and will continue to do so, where possible, as requested. Thailand was one of the key countries invited to attend the First Asia‐Pacific Workshop of National Institutions hosted by HREOC in Darwin in July 1996 with the aim of promoting cooperation among and the strengthening of national human rights institutions in the Asia Pacific region. Australia has also contributed $300,000 to the UN Voluntary Fund for Technical Cooperation for the purpose of strengthening the domestic infrastructures which support human rights and, in particular, national human rights machinery in Asia‐Pacific countries.

The Thai Parliament considered the establishment of an Ombudsman's Office in the context of constitutional reforms in 1994/95. The Commonwealth Ombudsman would be happy to advise the Thai Government regarding the establishment of an Ombudsman's Office if requested to do so.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That relevant authorities be encouraged, as a matter of priority, to enact appropriate Commonwealth and State legislation for the introduction and administration of a prisoner exchange scheme between Australia and Thailand.

SPEECH.PARA: Substantial work has been done over recent years in developing legislation which will allow Australians serving prison sentences overseas, and foreign citizens imprisoned in Australia, to be returned to their home countries to complete the serving of their sentences.

This work is being carried out through the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General (SCAG). SCAG has decided that legislation should be developed to enable prisoners to be transferred between Australia and other countries, and a considerable amount of work has been done on the legislative and administrative framework for the scheme.

Both Commonwealth and State/Territory legislation is required to be enacted. The legislation is being drafted by the Parliamentary Counsel's Committee at the direction of SCAG. It is anticipated that both the Commonwealth Bill and the model State/Territory legislation will be ready for SCAG endorsement in the near future. Following SCAG endorsement, the legislation will be introduced as soon as possible in the respective legislatures.

Australia and Thailand undertook negotiations towards a prisoner transfer agreement in Bangkok in April 1996. The negotiations were based on a Thai draft prisoner transfer agreement which had been examined by the Australian Government and found to be generally satisfactory.
The proposed Commonwealth and State/Territory legislation will constitute the legal basis, in Australia, for administering prisoner transfers under the Australia‐Thailand Prisoner Transfer Agreement.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That in its development assistance program, AusAID target projects which are directed towards improving human rights in Thailand.

SPEECH.PARA: Where appropriate, AusAID projects address human rights issues in Thailand. A number of programs which work through local NGOs and other organisations are directly aimed at improving specific areas of human rights concerns within Thailand. Commonly encountered issues being addressed under these programs include alternatives to prostitution and child abuse, mother and child health, assistance to Burmese exiles in Thailand, and women's issues. As noted under recommendation 14, a range of Australian aid activities in Thailand make a contribution to the reduction of the traffick ing in women and children. The Australian Government will continue to examine further options in this area (see also recommendation 37).

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Department of Defence enhance human rights training in Australian Defence Force courses.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1995 a review of Human Rights Training in the Australian Defence Force (ADF) was undertaken. The review examined all human rights training provided to members of the ADF and examined its appropriateness. The report concluded that human rights training occurs from point of entry, throughout members' careers and prior to overseas deployment, and did not consider that further training needed to be developed. Foreign students receive the same instruction on human rights matters as their ADF counterparts undertaking the same course.

On a tri‐Service basis, specific training in the Law of Armed Conflict (LOAC) for commanders and operational planners is provided by a specialist course at the ADF Warfare Centre (ADFWC). The ADFWC also includes LOAC instruction in other courses it conducts, including the Joint Warfare Seminar and the Peacekeeping Seminar, both of which are regularly attended by officers of the Royal Thai Armed Forces. At the Australian Defence Force Academy, to which Thailand sends 2—4 cadet officers each year, military law training includes training in essential provisions of the LOAC, and comprises 24 periods over a 3 year course. Passing the exam is a graduation requirement. The year‐long course of the Australian College for Defence and Strategic Studies (ACDSS) encompasses training in relevant areas of international humanitarian law. The Joint Services Staff College (JSSC) syllabus covers international law, including the Hague and Geneva Conventions and rules of engagement. International legal aspects are also covered regarding their impact on the formulation of national security and defence policies. Thai officers regularly attend both the ACDSS and JSSC courses.

Navy includes relevant LOAC training in courses conducted at all major Royal Australian Navy (RAN) training establishments. Specialised training is also provided at the RAN Surface Warfare School and the Navigation School. Regular LOAC instruction is given by naval legal officers to a variety of through‐career training courses such as the RAN Staff College course, which is regularly attended by Royal Thai Navy officers. All RAN Commanding Officers and Executive Officers undertake LOAC refresher training before assuming command.

Army conducts an annual Operations Law seminar under the auspices of Land Headquarters. This seminar deals with LOAC issues and is attended by legal officers and those ADF members involved in the planning and conduct of operations. LOAC and Operations Law is also provided in a variety of through‐career courses such as the Army Command and Staff College. These courses are regularly attended by Royal Thai Army officers. Local level training also covers matters such as forbidden targets, rules of engagement and orders for opening fire, prisoners of war and detainees, the rights of civilians and their property, and the reporting and prosecution of unlawful acts under the LOAC. An Operations Law Manual for commanders is currently being written by HQ Training Command. This includes chapters on LOAC and Human Rights.

Air Force provides LOAC training specifically targeted to aircrew and operational support members of the four force element groups (strike/reconnaissance, tactical fighter, air lift and maritime patrol). This training focuses on legal aspects likely to be raised by particular operations undertaken by those groups. Air Force also conducts an annual Operations Law Introductory Course, in which legal officers and other relevant personnel such as aircrew and intelligence officers, receive specialist training in relevant LOAC principles. LOAC and Operations Law is taught in a one day seminar at the RAAF Command and Staff College. This is regularly attended by Royal Thai Air Force Officers.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Attorney‐General's Department pursue the negotiations to finalise the Memorandum of Understanding with Thailand on the protection of intellectual property and, with the Department of Industry, Science and Technology, ensure that any assistance Thailand requests in the protection of copyright and intellectual/industrial property is provided.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney‐General's Department, the Australian Industrial Property Organisation within the Department of Industry Science and Tourism and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade are actively seeking finalisation of the Memorandum of Understanding. Each agency is seeking to encourage and to meet requests for assistance from Thailand with the help of AusAID through the APEC support initiative subject to funding availability.

A number of Thai judges undertook a study tour of Australia in March 1996 specifically to examine Australia's intellectual property regime. The judges held discussions with a wide range of contacts including the Federal Court, the Australian Industrial Property Organisation, the Attorney‐General's Department and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.
Australia is working with Thailand and other APEC member economies through the IP Get Together to pursue an action agenda that focuses on collaboration to develop more effective IP systems.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Attorney‐General's Department respond positively to requests for legal knowledge
or technology it might receive from Thailand, and encourage contributions from legal bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: The International Legal Services Advisory Council's (ILSAC) second three year term concluded on 30 June 1996. The Council was first established in 1990 by the then Attorney‐General for a three year period. In 1993, the Council was re‐established for a further three year period which concluded on 30 June 1996.
