The Government's support for the establishment of a new national body for teachers, the National Forum of Teacher Professional Associations, will give teachers, including arts educators, a strong voice in taking these issues forward. This addresses Recommendations 2 and 3.

. The Department of Communications and the Arts, in cooperation with the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, will convene a consultative forum to bring together key stakeholders in arts education to consider matters of mutual interest. The Department of Communications and the Arts will prepare an initial issues paper for consideration at the forum. The Departments will consult with the Ministerial Councils on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs and the Cultural Ministers Council to have the forum and its activities recognised. This addresses Recommendation 4.

. The Commonwealth will refer, for consideration, to the Schools Taskforce of the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs, the Committee's recommendation that the annual National Report on Schooling should report on inputs (enrolments, lesson time, teachers employed) to school education, broken down into learning areas. The Schools Taskforce is responsible for the development of an Agreed Information Framework that determines the coverage of the annual National Report on Schooling. This supports Recommendation 7.

. The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training will refer the Committee's recommendations about the influence of university entrance arrangements on school curriculum to establish whether they are having any detrimental effect on humanities and arts and matters relating to further curriculum initiatives to the State and Territory Ministers for Education. This addresses Recommendations 1 and 10.

. The Government is providing funds for the national schools forum on profiles and educational outcomes, held in New South Wales in 1996. Through this forum the on‐going monitoring of outcomes deriving from the curriculum profiles will be considered. This addresses Recommendation 11.

. The Government will ask the Australian Research Council to investigate whether current research funding arrangements may discriminate against particular disciplines. The Government will also bring concerns of arts education faculties about funding to the attention of the committee which is undertaking the review of higher education financing and policy in 1997. This addresses Recommendation 23.

. The Government will refer to the Working Group, comprising the Australian Vice‐Chancellor's Committee, the Australian Research Council, the Higher Education Council and DEETYA the issue of whether the current definition of research for the purpose of determining competitive research funding allocation is appropriate. This addresses Recommendation 24.

. The Government will refer to the Australian Vice‐Chancellors' Committee for its consideration, the Committee's concerns about a possible bias in research funding arrangements against particular disciplines. This addresses Recommendation 25.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
Madam President, this bill provides a framework for Australia to participate in the international transfer of prisoners.
The purpose of the bill is to enable Australians imprisoned overseas, and foreign nationals imprisoned in Australia, to be returned to their home countries to complete the serving of their sentences.
Increases in international air travel and criminal activity have resulted in a rise in the number of persons serving terms of imprisonment in foreign countries.
Participation in international prisoner transfers is important for Australia for both domestic and international reasons.
There are sound humanitarian and rehabilitative grounds for international prisoner transfers.
In addition, such transfers may result in practical benefits in terms of prison administration, as well as relieving some of the pressure on the consular services of Australian missions overseas.

It is possible that Australian participation in international prisoner transfers may also result in financial savings for some participating States and Territories if there is a net outflow of prisoners.
From the international perspective, a large number of countries are very supportive of prisoner transfer schemes.
In recent years, there has been growing pressure for Australia to participate, and Australia has been approached by various countries about this matter.
Accordingly, participation in prisoner transfers will enhance and supplement Australia's relations with other countries.

Madam President, apart from providing a framework for general transfer of prisoners, the bill will also enable persons who have been convicted by certain international war crimes tribunals to be transferred to Australia to serve their sentences.

As honourable senators will be aware, two international war crimes tribunals were established in 1993 and 1994 by the United Nations Security Council to deal with war crimes committed in the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda.

The International War Crimes Tribunals Act 1995 enables Australia to assist and comply with requests from the Tribunals, including the arrest and surrender of accused persons to the Tribunals and other assistance such as the taking of evidence in Australia for Tribunal purposes.

Persons convicted by the Tribunals are to serve their sentences in countries designated by the Tribunals from a list of countries which have indicated to the Security Council their willingness to accept such prisoners.
A number of countries have already agreed to accept Tribunal prisoners, and the President of the former Yugoslavia Tribunal has sought advice as to Australia's willingness to do so.
Australia's acceptance of Tribunal prisoners will be subject to the qualification that the prisoners have a connection with Australia.
The provisions in the bill enabling transfers from the Tribunals will complement the International War Crimes Tribunals Act 1995.
Madam President, clearly there has been a need to consult closely with the States and Territories in the development of this bill.
These consultations have taken place through the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.
As there are no federal prisons, incoming prisoners will need to be housed by prisons controlled by those States and Territories which are going to participate in the transfer scheme.
Many of the prisoners who will seek to take advantage of the proposed scheme to leave Australia will be serving sentences for State or Territory offences.
The participating States and Territories will need to enact complementary legislation.
Accordingly, the successful participation of Australia in international prisoner transfers will depend to a large measure on cooperation with the State and Territory authorities.
The States and Territories are generally supportive of the scheme.
At a Standing Committee of Attorneys-General meeting in October 1996, the participating States and Territories endorsed draft Commonwealth and model State/Territory legislation.
As to the detailed content of the bill, it contains separate provisions for the two different types of prisoners.
Parts 3 and 4 deal with general prisoner transfers between Australia and other countries.
Part 5 deals with transfers to Australia of Tribunal prisoners.
Parts 1, 2, 6 and 7 contain general provisions relating to both types of prisoners.
The bill provides for all transfers to be considered on a case-by-case basis.
Madam President, I now mention some of the important features of the provisions dealing with general prisoner transfers between Australia and other countries.
The bill is drafted in such a way that the transfer scheme is able to apply to all offences without exception.

It covers persons who have been convicted of a crime and sentenced to imprisonment or other deprivation of liberty, and includes persons confined in connection with criminal conduct by reason of mental disorder, and persons who have been released on parole.

A significant requirement is that all transfers must be consensual, requiring the consent of the person to be transferred, the Australian Government (Commonwealth and State/Territory where relevant) and the Government of the other country.
The bill contains certain prerequisites which must be satisfied before transfers can take place.
These include:
imprisonment under a final order, whereby neither the sentence of imprisonment nor the relevant conviction is subject to appeal;

for transfers to Australia, the person is an Australian citizen or is permitted to travel to, enter and remain in Australia indefinitely pursuant to the Migration Act 1958 and has community ties with a State or Territory;

dual criminality, whereby the acts or omissions constituting the relevant offence would, if the acts or omissions had occurred in Australia or the other country as appropriate, have constituted an offence in that country; and
at least six months of the sentence is remaining to be served.
In relation to these last two conditions, the Attorney-General has been given a discretion to waive these requirements in appropriate cases.
Madam President, I now turn to the provisions dealing with transfers of prisoners from the international war crimes tribunals.
There are some differences from the general prisoner transfer scheme.
These differences take account of the different nature and objectives of the transfer of Tribunal prisoners.
The intention is that a Tribunal prisoner would not be transferred to Australia unless he or she has some connection with Australia and the Australian Government has consented to the transfer.
The main differences in relation to Tribunal prisoners are that consent from the Tribunal prisoner is not a mandatory requirement, and there are no explicit citizenship or migration requirements.

On this point, I wish to draw to honourable senators' attention that the bill provides that no decision affecting a person who is not an Australian citizen can be made unless the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs consents.
A central issue in international prisoner transfers is the question as to how sentences imposed in other countries or the Tribunals will be enforced in Australia following transfer.
Part 6 of the bill addresses this matter.

The bill sets out two different methods for enforcement in Australia of a sentence of imprisonment imposed on a prisoner or Tribunal prisoner by a court or tribunal of a transfer country or by a Tribunal.
These methods are consistent with those set out in the Council of Europe Convention on the Transfer of Sentenced Persons (Council of Europe Convention).
The bill provides that the Attorney-General may direct that the sentence of imprisonment be enforced on the transfer of the prisoner to Australia under the act:
without any adaptation or with only such adaptation as is considered necessary to ensure consistency with Australian law—this is referred to as the continued enforcement method; or
by substituting a different sentence—this is referred to as the converted enforcement method.

While the bill provides for a choice between two different forms of sentence enforcement, the method actually adopted in a particular case will depend on the agreement with the country or the Tribunal.
For example, if a bilateral treaty with a particular country provides for only one method of sentence enforcement, that method would be used in relation to transfers from that country.
Subject to any agreement to the contrary, I would envisage that Australia would generally use the continued enforcement method.

This would involve being bound, so far as possible, by the legal nature and duration of the sentence as determined by the other country, such that a prisoner would bring with him, or her, the sentence from the sending country, minus any time served or remissions earned in the sending country, up to the date of the transfer.

The bill contains a discretion for the Attorney-General to make any necessary adaptations to the sentence, although this is subject to the limitation that the sentence to be enforced under either method much not be harsher than the sentence originally imposed.
From the date of transfer, the sentence would be generally subject to Australia's law concerning the enforcement of sentences.
The approach adopted in the bill is to treat all incoming prisoners as federal prisoners for administrative convenience and sentence enforcement purposes.
It is important to remember that this is not intended to affect the agreed financial obligations as between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories.

The agreement reached in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General is that the States and Territories will pay the cost of maintaining incoming prisoners in prison (unless the prisoners have community ties with Territories for which the Commonwealth is responsible).

PARA.EMPHASIS: Application of the legislation and treaty negotiation

SPEECH.PARA: Madam President, this legislation alone will not be sufficient to enable prisoners to be transferred to and from Australia.
As I have already mentioned, complementary legislation will need to be enacted by the participating States and Territories.

In addition, a number of administrative steps will need to be taken—for example, the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General has agreed that it may be appropriate to have arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories, defining the relationship between, and the responsibilities of, the Commonwealth and the States and Territories in administering the scheme.
The bill contains a provision enabling such arrangements to be made.
A further requirement is for transfer arrangements to be entered into with other countries.
The basis of the bill is that prisoners (other than Tribunal prisoners) can only be transferred between Australia and `transfer countries'.
The bill contains a mechanism by which the act is to be applied to transfer countries.
This involves the making of regulations, which may be based on treaty or non-treaty arrangements with other countries.
A number of countries have already concluded bilateral prisoner transfer treaties.

I am advised that some 27 countries are parties to the Council of Europe Convention, and that there are also 6 countries participating in the Commonwealth Scheme for the Transfer of Convicted Offenders (the Commonwealth Scheme).

Due to cost-effectiveness and scope, it is intended that Australia seek to become party to and implement existing multilateral arrangements such as the Council of Europe Convention and the Commonwealth Scheme, and that bilateral treaties be negotiated only with countries who are not parties to a multilateral arrangement to which Australia becomes party, and/or whose preference is for a bilateral treaty or arrangement.
The bill is expected to have little impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue in the short term.
Expenses in relation to transfers to Australia will generally be borne by the participating States and Territories.
In addition, the bill contains a clause enabling the recovery of the costs and expenses incurred in transferring prisoners.

Under the agreement reached in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, the Commonwealth's costs in relation to general prisoner transfers will include costs of negotiating participation in any appropriate multilateral schemes, bilateral treaties or other transfer arrangements, and the administration of receiving and making requests to other countries.

The costs for the States and Territories will include sending escort officers, returning prisoners (including airfares) and the cost of maintaining prisoners during the terms of sentences in Australia.
The cost arrangements will be different in relation to transfers of Tribunal prisoners, since that responsibility arises from international relations and Australia's membership of the United Nations.
The Commonwealth will be responsible for the costs associated with transfers from the Tribunals.
The cost implications are however not expected to be significant in relation to Tribunal prisoners.
In relation to general prisoner transfers, there may be significant cost savings to the States and Territories if there is a net outflow of prisoners.

It is difficult to predict the number of prisoners likely to be moved in and out of Australia once the scheme is operating, and of course, any financial savings will depend upon the actual number of transfers.
The cost implications are therefore unable to be precisely quantified at this stage, but will be examined as part of the agreed evaluation strategy.

This will entail a review of the legislation after the scheme has been in place for a period of 12 months to determine the extent to which it has been utilised and to assess the resource implications.

The bill was referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. After extensive consideration, the Committee indicated strong support for the bill, and made seven recommendations for change. Most of the Committee's recommendations involved undertakings of an administrative nature, and only one recommendation involved an amendment. I am pleased to advise that the Government accepted all recommendations and amended the bill in the House of Representatives.
The bill is based on strong humanitarian and social considerations, and is the outcome of a cooperative, lengthy and detailed consultation process with the States and Territories.
I believe the bill will bring significant advantages at both the domestic and international levels.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chris Evans) adjourned.

TITLE.XREF: NATURAL HERITAGE TRUST OF AUSTRALIA BILL 1996

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill 1996 and amendment No. 2. on revised amendment sheet 181 moved by the Australian Democrats to clause 11.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refresh people's memory on what this particular amendment is about. It involves a reworking and a rewording of the Murray-Darling objective. It replaces what is a rather vague parenthood statement by the government, one which I believe bureaucrats will probably spend three to five years trying to define and fighting over, such as we saw in the national forest policy statement where similar words were used—comprehensive, adequate and representative. They took several years to define, and we do not want that to happen again. Therefore, we are looking at redefining the statement to make it a lot clearer. We believe our reworked objective makes it a stronger statement, and it is more workable for all concerned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Apart from last night when we were last debating this bill, I am not sure whether I put on the record the government's objection to this amendment. The explanation for our objection is that we believe the proposed new definition is too specific. We think it would cause problems with interpretation, and it would restrict the types of projects able to be under the initiative. The way we interpret it, unless a project can be demonstrated that it meets all four objectives, legally it would not be able to be funded, which would be against our wishes. On the basis that there is much within Senator Lees's package of amendments that, upon reflection, we have decided we can support, this one we cannot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Democrats' amendment for the very reason that the Minister for the Environ ment (Senator Hill) discounted it: that is, it is specific. The minister says that it is too specific. As Senator Lees says, what it does is try to give direction in the spending of very limited funds on the restoration of the Murray-Darling Basin and specifically to the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: We know from the debate last night that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) wrote to the minister earlier this year indicating a concern that jobs creation be taken into account. Nobody is going to dispute that jobs are important, but many of us on this side of the house believe that if you are engaged in environmental excellence you will produce excellent jobs at the same time. That goes without saying.

The direction of this legislation and government policy has been towards environmental excellence. Senator Lees tries to tie that down with her amendment, and the minister says `I won't have it.' One can only see his consistency in that, because he is not good at having anything that ties him down to carrying out his environmental obligations.

That said, the other point that has to be made here is that this is not a cornucopia. This is not going to fix up Australia's environment. This Telstra money is going to go a little way towards repairing some of the past damage. It is not going to do anything towards repairing the damage that is being created at the moment by the actions of this Minister for the Environment or his government. But it ought to be at least concentrated on getting maximum benefits for the environment and, in this case, specifically for the Murray-Darling Basin. Therefore, the parameters that Senator Lees points to ought to be endorsed by the committee and by the Senate.

There is not enough money in this whole fund to do just for the Murray-Darling Basin the specifics that Senator Lees has outlined: restoring the flow and habitat requirements of the freshwater ecosystems, enhancing efficiency and sustainability in irrigated agriculture and water storage and delivery systems, improving water quality and protecting and restoring river frontage vegetation. If the billion dollars or so over the next five years could achieve just those four aims that Sena tor Lees has put before the committee, I for one would be very satisfied. But it is not going to. The job is much bigger than that. The money is far too limited. But at least we have got here an amendment which is going to try to keep this minister and this government focused on the environment. Therefore, it ought to be endorsed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —To follow through one of the issues that Senator Brown raised in his brief contribution, he recalled that last night—I think in answer to a question that I had raised in the chamber—the minister indicated that the Prime Minister had written to him some months ago regarding the need for the Natural Heritage Trust to maximise employment opportunities. I was wondering whether the minister would be able to table that correspondence from the Prime Minister so that senators who are participating in the debate would have a better understanding of the additional obligations that I understand the Prime Minister is placing on the trust fund itself.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is within the cabinet context and, of course, it is a letter written to me. I will ask the Prime Minister whether he has any objection to me producing it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Hill for that; obviously, it would be appreciated if that could be done expeditiously. What I am grappling with, and what I expect those participating in the debate are grappling with, is the issue of what extra obligations have been placed on the board of the Natural Heritage Trust in terms of its administration as a result of the Prime Minister's communication. That is the issue that I am interested in—the extra obligations that are placed upon you and Minister Anderson as a result of the Prime Minister's directive. I would appreciate the letter; it would be helpful if that could be tabled. Perhaps you could benefit the Senate with advice on that issue that I have just raised.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I said last night that I do not see any extra obligations as such under the legislation. The final responsibility rests with Minister Anderson and me. I said that the Prime Minister, through the employment committee of cabinet, is looking at the range, as I understand it, of major government programs to ensure that, consistent with the primary objectives of those programs, we are also maximising employment opportunities. I said last night that I think that is a very sensible approach and it is one that I endorse. But ultimately the responsibility will fall to Minister Anderson and me.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask you, minister, how the government or you can guarantee that the trust fund actually will remain an environment fund. I would be interested in receiving your guarantee on that issue so that we can be satisfied that the fund will not in any way be skewed away from environmental objectives, which I think is also of concern to other senators who have participated in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a range of accountability provisions in the bill, which no doubt we will get to later in this committee stage, dealing with the annual reports. As I recall it, there are some additional amendments to strengthen those further accountability provisions so that the public will be able to make that judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: Contrary to what Senator Brown said last night, we have in mind a range of guidance mechanisms in relation to developing the spending programs. As has been already published, we are working through regional assessment committees and state assessment committees. Each will be supported by specialists in the various aspects of the environment, largely out of the state bureaucracies but sometimes from elsewhere.

We are assisted by a number of other existing committees, such as the biological diversity committee and the national landcare committee. We are in the process of setting up our sustainable vegetation committee. So the input to keep us on track will be there, Senator, in the development of the programs. At the other end of the programs, as I said, within the bill there are quite considerable accountability mechanisms to assure the public that the money has been spent in accordance with our obligations.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue goes to this because during the last election campaign the coalition, then in opposition, made a commitment to establish the trust fund. It also made a commitment that that trust fund would in fact represent further expenditure of $1.25 billion on the environment.
—It was then $1.15 billion.

—Well, an extra $1.15 billion on the environment. What I am interested in hearing is your assurance that that remains an extra amount of money, which now stands at $1.25 billion, towards environment programs.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a different question and I think it probably goes well beyond the scope of this committee debate. Nevertheless, what Senator Faulkner says is correct. It was our objective that the $1.149 billion that we promised would be in addition to the published forecasts. That remains our objective. Of course, it has been moderated slightly by the contribution we have had to make towards redressing the $10 billion deficit we inherited. That has been the subject of questions and answers in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As we look at these amendments before us, therein lies the rub because, of course, it is not an extra amount of spending on the environment at all. This does not even address the issue of whether the trust fund moneys go to environment funding at all. That is another debate. The issue here is whether it is over and above the existing government programs.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill is presiding over the most extraordinary cutback in funding off the budget for environment programs that we have seen in this country's history. That is the truth of the matter. This evening, Senator Hill and Mr Costello will be announcing a very significant reduction in expenditure on a range of environment programs.

The fact is that the government has a plan to cut the Daintree rescue package. We could ask why the government is not prepared to provide the $4 million that Labor had budgeted for for this program in the forward estimates for the 1997-98 financial year. We could ask why the government is not even prepared to provide the $1.4 million to this program that was earmarked for the 1997-98 financial year in last year's forward estimates. We could, if we were being unkind, ask Senator Hill about the mahogany glider rescue package. Senator Hill is apparently happily presiding over the gutting of the mahogany glider rescue package, with a smirk on his face. It is effectively being ditched by the government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Smirk is the degree to which you are prepared to mislead.

—Isn't it true that you will not provide the $2 million you promised to commit in last year's forward estimates to this program in the 1997-98 budget? Of course it is. That was a commitment, I might say, that was significantly less than Labor had promised to provide in its last budget.

SPEECH.PARA: My recollection is—I did have some interest in this at the time because I was the then environment minister—that Labor had promised to allocate $3 million in 1996-97 and $3 million in 1997-98. The coalition reduced the commitment to $2 million in 1996-97 and $2 million in 1997-98 and now they are not even prepared to provide that reduced level of funding. This is what we are going to be facing up to in a few short hours, courtesy of Senator Hill and Mr Costello, in the coalition government's budget.

I am also willing to make a prediction now, at 4.12 p.m., that you will scrap the highly successful, popular and effective environment program `save the bush'. This is all your own work, Senator Hill, isn't it? Why is the government not prepared to continue to provide the $3 million that has been allocated to this program in 1997-98 and in the 1998-99 budget?

We know about the one billion trees program that you are axing, even though $7.4 million has been allocated in this program for the 1997-98 financial year. I say, as we examine this bill in the committee stage, that the one billion trees program has been incredibly successful and has been responsible for somewhere between 600 million and 700 million trees being planted across Australia.

The point I make is—we will know all about it in a few short hours—that I think senators and any interested members of the public that might be listening to the debate are going to see my contribution here as quite a remarkable piece of crystal ball gazing, because part of Senator Hill's budget has been leaking like a sieve.

How can the government sustain their argument that they will be spending over $1 billion extra on the environment in the light of these absolutely outrageous cuts to the environment that are going to have a very significant impact on the quality of our environment and our commitment to environmental protection in this country?

Senator Hill, you really should be ashamed of yourself in relation to these issues. It is a massive breach of faith with the electorate. You have not delivered in any sense. I think we are entitled to be very concerned about the most recent change in focus that has been announced by the government in relation to the Natural Heritage Trust Fund.

I accept the importance of some of the imperatives that I hope are shared by you and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). That is why I am trying to understand fully what the government's intention is in relation to the role of the employment committee of cabinet and its interrelationship with your and Minister Anderson's work as the board of the trust fund. I appreciate the fact that you have indicated that you may well table the Prime Minister's communication so that many of us in the Senate can be let into the secret.

Given the sorts of announcements you are going to make in the budget, it is little wonder that senators and those in the community, who I think are very significant in number, who have a real concern about the protection of Australia's natural environment have a great deal to worry about in relation to your stewardship of this portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I cannot speculate on tonight's budget, I do remind Senator Faulkner that I have said at previous estimate committee meetings that it is the intention of the government to deliver in full on both the Daintree rescue package and the mahogany glider package.

SPEECH.PARA: We have acknowledged that we are spreading the funding a little in relation to those. That was very sensible because the first purchases in relation to the glider were largely of land. It was then realised that much of the glider habitat could continue on private land and the better solution was to find ways of covenanting the protection on that private land. That work has been continuing, but it has meant that the same amount of capital up front has not been necessary.

In relation to the revegetation programs of the previous government, yes they were useful, but they were very small programs. We are interested now in reinvesting very substantial sums both in protecting native vegetation and in revegetating. Within that spirit, I think Senator Faulkner will be impressed by the budget announcements that are made tonight. He will be somewhat embarrassed by his contribution that he has just made here today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We seem to have strayed back into last night's territory looking at the link between employment and the environment, so I ask the minister: whereabouts does the green corps fit as far as the spending of natural heritage trust money is concerned? Would it be the case that projects that involved troops from the green corps rather than volunteers would be more likely to get funding?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —The green corps has not been funded from the trust. I suppose it demonstrates the commitment of this government that the trust is only part of our contribution to remedying the deficiencies of the previous administration. The green corps may well advance objectives of the trust in the projects that it works on, but it is not being funded from the trust.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I realise the green corps is not being funded by the trust. My question was: if they are using troops from the green corps—in other words, linking your employment and your environment objectives—are those projects more likely to get funding than projects that are using volunteers, which is what most of the landcare projects are doing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I said a little while ago briefly the process for identification of the best projects. Submissions have been called for from the public. They will be expended under four different heads. The first are community grants. The second are regional grants, which will be the major distinction between the future and the past. We have heeded the advice of people such as those who have written the State of the environment report and said, `What you need are integrated responses if you are going to maximise the environmental benefit from the funding.'

SPEECH.PARA: The third will be certain state programs that will be supported and the fourth will be certain Commonwealth programs such as research programs. A process of regional assessment committees and state assessment committees will assist us in that regard. They may turn up programs on which the green corps are working. I can think of some green corps who are working on world heritage projects. Of course, we have specific commitments of support to world heritage. It will really depend on whether the green corps happen to be working on projects that pass the tests that will lead to funding under this program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister in response to what Senator Faulkner had to say about his crystal ball gazing into what might be in tonight's budget mentioned cutting funding to some programs affecting Queensland, in particular the Daintree rescue package and the mahogany glider rescue package, both of which are extraordinarily important programs coming from the last government. The minister said in response to that that he will be spreading the funding.

SPEECH.PARA: Unless I misinterpret that politicalspeak, he has corroborated what Senator Faulkner had to say. I would expect that that means that he is splattering the mahogany glider. He is taking money out of that program and either putting it elsewhere or carrying it on into some future date. He has already indicated that that is the fate of the Daintree rescue package.

Earlier on the minister said that he was relying on regional and state advisory boards or councils being set up to look after the disbursement of money out of this fund. I would like to ask the minister about the Tasmanian situation, where a committee of three has been set up—not in the Department of Environment and Land Management but in the Premier's office—to look after Tasmania's share of funding.

That committee comprises an administrator formerly from the department of environment, an adviser to successive Liberal governments—neither of whom, as far as I am aware, have any environmental qualifications—and it is headed up by a forester from Tasmania's notorious, in environmental terms, Forestry Commission, which is now called Forestry Tasmania. Its record has been serially one of fighting environmental breakthroughs in terms of protecting Tasmania's grand eucalypt forests, the rainforests and the wildlife.

So, on the face of it, we have a hostile committee—certainly one where it is hard to discover the environmental application, rigour, past performance and avocation. I would ask the minister to tell the committee where I am wrong in that and to explain to us why he has confidence that these people are suitably qualified to look after the disbursement of these funds in Tasmania, to ensure that those funds are put to projects of maximum environmental efficacy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brown, I am sorry to interrupt, but could you please address your remarks to the actual amendment before the chair, instead of the general issue that you are now canvassing.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I would be happy to. I did say when earlier canvassing this issue that I am responding to the minister's own comments about the establishment of these advisory committees. I was simply asking for him to address my response to that matter. So I am not straying from the subjects that he himself brought up under this item in the committee. I would be very happy to hear what he has to say about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —We did have these general discussions when we met previously before last night. In fact, I think we met for several hours. We seem to be re-running that debate, so I hope we will soon come back to the specific amendments. I regret that Senator Brown, consistent with his habit, deliberately misled the Senate in his interpretation of what I said. I did not say that we were cutting the Daintree rescue package or the mahogany glider package.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth is negotiating partnership agreements with the states through which the trust will operate. That is important because the states basically run most of these programs on the ground. The states are going to be responsible for a lot of the delivery. We want to ensure that the objectives that we are seeking through the trust are reflected in the commitment of the states. We are negotiating with the Tasmanian government. Some of the other states have also set up whole of government mechanisms for the purpose of that negotiation. My officials have been negotiating with the Tasmanian officials in relation to the program in Tasmania. Obviously the committee to which Senator Brown referred is assisted by specialists from a range of Tasmanian departments.

My advice is that those negotiations are going well, and what is being developed is a real quality program for Tasmania in terms of environmental outcome. That is good news. I am quite happy to take this opportunity to again confirm our commitment to $125 million of the trust fund being expended on the Tasmanian program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that Senator Hill has answered those peripheral questions, I invite honourable senators to return back to the issue of Democrat amendment No. 2.
—I think Senator Hill means that is 10 per cent, doesn't he?
—I hope $125 million off $1.25 billion is 10 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could help by going over the Democrat amendment to make it very clear what it is we are trying to achieve. What we wish to do is to replace, on page 7 of the bill, the primary objective for the Murray‐Darling 2001 project. We wish it to read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of this act, the primary objective of the Murray‐Darling 2001 project is:
to ensure the maintenance of biological diversity and an ecologically sustainable future for the Murray‐Darling River system and its communities by:

PARA.TAB: (a) restoring the flow and habitat requirements of freshwater ecosystems; and
(b) enhancing efficiency and sustainability in irrigated agriculture and water storage and delivery systems; and
(c) improving water quality; and
(d) protecting and restoring river frontage vegetation.

SPEECH.PARA: Hopefully, Minister, you will see that what we have done has not in any way moved away from your original intention. What we have done is to define it more clearly for those who are looking at which projects fit the bill and which projects do not quite measure up. For those people, I believe we should have a very clear definition of what it is we are trying to achieve. We are not speaking about every individual project fulfilling every individual requirement. We are talking about a broad objective just as you have here, which, for the purpose of the act, is the primary objective. We believe we do need rewording to make it abundantly clear what it is we are trying to achieve.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will support this amendment on the basis that we believe it does, in fact, improve the bill's objective in relation to the Murray‐Darling 2001 project to ensure that ecologically sustainable objectives, such as environmental flows, are included along with sustainable agricultural objectives. I think this is a worthy amendment and, for that reason, it will receive the opposition's support.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to complete this discussion. I note from my notes that we did debate this on the last occasion. It remains our legal advice that you would have to satisfy the four objectives. You might be right, Senator Lees, but the Commonwealth's legal advice is that it does and, therefore, if your amendment was successful it would largely wreck the Murray-Darling program. I remind you that we are putting $165 million into it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I like the wording in Senator Lees's amendment, but put yourself in my position. We have the Leader of the Government in the Senate saying that their legal advice is that the amendment would virtually wreck the program in that the projects would have to satisfy four criteria that are included in Senator Lees's amendment. I think we ought to see how it goes. If something happens along the way—and I hope Senator Lees understands my position—then let us revisit it.

SPEECH.PARA: I know of Senator Lees's interest in that particular area. It is a very important objective. Might I say that I am pleased that the Murray-Darling river system is one of the particular focuses for funding from the Natural Heritage Trust. At this stage, I would be inclined to support the proposition in part 3, clause 11 of the bill as it stands. Under that part, the objective is to contribute to the rehabilitation of the Murray-Darling Basin with a view to achieving a sustainable future for the basin's natural systems and its communities. It is pretty broad. If Senator Lees or any other honourable senator has problems with it as time goes on, as I say, we can revisit it.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 11, page 7 (line 23), before "sustainable", insert "ecologically".

This is another attempt at the same objective for the Murray-Darling 2001 project. As we lost the previous amendment, I will try to improve the government's definition by inserting just one word and that is `ecologically' so that it would read on the third line:
. . . with a view to achieving an ecologically sustainable future for the Basin, its natural systems and communities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again we are concerned that you are just inviting questions of interpretation that are unnecessary and might lead to an unexpected outcome. As we have previously published through `Meeting our commitments' what we are looking at is significantly accelerating on‐ground action within the Murray-Darling Basin in relation to improving the health of the key river systems, encouraging ecologically and economically sustainable land use, restoring riparian land systems, wetlands and flood plains and improving water quality.

SPEECH.PARA: You might argue that all of those would be adequately encompassed within the word `ecological' and that we would not be limiting ourselves. We would prefer the broader definition of sustainability—in other words, the definition that is unqualified. In particular, it means that it is clear that we are talking about both economical and environmental sustainability and that is really within the concept of the whole Natural Heritage Trust. It is within the concept of sustainable development, as you know, Senator Lees. Basically, it is a three‐armed concept of environmental, economic and social sustainability. When you link those three goals you can end up with a sustainable outcome that I think is the wish of most Australian people. That is why we are concerned about your attempt to further narrow that definition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you have a program that is economically sustainable relating to the environment if it is not environmentally sustainable? How can we possibly agree to a program that is defined as economically sustainable under this trust that is not ecologically sustainable?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Actually, I have some sympathy with the argument that that is the whole point of the broader definition of sustainability. I would argue that, unless you treat the environment sensitively, ultimately you will destroy its economic potential. Be that as it may, nevertheless that is not an argument for more narrowly defining the definition of sustainability. It is better to leave it in its broader sense and recognise that sustainability, in the broader sense, encompasses the three objectives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a bill about the environment. If we were dealing with an economic bill I could understand the government's reluctance to put anything about the environment in it, but we are dealing with a bill that supposedly targets the environment. Of course we have to pay due heed to the social and economic impacts of what we are doing, but the key issue is ecological sustainability. Unless it is environmentally sustainable, whatever the project, it will not be either socially or economically sustainable in the longer term.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, as this bill is about the environment and supposedly begins by drawing a line in the sand and preventing further degradation and then working to undo the damage we have done, surely the word `ecologically' in this particular clause relating to the Murray-Darling Basin is essential. As Senator Harradine has said, our interest as South Australians is surely getting this particular definition right because we are the ones who are at the end of the mess at the moment and we are the ones who live in a city whose water supply is under enormous stress thanks to what is happening in the rest of the basin. Surely we can put the word `ecologically' into a bill that is about the environment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just finish this exchange by saying that I think therein lies some misunderstanding on the part of Senator Lees, because it is not just a bill about the environment per se; it is about the environment from which we take economic advantage. It is learning to live with the environment in a sustainable way, and that is a way that allows us to take economic opportunity, that allows us to live as social beings and ensures that we do so in such a way that we can pass on the natural heritage in a better condition than we inherited it. That is why I think there is, Senator, within your attempt, the danger—and I understand what you are seeking to do—of unduly limiting what we are seeking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is something we could debate all night and I will not continue except to say that if the government's position were consistent, then in bills dealing with the economy, we would look at environmental sustainability and social sustainability. Wouldn't it be nice if every single bill that came before this chamber not only had an economic impact statement but had an environment impact statement and a social impact statement? Sometimes the answer might be `no impact' but, on an awful lot of occasions, the bills that you bring into this chamber do have an impact on the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have a bill that is supposedly about the environment, and of course we acknowledge the flow‐ons. It is great to hear this government doing so, but surely the key issue here is ecological sustainability.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lees is absolutely right. The minister says that he does not want the word `ecologically' in front of the word `sustainable', although he has some sympathy for the idea. He has got to make up his mind about this. He said earlier that he is looking at ecological as well as economic sustainability, but any schoolroom environmentalist in Australia will tell you that if you do not have ecological sustainability, you do not have economic sustainability. If you lose your environment, you do not have your economic base.

BREAK.PARA: What Senator Lees has done here is focus the minister's mind on the fact that this is the Natural Heritage Trust Fund, which is aimed at putting money into repair of past environmental damage—in particular, in this clause, in the Murray‐Darling Basin. She is saying that we ought to put the word `ecologically' as an adjective before the word `sustainable' to make it clear that money must be spent within the ambit of ecological sustainability.

There is only one alternative to that and that is that money would be spent on projects that injure the ecological attributes of the Murray‐Darling Basin. If it is not ecologically sustainable, it must be ecologically damaging. But we have got the Minister for the Environment saying, `No, I don't want that word there. It might cause some restriction in the way in which I and the minister for agriculture spend money for the environment.' He adds to that—and he says this with an equal‐handed tone in his voice, if you will forgive the mixed metaphor—`We have got to also look at economic sustainability,' as if the two things are incompatible. That is not the case and what we cannot close our eyes to in this committee is that the minister has, for himself, in the terms of this legislation, written in the ability for the government to spend money on projects that are not ecologically sustainable.

That is the short and long of it. If ecological sustainability, as a minimum, is to be a condition of this money being spent, then he would agree to it. `Ecologically enhancing' ought to be the term that is put here—not just sustaining but enhancing—because we are trying to repair the damage that has been done by past malpractice to this greatest of Australia's river basins. But here we have the Minister for the Environment saying, `I don't want the word "environment"; I don't want the word "ecological" put into the conditions.'

It is a remarkable indictment of him as a minister of the government failing to live up to the expectations that they put into the Australian people's minds when putting forward the policy of spending money from the part‐sale of Telstra specifically on the environment. It must open us as a committee to the concern that this minister and his fellow minister for primary industry, Mr Anderson, have sole control of where this money is going to be spent. They want to leave open to themselves the possibility of spending money on projects that are not ecologically sustainable. Who knows what that means? Are they going to patronise their supporters? Are they going to open their largess to people who are putting forward projects that are going to be economically rewarding to those people but not ecologically sustainable? I think so. And if that is not the case, the minister should be agreeing to this very simple, minimal and quite appropriate amendment being put forward by Senator Lees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister can defend himself, but I reckon it is not a fair crack of the whip for Senator Brown to have said what he did about what Senator Hill said. I did not hear anything that Senator Hill said that deserved the comment just made by Senator Brown. In fact, the thing that I did hear Senator Brown say about ecologically sustainable development being vital to economic sustainability was precisely what I heard Senator Hill say. You can have a look at the Hansard if you like, but I do not think it is warranted and nor is the debate going to be improved over a period of time by somehow imagining what people said or twisting people's words.

SPEECH.PARA: I heard what Senator Hill said. He was very clear that there needs to be environmental sustainability if we are to get economic sustainability. We are talking about the words in this piece of legislation which say:
For the purposes of the act, the primary objective of the Murray‐Darling 2001 project is to contribute to the rehabilitation—
surely that is ecological, is it not—
of the Murray‐Darling basin, with a view to achieving a sustainable future for the Basin—
that is this whole ecosystem of the basin—
its natural systems and its communities.
What are we arguing about—a jolly word? As far as I am concerned, I am supporting the legislation as is.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is certainly supportive of this amendment that has been proposed by Senator Lees. But I would like, in order to understand the minister's arguments, to have the minister indicate to the Senate whether the government still supports the national strategy for ecologically sustainable development. My mind goes back I think to 1992 when Commonwealth and state and territory governments signed on to that strategy. It was something that was worked through I think in a very consultative way. It involved not only environment groups but also industry groups—a very broad number of working groups developing the strategy. What I would like to hear from the minister is whether this government is committed to the ESD strategy.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we are and it is included within this bill that, in fact, we have to assess the programs against ESD principles. I think it is the first bill, or certainly one of the first bills, to do that. One of the problems has been that the states and the Commonwealth have for a long time been negotiating these sort of high principled national strategies, and when the strategy is completed the file is put away. What we are doing through the Natural Heritage Trust is actually providing a funding base to provide for the implementation of these strategies. So this is actually putting into practice the spirit that the states and the Commonwealth agreed upon some time ago.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his response. In the light of that response it baffles me as to why the minister cannot accept—given that the government does still embrace the national strategy for ecologically sustainable development—and comfortably embrace this amendment that has been proposed by Senator Lees. We have not heard a substantive argument mounted against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner is absolutely right, and Senator Lees is right too. Senator Hill laughs about this, but he has been unable to explain why he is so averse to the word `ecologically' being placed in front of the word `sustainable'.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine accused me of twisting the words that Senator Hill had used. I did not. I was very clear about what Senator Hill had said. Firstly, he said that he did not want to put `ecologically' before `sustainable'; and secondly, he was concerned that economic sustainability had to be taken into account. What we have argued over here is that you cannot get economic sustainability if you do not have ecological sustainability. That is pure logic in this modern age where the government does subscribe, as we have just heard, to ecological sustainability principles now adopted world wide.

It is quite fair of the committee to be alarmed and concerned about the minister moving to block this amendment from the Democrats to ensure that this money goes towards ecological sustainability and not just sustainability, whatever that might mean. There has been no explanation from either the government or Senator Harradine as to why the word `ecological' should not be placed in here. I guess we cannot go further than that, but I retain my right to be alarmed about it. It is not good enough for the minister simply to say, `Well, I have sympathy with this point of view, but I am going to oppose it.' It does not add up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot cope with that sort of thing. It is a false alarm, for crying out loud. Look at page 11 of the legislation. I know you did not have anything to do with the legislation being prepared; Senator Hill and his people did, and I had a bit to do with it myself, I might say. On page 11 of the legislation at point 21, it says `Principles of ecologically sustainable development'. There it is in black and white. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) This section applies to a decision of a Minister to approve a proposal to spend money in the Reserve for a purpose of the Reserve.
(2) In making that decision, the Minister concerned must have regard to:

PARA.TAB: (a) the principles of ecologically sustainable development—

SPEECH.PARA: et cetera. Then it defines what `principles of ecologically sustainable development' consist of. I am all in favour of simple legislation, but what is the use of putting this word in there when you have it in the legislation itself, as a requirement for the minister before he makes his decision. I cannot understand what all the fuss is about, so I am going to support the legislation as it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine might not be able to understand, but it is a perfectly reasonable amendment that the Democrats have brought forward. It is corroborated by section 21 coming down the line. We have not got to that yet. It is reasonable that the Democrat amendment be made, simply reflecting what that explanation further down the line has to say. Goodness gracious, Senator Harradine says he cannot understand what all the fuss is about. It is he who is making the fuss. We are supporting a very simple amendment that the government could have been well past by now if it had said, `Yes, that is consistent with the rest of our legislation. Let us accept it and move on.' The fuss is coming from the other side of the chamber. It is a fussy refusal to accept a simple word that would enhance and clarify this clause and ought to be supported.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Lees's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator Jacinta Collins did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza.)

SPEECH.PARA: (Senator Sherry did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Short.)
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move that the House of Representative be requested to make the following amendments:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 6, page 4 (line 17), to page 5 (line 3), omit the clause, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 6 Investments and income of the Reserve

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Amounts equal to income derived from the investment of money in the Reserve are to be transferred to the Reserve from the Consolidated Revenue Fund.
Note 1: Money in the Reserve may be invested in accordance with whichever of the following Acts is applicable:

TAB.TAB: (a) the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1996 ;
(b) the Audit Act 1901.

SPEECH.PARA: Note 2: Under section 81 of the Constitution, income from investments must be paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

(2) Within 28 days after the end of a financial year, there is to be transferred to the Reserve from the Consolidated Revenue Fund, in respect of the financial year, an amount equal to the fixed-income percentage of the uninvested money in the Reserve as at the end of the financial year.
(3) For the purposes of the application of subsection (2) to a particular financial year, the fixed-income percentage is:

PARA.TAB: (a) if the financial year begins on or before 1 July 2001:

TAB.TAB: (ii) if the Minister for Finance, by written instrument made within 28 days after the end of the financial year, determines a higher percentage—that higher percentage; or

PARA.TAB: (b) if the financial year begins on or after 1 July 2002:

TAB.TAB: (i) the percentage equal to the rate of interest earned by the Commonwealth as at the end of the financial year on deposits held with the Reserve Bank of Australia; or
(ii) if the Minister for Finance, by written instrument made within 28 days after the end of the financial year, determines a higher percentage—that higher percentage.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Advances on account of fixed income

SPEECH.PARA: (4) During a financial year, the Minister for Finance may, by written instrument, determine that a specified amount is to be transferred to the Reserve from the Consolidated Revenue Fund by way of an advance on account of the amount that may become transferable to the Reserve under subsection (2) in respect of the financial year. The determination has effect accordingly.
(5) For each $1 transferred under subsection (4) in respect of a financial year, the amount transferred under subsection (2) in respect of the financial year is to be reduced by $1.

PARA.TAB: (a) at the end of a financial year, the total amount transferred to the Reserve under subsection (4) in respect of the financial year;
exceeds:

(b) the amount (if any) that would have been transferred to the Reserve under subsection (2) in respect of the financial year if it were assumed that no amounts had been transferred under subsection (4) in respect of the financial year; there is to be transferred to the Consolidated Revenue Fund from the Reserve an amount equal to the excess.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments will lead to increased efficiencies in the management of the trust by providing the flexibility for trust funds to be invested and for invested funds to receive a fixed interest rate for the financial years to 2001‐02. The fixed income on any uninvested funds will be not less than eight per cent of the balance of the trust at the end of the financial year. This guarantees that a minimum interest rate is paid on uninvested funds based on the rate used for interest calculations for the trust in our Meeting our commitments document that we published at the time of the election.

These amendments therefore provide the opportunity for greater certainty in planning the trust program. They will ensure that the government can meet its commitment to spend a total of $1.249 billion on the range of activities under the trust.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be supporting this, Minister, but my understanding from reading your amendment is that this interest is going to be calculated annually. Is this the case, and if so why are we not looking at quarterly or, preferably, monthly interest so that we can have a compounding effect? I understand from some of our back of the envelope calculations that, by doing it annually, if this is the case, rather than quarterly, over the five‐year life of the trust you are losing something like $10 million. Can you clarify that for us, please?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are being offered above current interest rates and it is a question of how far you can reasonably press the government. The fact is that, because of the effectiveness of other government programs, the interest rate has come down. The government is saying, `Notwithstanding the fact that interest is now more competitive in this country we guarantee the $1.149 billion and to achieve that we guarantee the eight per cent interest rate.' The Department of Finance, after long and rigorous accounting, has assured me that that is the rate of interest that will enable us to meet that full commitment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be supporting this request. I will not be unkind enough to establish from the minister why this has taken so long to appear. The request is reasonable in the form that it has been presented, and as such will be supported by the opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Request agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 5 (after line 6), after Part 2, insert:
(1) There is to be a Natural Heritage Board, which, subject to subsection (3), is to consist of 9 members, including the Chairperson.
(2) The members of the Board, including the Chairperson, are to be appointed by the Minister.
(3) In appointing members of the Board, other than the Chairperson, the Minister must ensure that the Board includes members with expertise in the following areas: (a) biodiversity;

PARA.TAB: (b) marine conservation;
(c) wilderness conservation;
(d) world heritage;
(e) arid lands;
(f) soil conservation;
(g) inland waters;
(h) indigenous people's heritage;
(i) community consultation.

SPEECH.PARA: (4) The Minister may appoint as Chairperson a person who does not have expertise in any of the areas listed in subsection (3) but must be satisfied that the person has an established interest in and demonstrated concern for environmental matters.
(5) For the purposes of subsections (3) and (4), expertise means either:

PARA.TAB: (a) relevant post-graduate qualifications; or
(b) at least 5 years' significant work experience in the area.

SPEECH.PARA: (6) The members of the Board, including the Chairperson, hold office on a part-time basis.

PARA.TAB: (i) Subject to subsection 7I(3), the performance of the functions or the exercise of the powers of the Board is not affected by reason only of there being a vacancy or vacancies in the membership of the Board.

SPEECH.PARA: The Chairperson of the Board is responsible to the Minister for:
(a) reporting to the Minister; and
(b) the efficient and orderly operation of the Board.
The Board is responsible for the disbursement of funds from the Reserve in accordance with the objectives set out in its charter (see section 8).

(1) Subject to this Act, a member of the Board appointed under section 7A holds office for such period not exceeding 3 years as is specified in the instrument of appointment, but is eligible for re-appointment.
(2) A person shall not hold office for a continuous period exceeding 6 years.
(3) A person who has held office for a continuous period of 6 years is not eligible to be again appointed for a term of office commencing within 2 years after the expiration of that period.

(1) A member of the Board is to be paid such remuneration and allowances as the Remuneration Tribunal determines [but, if no determination of that remuneration by the Tribunal is in operation, a member, including the Chairperson, is to be paid such remuneration as the Minister determines in writing].
(2) This section has effect subject to the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973.
A member of the Board, including the Chairperson, may resign by giving a written notice of resignation to the Minister.
(1) The Minister may remove a member of the Board from office:

PARA.TAB: (a) for misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity; or
(b) if the member is absent, without the approval of the Board, from 3 consecutive meetings of the Board; or
(c) where the member of the Board is the Chairperson of the Board—if the member is absent, without the approval of the Minister, from 3 consecutive meetings of the Board.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) If a member of the Board tails without reasonable excuse to comply with section 7J, the Minister must terminate the appointment of the member.
(1) The Minister may appoint a person to act as Chairperson of the Board:

PARA.TAB: (a) during a vacancy in the office of Chairperson, whether or not an appointment has previously been made to the office; or

(b) during any period, or during all periods, when the Chairperson is absent from duty or from Australia or, for any reason, unable to perform the functions of the office of Chairperson; but a person appointed to act during a vacancy shall not continue so to act for more than 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The Minister may:

PARA.TAB: (a) determine the terms and conditions of appointment, including remuneration and allowances, of an Acting Chairperson; and
(b) at any time terminate such an appointment.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Where a person is acting as Chairperson in accordance with paragraph l(b) and the office of Chairperson becomes vacant while that person is so acting, that person may continue so to act until the Minister otherwise directs, that vacancy is filled or a period of 12 months from the date on which the vacancy occurred expires, whichever first happens.
(4) The appointment of an Acting Chairperson ceases to have effect if the person resigns the appointment by writing signed by the person and delivered to the Minister.
(5) At any time when a person is acting as Chairperson of the Board the person has, and may exercise, all the powers and shall perform all the functions of the Chairperson.

(6) The validity of anything done by the Acting Chairperson must not be called in question on the grounds that the occasion for the person's appointment had not arisen or that the appointment had ceased to have effect.
(1) The Board may hold such meetings as are necessary for the performance of its functions but must meet no fewer than 3 times in each year.
(2) The meetings of the Board must be convened by the Chairperson.
(3) At a meeting of the Board, a quorum is constituted by 7 members of the Board.
(4) The Chairperson must preside at all meetings of the Board at which he or she is present.
(5) If the Chairperson is not present at a meeting of the Board, the members present must elect one of their number to preside at the meeting.
(6) Questions arising at a meeting of the Board must be determined by a majority of the votes of the members present and voting.
(7) The person presiding at a meeting of the Board has a deliberative vote and, in the event of an equality of votes, also has a casting vote.
(8) In this section, Chairperson includes Acting Chairperson.
(9) If the Board so determines, a member of the Board may participate in, and form part of a quorum at,- a meeting of the Board by means of any of the following methods of communication:

PARA.TAB: (a) telephone;
(b) closed circuit television;
(c) another method of communication determined by the Board.

SPEECH.PARA: (10) A determination by the Board under subsection (9) may be made in respect of a particular meeting, or in respect of all meetings, of the Board.
(11) A member of the Board who participates in a meeting as provided by subsection (9) is taken for the purposes of this Act to be present at the meeting.

(12) If the Board so determines, a resolution must be taken to have been passed at a meeting of the Board if, without meeting, a majority of the number of members who would, if present at a meeting of the Board and entitled to vote on the resolution at that meeting, have constituted a quorum of the Board indicate agreement with the resolution in accordance with the method determined by the Board.

(1) A member of the Board who has a direct or indirect pecuniary interest in a matter being considered or about to be considered by the Board shall, as soon as possible after the relevant facts have come to his or her knowledge, disclose the nature of the interest at a meeting of the Board.
(2) A disclosure under subsection (1) shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting of the Board and the member must not:

PARA.TAB: (a) be present during any deliberation of the Board with respect to that matter; or
(b) take part in any decision of the Board with respect to that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 8, page 6 (lines 3 to 24), omit the clause, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 8 Objectives of the Board and purposes of the Reserve

SPEECH.PARA: (1) In disbursing funds from the Reserve, the objectives of the Board are:

PARA.TAB: (a) to protect and conserve the natural environment of Australia;
(b) to assist the Australian Government in implementing Australia's obligations under international conventions for the protection of the environment.

Note: International conventions under which Australia has obligations include the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage, a copy of the English text of which is set out in the Schedule to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 , the Convention on Wetlands of International Importance especially as Waterfowl Habitat, adopted on 2 February 1971 by the International Conference on the Conservation of Wetlands and Waterfowl held at Ramsar, Iran, the Convention on Biological Diversity and the United Nations Framework Convention of Climate Change.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The purposes of the Reserve are as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) the National Vegetation Initiative;
(b) the Murray-Darling 2001 Project;
(c) the National Land and Water Resources Audit;
(d) the National Reserve System;
(e) the Coasts and Clean Seas Initiative;
(f) environmental protection-(as defined by section 15);
(g) supporting the sustainable management of agricultural land (as defined by section 16);
(h) a purpose incidental or ancillary to any of the above purposes;
(i) the making of grants of financial assistance for any of the above purposes;
(j) an accounting transfer purpose (as defined by section 18);
(k) remuneration and allowances for the Chairperson and members of the Board (see section 7E).
Note: After the commencement of the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1996 , subsection 20(5) of that Act provides that money in the Reserve may be debited for the purposes of the Reserve.

Note 2: Before the commencement of the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1996 subsection 62A(6) of the Audit Act 1901 provides that money in the Reserve may be expended for the purposes of the Reserve.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Clause 9, page 7 (after line 6), after paragraph (g), insert: (h) remuneration and allowances for the Chairperson and members of the Board.

This is a very important amendment. It is the most important direction for improvement of the bill that the Greens will be taking. The situation under the legislation as it stands is that the allocation of funds is in the care and determination of a board. When you look at that board you find that it is none other than the Minister for the Environment and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. It is really not a board as the public expects these things to be at all. It is two ministers taking to themselves total power for the disbursement of this $1¼ billion for the Natural Heritage Trust Fund over the next five years.

The Greens believe that there should be expertise brought into this. This nation has a great level of environmental expertise, particularly amongst professionals who understand the damage of the past and who are working prodigiously to find means to repair that damage and to get the country's environment back on track—whether that be the Murray‐Darling Basin about which we have just been speaking, our forests, our rangelands, our coasts or any other component of the environment.
