To that end, this amendment is to establish a board which has a specific make‐up of nine people with expertise in the following areas: biodiversity; marine conservation; wilderness conservation; world heritage; arid lands; soil conservation; inland waters; indigenous people's heritage; and community consultation. The government or other members of the committee may argue that there are other areas which ought to be covered. But we have framed this amendment carefully to cover a range of areas which is going to be more than adequate for the modest amount of money to be spent on the environment out of this fund over the next five years.

What is very important about this matter is that it will bring in Australian experts in the environment and in community consultation to ensure that the maximum value comes out of every dollar of this $1¼ billion. We know that it is not enough money to do more than make a very tiny start on the road to repairing Australia's environment. That is a key reason why we should be making sure that it has maximum impact for the benefit of that environment.

In a previous amendment, which was rejected by the committee, we did not lay out the areas in which board members should have expertise. We have also expanded the size of the board under this amendment. The minister, however, as with boards set up for other instrumentalities, is the appointing person. The ministers will be able to appoint the people with this expertise. The amendment requires that the experts will have relevant postgraduate qualifications or at least five years significant work experience; and that there be a chairperson who, while not necessarily having the expertise that is listed for the nine specific members, has an established interest and demonstrated concern in environmental matters. The members of the board, including the chair, will hold office on a part‐time basis; and they will have similar terms and conditions in their appointment as do members of other boards such as the Australia Council, the CSIRO and the ABC.

Let us not forget that, while $1¼ billion might seem modest in terms of the job ahead, it is a very big amount of public funds; and it needs to be under very expert direction. In putting forward the amendment, we draw from the experience gained in spending large amounts of public money on other bodies such as the Australia Council or the CSIRO.

I cannot believe that the government expects the people to feel fully comfortable with two ministers administering these funds. The reality is that people will expect that the ministers are going to come under sectional pressures. We know that environmental interests are at a very great disadvantage compared with economic interests in determining government outcomes in this country. They do not have the public relations millions; they do not have the expert lobbyists; they do not have the power of persuasion over governments simply because they do not have the money.

In that situation, I would have thought that the government would welcome this amendment. It is simply going to shield the ministers from future accusations by people who lose out in their applications for money. The two ministers will be able to say, `Here's a recommendation from this panel of national experts.' As it is, the two ministers leave themselves open to accusations of bias, of political or sheer economic considerations being taken into account from anybody who fails to get funding from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund.

It is a really sensible amendment which is pivotal to the reputation of this project. It is enhancing the public good feeling about this money being spent on the environment and it is specifically going to free the ministers to take advice from the best brains and the most experienced people in the country. They will be able to feel confident that they are making the best decisions; and that they are not subject to considerations such as pressure from sources, from within and outside the government, for non‐environmental considerations to be taken into account.

BREAK.PARA: So there it is. I recommend the amendment to the committee. It is fundamental to the way in which the public is going to determine whether or not it has faith in the process of spending this money. It is extremely good practice for the government not to allow itself to be seen to be making political decisions in spending this money. It ensures that the government is seen to be drawing on environmental expertise, second to none, in making these important decisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that this amendment is being allowed. It is basically repeating an amendment that was defeated during the previous consideration of this bill by the committee. On that occasion, Senator Brown attempted to set up a committee that would assume the responsibility for disbursement of funds under this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than shield ministers in the way put by Senator Brown, we believe that ministers should accept responsibility for the expenditure of public funds and take the consequences for that. The safeguards lie within the mechanisms for developing the programs and the partnership agreements that will be entered into with the states, and then the annual reports and other accountability provisions that are contained in the bill.

This debate is exactly the same as the one we had on the last occasion. It is principally the same amendment that Senator Brown advanced on the last occasion and upon which he was defeated. He has changed the composition of the board, but the objective of his amendment is exactly the same. I did not know that you could come back with repeat amendments—amendments substantially in the same form as those that have been defeated.

For the same reasons as I advanced on the last occasion, we will continue to oppose this. As I have said, we have put in place the mechanisms to ensure that the funds are properly disbursed—mechanisms that allow for a very wide contribution to the development of the programs through the regional assessment panels and the state assessment panels; through advisory bodies, such as the National Landcare Advisory Committee, the Biological Diversity Advisory Committee, the Murray‐Darling Basin Community Advisory Council, the Endangered Species Advisory Committee, and the Council for Sustainable Vegetation Management which is soon to be formed. There is no reason, in fact, to think it inconsistent with that objective to then take the step that Senator Brown is advocating—and that is, to then pass all responsibilities to another body. Therefore, we continue to oppose this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Hill indicated, the Senate has already debated an amendment proposing an independent board to administer the trust fund. The opposition did strongly support the establishment of such a board basically because it would limit the capacity of the trust fund to be used as a political slush fund.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Hill's `criticism', if you like, that this amendment is similar to the one that we had dealt with earlier, which was defeated, is probably accurate, or that his assessment that that is the case is probably pretty true. But the new amendment that is before us increases the size of the board to nine members and places requirements on the members of the board to have certain expertise. The opposition, in fact, preferred the constitution of the earlier board. We do remain committed to the principle of the need to establish an independent board. It is for those reasons that the opposition will be supporting the amendment that Senator Brown is proposing.

I do not think you can really stress enough how important it is for this trust to be managed properly. Without an independent board, the trust will be the biggest discretionary fund ever established which can be distributed at the whim of two ministers. The accountability mechanisms in this bill, as far as the opposition is concerned, are almost non-existent. That is obviously a major concern to us, and we believe that an independent board would go some way to addressing that concern. We believe that an independent board would go some way to ensuring that environmental priorities—not political priorities—are a concern of the trust. Without some form of independent board, our major concern remains that the trust becomes simply the biggest slush fund in Australian political history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats also remain consistent on this issue. We argued this last time—indeed, last session—when this bill was before the chamber. We made it very clear then that we were concerned about the independence of a board; the fact that, if you really are going to have trust, there is that break in the direct linkage between government decisions and trust decisions. A trust decision should be, and should be seen to be, independent.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the minister is unduly sensitive when it comes to a body, and—as has been specified by Senator Brown—a very well qualified body, making these decisions. The minister, he or she, after all does have direct involvement in the appointment of the people who will be making up this board. I had hoped that the government would have had the opportunity to rethink its attitude to this particular amendment. But I will just say now that the Democrats will continue their support for as much independence as possible when it comes to the decision making process on how the money should be spent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to vote for this amendment. The matters were thoroughly canvassed on the last occasion when an amendment of similar purpose was not accepted by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Hill has said, there are state advisory committees and there will be a number of other committees through which all of these matters, or a number of them, will be canvassed. Ultimately, it does have to be in the hands of the ministers to determine the issues—and the buck should stop there. We in this chamber and elsewhere would then have the opportunity, if we or any of our constituents are dissatisfied with the way the disbursements have taken place, of challenging the ministers; that could be done here, in the estimates committees and elsewhere.

BREAK.PARA: I think, frankly, there are too many statutory boards where there is not that sort of accountability that we need. I believe that the accountability ought to be `political accountability'. The minister—that is to say, Senator Hill and Mr Anderson—is correct when he indicates that it is the board which should wear the decisions, and wear them publicly.

Do you think for a moment that, if there were any justification at all in any complaint by any organisation or any group within a particular state that had put forward a project which fitted all of the other prescriptions in this legislation, they would not complain and that we would not take the matter up here if it were a bone fide complaint? Of course we would. That is in the hands of every member of parliament.

Frankly, I do not agree with a number of the statutory boards. It is very hard at times to get answers from the estimates committees about the activities of some of the statutory authorities that are governed by boards. It is better, in my view, to have the final decision taken by the political board consisting of the two ministers and have them held responsible in a political fashion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine may feel that we in this Senate are in a better position to influence what our fellow politicians do or do not do in making political decisions, but we ought to also think about the wider public. They generally have greater faith in boards made up of representatives from their own ranks than they do in this sort of sham board—because that is what it is—which consists of two ministers. It is not a board as the public reads the meaning of the word. It is simply two ministers making up their minds on a whole range of political as well as other considerations. Let us not put our heads in the sand, because that is what will happen.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine says that people can complain about that when they are cut out and when the decisions have not been made on purely environmental grounds. He is a little more naive than I thought he was after so many years in this place and in public life. The public, particularly those who are furthest away from the seat of power who do not have the connections and who do not have the money, may complain that they are left out. Those who have the money, the power, the influence and the closest connection with the government of the day—be it this one or any other government—will have a better run in seeing that some of these funds go their way.

I defy anybody from this place to explain to the public that it is better to have two ministers deciding where this money goes to—it is taxpayers' money after all—than an independent board appointed by the minister consisting of nine people from the public who have expertise in environmental matters. That is the long and the short of it.

Earlier I sought to have the minister explain the case of the advisory board in Tasmania. I do not know what is happening in the other states, but I know what is happening in Tasmania. I guess it is representative of this system that is being set up which is totally unsatisfactory. At the Tasmanian level, instead of an advisory board being set up for the use of these environmental funds in the department of the environment, which includes national parks, it is being set up in the Premier's own office.

Instead of the board being made up from environmentalists in Tasmania—and there are plenty of those with extraordinarily high qualifications—it has been made up of two folk who do not have particular environmental expertise. The whole record of the person in charge has been to set his face against the environment movement in Tasmania. His record has been to fight against the proper establishment of world heritage protection for Tasmania's forests, including its rainforests and its tall eucalypt forests, over the last 15 years or so of moves by the community to protect what is left of Tasmania's grand forests. That includes world heritage forests.

I am completely stonkered by the minister's ability to believe those who are concerned for the nation's environment can get any comfort at all from the way in which the administration of these funds is being established. The government, with the pivotal assistance of Senator Harradine, is turning down this sensible move to establish an independent panel of environmental experts to ensure that this money is spent in the best way possible. The government wants to leave it in the hands of two ministers whose record on the environment is abysmal.

The government is excusing itself by saying, `Further down the line we will be getting good advice.' I challenged the minister to come forward with the bona fides of those people who are giving that primary advice in Tasmania, and he was silent on it. As I have explained to this committee, those people do not have the expertise to enable the environmentally concerned people in Tasmania to have any faith at all. In fact, it is quite the reverse. There is enormous alarm and shrugging of shoulders in despair in Tasmania about the people who are being put in charge of the disbursement of these funds.

A lot of peak community groups in Tasmania feel that they are cut out. They do not understand the process. It is closed as far as initial applications are concerned. There are all sorts of provisos in their way, and the feeling is already being built up that those in the know will get those funds. Those who know how to work the reins of power and who have the lines to power will do better than those who do not.

It is a totally unsatisfactory situation. I reiterate that we are speaking about a billion and a quarter dollars of the Australian people's money. We are speaking about a special opportunity to do good things for the environment. We are speaking about an obligation on the government and on Senator Harradine, who has now said that he had a role in helping formulate the legislation we are dealing with, and we know that he had a prodigious lobbying role in terms of this legislation and in ensuring that the part sale of Telstra went through this place. The government and Senator Harradine are saying no to this extraordinarily important improvement on this legislation. I believe that situation is totally unsatisfactory.

It is reprehensible that environmental expertise is not in the pivotal positions where the decisions are going to be made. We are going to live to see a great deal of unnecessary animosity and public dissatisfaction with what should be a matter of great public faith and optimism as far as addressing the enormous concern there is in Australia for environmental excellence and improvement in the years ahead.

I would once again appeal to Senator Harradine, in particular, who is pivotal in the numbers in this place if we are going to see this sort of amendment get up, to consider again the need for environmental experts to be put in the key positions of deciding where this money should go and not just leaving it to the ministers, who have neither the environmental expertise nor the record which would give confidence.

Let me finally say that the best half, if you like, of the authority in disbursing these funds is going to be vested in the Minister for the Environment. But here we have a Minister for the Environment who, in his short 12 months in office, has licensed the record destruction of what is left of Australia's wild forests and wildlife through licensing woodchip operations to an unprecedented level in the forested states of this country.

For example, during question time we heard him dismissing the concerns that Senator Margetts had that he was riding over advice from the Australian Heritage Commission which would have protected the Giblett block in Western Australia where demonstrators right now are trying to prevent the bulldozers and chainsaws from moving in on magnificent ancient forest which, if this Minister for the Environment has his way, is going to be cut down and sent to the woodchip mills and to the processors in the Northern Hemisphere. It is a minister who is in favour of increased uranium mining and, therefore, the enhancement of the dangerous nuclear industry and nuclear cycle in the rest of the world. It is a minister who has failed and made Australia the only country in the Southern Hemisphere not to object to the transport of extraordinarily dangerous nuclear waste cargoes through our waters on the way from reprocessing in France to storage in Japan.

It is a minister who has given the tick to the extremely damaging Hinchinbrook tourist resort at the conjunction of the two world heritage areas at Hinchinbrook in Queensland. It is a minister who is advocating that Australia be seen as the recalcitrant as far as global warming responsibilities are concerned when it comes to the international conference at Kyoto at the end of this year where Australia's environmental record is going to take another hammering so that the position we had in the 1980s of being at the front of the community of nations in advancing the interests of the environment is lost and frittered away to one where we become internationally regarded as holding back in the traces when it comes to our responsibilities, and so on and so on and so on.

I would rather that we brought in Australia's environmental experts and saw that this money was put to the very best use. Apparently we are not going to see that because the government and Senator Harradine do not want this committee. Well, they have got the numbers. It could be said, `Be that on their heads.' But that is not good enough as far as responsibility to the Australian public is concerned. That is not good enough as far as the use of an enormous amount of public funds belonging to the Australian people is concerned. Above all, that is not good enough for meeting the aspirations of a very environmentally alert Australian public towards the future environmental health of this country.

This whole matter of the Natural Heritage Trust Fund has become second rate. Senator Faulkner said that it is moving towards the reality of a slush fund. Those are very strong terms indeed, but there has been nothing in this part of the debate, either from the minister or from Senator Harradine, which would give confidence that that is not going to be the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, I do not know where to start. There would not have been one red cent in the Natural Heritage Trust Fund if Senator Brown had had his way—not a cent. Over a billion dollars has been put into the Natural Heritage Trust Fund, and not by anything that Senator Brown has said. He said words to the effect that the system is totally unsatisfactory. Is it unsatisfactory to have over a billion dollars put into the Natural Heritage Trust Fund? Is it, Senator Brown? You had nothing to do with that.

SPEECH.PARA: I am happy to say that, when it became absolutely clear that there was no way out of the one‐third sale of Telstra, I did go to the government and ask them what it was all about. They indicated that it was about getting money, some of which was to go to the redemption of debt and other parts of which were to go to the Natural Heritage Trust Fund.

I suppose Senator Brown is sorry that Tasmania got more than its fair share, if you are looking at the number of people in Tasmania. I do not think we got more than our fair share. I know that we would not have got anywhere near 10 per cent had that not been a matter of great moment to me and had not the negotiations borne that out. That it why it is now not a particular figure but it is 10 per cent of the Natural Heritage Trust.

Not one cent would have gone into that trust fund if Senator Brown had had anything to do with it. What is he belly‐aching for here now? He is talking about the system being totally unsatisfactory. He is talking about a whole range of areas that frankly have nothing to do with the case in hand. What we are talking about here is accountability.

To be quite frank, a body such as that Senator Brown is proposing is not the body that should be accountable. It is the politicians that should be accountable. It is the Minister for the Environment, who is at the table, who should be accountable. If there is some problem, if there are a number of groups that feel cut out, then those groups have the opportunity through their organisations, directly with the ministers and through their members of parliament, to have the matters taken up and to have all of the questions relating to disbursement of the funds examined.

I tell you what: those disbursements will be examined and examined and examined, particularly if the disbursements are the responsibility ultimately of the two ministers. That is how it ought to be. The two ministers ought to be receiving the advice of the various groups in the states and they are the ones who should make the final decisions in accordance with the legislation before us.

I do not want to canvass any further the matters that were canvassed last time. I feel that this legislation should get a pretty swift passage and we then should get on with the job of making the disbursements as soon as possible from the fund that is established under this measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine wants a swift passage of this legislation. It is the first time I have heard it. This legislation has been hanging back for months. As Senator Lees said earlier, it is quite surprising that it has taken so long to get here.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine says that there would not be a red cent as far as I was concerned. There would be a whole different environmental set‐up in this country if I were in the position to make this happen. For example, instead of sitting on the side, as Senator Harradine has done, we would have protection of our wild forests. We would not have a woodchip industry marauding through those forests, shedding jobs as it goes, particularly in Tasmania, where it includes the destruction of world heritage forests.

We also would be looking at alternatives, which include proper greenhouse gas controls and a carbon levy, as is the case in many other more enlightened countries in the Northern Hemisphere. We would have proper biodiversity protection in this country, we would have proper public transport, with the emphasis going away from the polluting transport systems we have got at the moment, and a whole range of other things that Senator Harradine has, if you ask me, been remiss in promoting in this place in his 21 years here.

In fact, on issue after issue, from the Franklin River through to the great issues of the forests and Wesley Vale in Tasmania, I cannot remember Senator Harradine taking any outspoken point of view in favour of the environment. If Senator Harradine equates money with the environment, he has got it wrong. Sure, it helps. This is a repair package for damage done in the past by the failure of politicians like, I submit, Senator Harradine to stand up when they had the opportunity years ago to protect the environment as the damage expanded and increased, even while platitudes were being spoken about the environment.

Of course, that is the case at the moment. Here we have Senator Harradine backing this minister, putting forward his stamp of approval on this minister and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. They, as I have said earlier, take pivotal responsibility for the record rate of destruction of forests and wildlife going on in this country at the moment—as opposed to putting it across to a panel of environmental experts. So much for Senator Harradine's commitment or, might I say, his knowledge about proper mechanisms for looking after the environmental interests of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 3 (after line 13), at the end of the clause, add:
. The Natural Heritage Trust Advisory Committee is established.
(17) Page 15 (after line 9), after Part 4, insert:

PARA.TAB: (1) There is to be a Natural Heritage Trust Advisory Committee, which is to consist of the following members:

TAB.TAB: (a) a Chairman;
(b) not more than 9, but not fewer than 5, other members.

PARA.TAB: (2) Among the persons appointed as Committee members, there are to be at least 5 persons who appear to the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board to have knowledge of, or experience in, one or more of the following fields:

TAB.TAB: (a) biodiversity conservation;
(b) land and/or water management;
(c) native vegetation sciences;
(d) river and/or wetland ecology;
(e) coastal and/or marine systems.
The functions of the Committee are as follows:
(a) to advise the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board about the integration of the objectives of environmental protection, natural resources management and sustainable agriculture;
(b) to advise the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board about the effectiveness of agreements entered into under subsection 19(2) in achieving integrated outcomes for the operations of the Reserve;
(c) when requested by the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board to do so—to advise the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board about other matters.

PARA.TAB: (1) The Committee members are to be appointed by the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board by written instrument.
(2) A Committee member is to be appointed for the period specified in the instrument of appointment. The period must not exceed 3 years.
(3) A Committee member holds office on a part-time basis.
(4) The performance of the functions of the Committee is not affected only because of there being a vacancy or vacancies in the membership of the Committee.

TAB.TAB: The Natural Heritage Ministerial Board may give the Committee written directions as to:
(a) the way in which the Committee is to carry out its functions; and
(b) procedures to be followed in relation to meetings.

PARA.TAB: (1) A Committee member who has a material personal interest in a matter being considered by the Committee must, as soon as possible after the relevant facts have come to his or her knowledge, disclose the nature of the interest at a meeting of the Committee.
(2) A disclosure must be recorded in the minutes of the meeting and the Committee member must not, unless the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board otherwise determines:

TAB.TAB: (a) be present during any deliberation by the Committee about that matter; or
(b) take part in any decision of the Committee relating to that matter.

PARA.TAB: (1) A Committee member is to be paid such remuneration as is determined by the Remuneration Tribunal.
(2) If no determination of that remuneration is in operation, a Committee member is to be paid such remuneration as is prescribed.
(3) A Committee member is to be paid such allowances as are prescribed.
(4) This section has effect subject to the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 .

TAB.TAB: The Natural Heritage Ministerial Board or the Chairman may grant leave to a Committee member to be absent from a meeting or meetings of the Committee.
A Committee member may resign by writing signed by the Committee member and sent to the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board.

PARA.TAB: (1) The Natural Heritage Ministerial Board may terminate the appointment of a Committee member if the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board is of the opinion that the performance of the Committee member has been unsatisfactory for a significant period of time.

(2) The Natural Heritage Ministerial Board may terminate the appointment of all of the Committee members if the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board is of the opinion that the performance of the Committee has been unsatisfactory for a significant period of time.
(3) The Natural Heritage Ministerial Board may terminate the appointment of a Committee member because of misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity.

TAB.TAB: (a) a Committee member becomes bankrupt, applies to take the benefit of any law for the relief of bankrupt or insolvent debtors, compounds with creditors or makes an assignment of remuneration for their benefit; or
(b) a Committee member is absent, except on leave of absence, from 3 consecutive meetings of the Committee; or
(c) a Committee member fails, without reasonable excuse, to comply with section 29E;
the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board may terminate the appointment of the Committee member.
A Committee member holds office on such terms and conditions (if any) in respect of matters not provided for by this Act as are determined by the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board.

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Clause 44, page 23 (after line 26), after the definition of Australia , insert:

TAB.TAB: Committee means the Natural Heritage Trust Advisory Committee established by section 29A.
Committee member means a member of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments relate to the Natural Heritage Trust Advisory Committee. Very briefly, looking at the time, all I will say is that these amendments set up an advisory committee of between five and nine persons to advise the ministerial board. At least five of these persons must have expertise in biodiversity conservation, land and/or water management, native vegetation sciences, river and/or wetland ecology, coastal and/or marine systems.

While these amendments are a long way short of our original amendment, we are pleased that the government has agreed to move in this direction and to provide a level of independent advice. We are sure that this will make the trust more accountable and more open and give greater general public confidence in what the trust is doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. We have been persuaded. We believed for a long time that the existing or the advisory mechanisms that we established were adequate. Nevertheless, we have listened to the arguments in a constructive way.

SPEECH.PARA: This advisory committee has been structured in a way that it will look at the overall program. In particular, the integration of various parts of the program—whether it be the national vegetation initiative together with the coasts and clean seas initiative or the reserve system together with world heritage and so forth—can be useful. We have provided for the appropriate qualifications for the members of the committee. After long and constructive discussion, we nevertheless agreed to the establishment of the committee in the form that has been now set out in this amendment. I do also confirm that we have had some contribution to the detail of the committee, as has been put by Senator Lees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Greens, I will support this as well. It is a long way short of the committee that we proposed. It is of advisory nature only. It can be totally ignored by the ministers. The functions of the committee, as laid out, are to advise the ministers about the integration of the objectives of environmental protection, natural resources management and sustainable agriculture and about achieving integrated outcomes for the operations of the reserve.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not quite understand that or why this advisory committee's functions are restricted to advising about the integration of those matters rather than those matters themselves. I would have thought that advice on environmental protection, natural resources management and sustainable agriculture—rather than advice on how to integrate those three things—would be much better and much more worth while for the ministers involved. I am a bit concerned that the strict reading of this functions clause restricts the committee to just talking about integrated outcomes and how you integrate these various objectives, not the objectives themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The design is that each and all of these issues can be discussed, but the aim of this advisory committee is to look at the bigger picture to ensure that there are not issues falling through the gaps. It will ensure there are no issues being missed as money goes into the Murray-Darling Basin perhaps or into vegetation programs in such a way as it is not integrated and is not meeting overall objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: So there is no issue that is off‐limits. All of this will need to be discussed by the members of the committee—of course, with due con sideration to their various levels of expertise in different areas and their specific interests. We wanted the advisory committee to look at the big picture, to look at where we were going and, in particular, to look at where we have been—where the money spent in the previous year has gone and what it has actually achieved as far as the big picture is concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the opposition's view, the arrangement that Senator Lees has come to with the government to establish an advisory committee does not remove the real potential for money provided to the trust being allocated on the basis of political and not environmental need. So I do think this is rather a token amendment. It does not address the underlying problem because, once established, this trust fund will be, as I have said before, the biggest discretionary fund in the hands of two ministers in Australia's history. I do not believe it is adequate to address this issue with the establishment of an advisory committee.

SPEECH.PARA: To remove the potential for massive pork-barrelling and to improve the accountability of the trust, the opposition obviously preferred the establishment of a stronger, more independent board which set criteria for distributing the funds. I think, unfortunately for the future of the trust, the proposal for an independent board has been defeated—now on two occasions. So it is in the absence of success for those amendments that the opposition supports the establishment of an advisory board and hence supports this amendment.

I think it is important to remember that the Senate committee report recommended the establishment of an advisory board. The committee actually reported that there was significant community concern raised during the public hearings and in individual submissions about the lack of accountability and the need for greater transparency in the current two-minister board. There was obviously also significant support for the board to be representative.

I think it is probably reasonable to say that the establishment of an advisory board com posed of relevant interest groups and experts goes some way to achieving these aims. The advisory committee will provide some degree of openness in the decision making process but, in our view, not enough. I do think this particular committee represents only a token concession by the government.

As far as we are concerned, the trust still remains a slush fund that can be divided up at the political whim of the two controlling ministers. My concern, as I have said before, is that they will do that according to political priorities, not environmental priorities.

Budget documents—
Budget strategy and outlook 1997‐98;

Savings: Choice and incentive;

Our commitment to women

I seek leave to make a statement relating to the 1997‐98 budget.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Treasurer is delivering in another place his Budget Speech for 1997‐98.

SPEECH.PARA: In last year's Budget, delivered less than nine months ago, this Government laid out a plan to turn around our nation's finances and secure our future. Our country had been on a losing strategy—a path of deficit and debt to the next century.

So we took a look at that problem—not one of our making—we faced it and we determined to fix it. You can't fix years of neglect overnight. But our Government laid out its strategy and got on with the job.
Tonight the Treasurer will report that we have made very significant progress.

And tonight the Treasurer will announce measures to consolidate and extend that progress, measures which can secure our objective to put the Commonwealth budget into surplus in this our first term of Government. Our consolidated measures turned around a $10.3 billion Labor deficit in 1995‐96 and they lay out a path to a $1.6 billion Coalition surplus over three years.

Whilst the former Government was running up deficit and debts our prospects were getting bleaker. Our future choices were getting narrower and harder. But paying our way, and then reducing our debt, means our prospects are getting brighter and our opportunities greater.

In the forthcoming year the Commonwealth has no borrowing requirement. In fact for the first time in nearly a decade, this year the Commonwealth will not run up debt. In the coming financial year we will repay it. We will repay over $5 billion of debt.

The Government's one third Telstra privatisation is not being done to balance the books. Aside from establishing the Natural Heritage Trust that money is going to retire debt. That money will free future Australians from debt and the debt servicing costs that threatened to choke them.
From the time we came to office to 2000‐01 the Commonwealth's net debt to GDP ratio will almost halve on current forecasts.

Madam President, for the second time in a row, the Treasurer will announce that this will be done with no increase in income tax rates, no increase in the company tax rate, no increase in the wholesale sales tax, no lift in the petrol excise. In fact, for the second Budget in a row, tonight the Treasurer will announce tax reductions.

The Government's programme of budget repair is being accomplished on the expenditure side. From our coming to office to the turn of the decade, underlying outlays are projected to fall from 27 per cent of GDP to just under 23 per cent.
This year's Budget papers provide unprecedented information on our fiscal strategy and economic outlook. It is the first Budget to be prepared in accordance with the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill.
When enacted, that Charter will require all future governments to match the standards of integrity in financial reporting that we are setting today.
The specific measures the Treasurer is announcing tonight are directed to:
helping families;
boosting small business;
creating jobs; and
encouraging saving.
Madam President, increasing savings will bring important economic benefits for Australia. It will reduce our reliance on foreign debt.
With more saving we can finance more of our investment to grow the economy faster and produce jobs. Higher savings will raise the speed limits to growth that have held us back over the past decade.
The Treasurer has outlined the way in which the Government will move from borrowing to saving in the first term of the Howard Government. And now is the time to encourage individuals to save as well.
Tonight the Treasurer will announce the Government's plan to reduce the tax on saving.

Every Australian will be eligible for a 15 per cent tax rebate on their savings. The measure will be introduced in two stages with a 7.5 per cent rebate from 1 July 1998 and the full rebate from 1 July 1999.
The rebate will apply to the first $3,000 of taxable income from savings however derived. For example, the rebate would apply to the whole of the interest earned on $60,000 invested at 5 per cent.
Alternatively, the rebate can be claimed in respect of any payment of personal contributions into superannuation up to $3,000. A person who pays $3,000 into superannuation will get a $450 tax rebate.
The 15 per cent rebate applies to the marginal tax rate. For a person on the 20 per cent tax rate it will mean the income they put into superannuation is taxed at just 5 per cent.

Madam President, the savings rebate will benefit around 6 million taxpayers. The bulk of the benefit will flow to individuals with taxable income under $40,000. It will benefit current savers and encourage new savers.

It is a significant encouragement to save in the form of superannuation, but it also provides assistance for individuals who are saving for other life cycle purposes such as education, health care, housing, and retirement.

The savings rebate takes the place of Labor's L‐A‐W tax cuts which were never paid. This brings to an end a tawdry episode. Other Labor schemes to deduct contributions from take home pay and make Government payments into superannuation couldn't have worked. And they were discriminatory—to one class of saving (superannuation)—and to one class of society (those in the workforce).

The Coalition approach is universal—open to all Australians and all types of saving. In particular, older Australians who have saved for their retirement are brought in from the cold and given the chance to take up the savings rebate.
It will equally benefit individuals who have used their savings to build up a business and subsequently derive a return on that business.
The savings rebate is estimated to cost $350 million in 1998‐99 and $1.4 billion in 1999‐2000.
This measure will provide a saving of $1 billion against the forward estimates in that year over the cost of the previous proposals for Government superannuation payments.
SUPERANNUATION AND RETIREMENT INCOMES

The Government is also announcing tonight a number of other major measures to improve the operation of our superannuation and retirement income system. These are designed to promote savings, choice, and incentive.
Superannuation Preservation Arrangements

Madam President, the Government considers it important to ensure that savings through superannuation are directed to their intended purpose—providing income in retirement. It is for this reason that superannuation is given concessional tax treatment.
We have therefore decided to introduce a number of improvements to the preservation arrangements.

The preservation rules will be amended from 1 July 1999 to ensure that all future superannuation contributions, including personal contributions, and earnings, will be preserved until preservation age, except in limited circumstances.
Benefits which are unpreserved at that date will remain so.

As indicated prior to the election, the Government will proceed with a phased increase in the preservation age from 55 to 60 by the year 2025. This proposal was first announced by the former Government in 1992.
For someone born before July 1960 the preservation age will remain at 55 years, while for someone born after 30 June 1964 the preservation age will be 60.

BREAK.PARA: Increasing the preservation age to 60 will reduce the gap between the preservation age and the qualifying age for the pension.
People retiring prior to age 60 will still be able to access their benefits in the form of a non‐commutable life pension or lifetime annuity.
These preservation reforms will have a very positive impact on national saving and, ultimately, a positive impact on the cost of social security.
Choice in Superannuation
Madam President, the Government is also committed to giving Australians more choice and control over their superannuation savings.
Accordingly, from 1 July 1998, employees will be given greater choice as to the Fund or Retirement Savings Account their superannuation contributions are made into.

They can make their savings work harder for them as providers compete to enhance their performance. It will give employees the power to protect their savings by taking them out of non‐performing funds.
A Fair Safety Net
Madam President, this Government has introduced legislation to maintain the pension at 25 per cent of Male Total Average Weekly Earnings. We are the first Government to ever do so.
And tonight's budget includes this commitment as a specific budget outlay for the very first time. This underlines the Government's commitment to maintain the income of age pensioners.
Deferred Pension Bonus Plan
The Government has also decided to introduce a new opportunity for older Australians.

From July 1998 people of Age or Service Pension age will become eligible for a pension bonus if they choose to defer their pension and continue in gainful employment for at least 25 hours per week. The Government will pay a bonus of 9.4 per cent of basic pension entitlement for each year of pension deferral, up to a maximum of five years.

The bonus will be paid as a lump sum on pension take‐up. A maximum bonus of $21,251 for a single person and $35,450 for a couple will be payable to those who have delayed retirement for 5 years and have been granted pension at the maximum rate. The bonus will be tax exempt.
OUTLAYS MEASURES

Madam President, as the Treasurer mentioned earlier, the Government is turning the budget deficit to surplus while meeting high priority spending needs. It is able to do so by reordering spending priorities and targeting programmes more effectively.
Families
In last year's Budget the Treasurer announced the Family Tax Initiative, which has already begun to provide significant assistance for low and middle income families.
The Treasurer has also announced a rebate of $450 on the cost of private health insurance which will become available for families in seven weeks time on 1 July.
Our commitment to families does not end there.
There are many families across Australia where carers make considerable sacrifices to look after elderly relatives or children with disabilities.

To further assist such families, the rate of Domiciliary Nursing Care Benefit will be aligned with the Child Disability Allowance from 1 July 1998. This will increase the rate of benefit payable by over 25 per cent and will provide carers who provide home‐based rather than nursing home care with an extra $16.60 per fortnight at current rates.

In addition, eligibility for the Carer Payment for personal care of a severely disabled person will be extended to those caring for children under the age of 16 with profound disabilities, from 1 July 1998. A full time carer will be eligible for a payment of up to $347.80 per fortnight at current rates.

From 1 July 1998, new child disability tables will be introduced to provide a more objective basis for assessing the eligibility of applicants for the Child Disability Allowance. New claimants will be assessed against these tables and a Health Care Card will be provided for children with a chronic illness who do not qualify for the Allowance on the basis of the new tables.

Additional funding of $54 million over four years is to be provided under the Commonwealth‐State Disability Agreement for additional accommodation support for people with disabilities. The measure will allow at least 500 additional families to access personal care and accommodation support for a person with severe or profound disabilities.
Madam President, the Government strongly values the contribution made by rural and regional Australia. We recognise the exceptionally difficult time it has endured over the past decade.

Rural families make great sacrifices to send their children away for tertiary education. From 1 July access to AUSTUDY will be improved for families who have two or more children away for study. The deduction under the income test for a second and any subsequent child will be doubled to allow more families more access to AUSTUDY.
In the second half of 1997, the Government will announce a comprehensive rural policy package of $200 million over four years to replace the ineffective Rural Adjustment Scheme.
In addition, the Treasurer will announce tonight the provision of an additional $76 million over the next four years to increase our quarantine capacity and improve our quarantine service.
A `best practice' quarantine service is of critical importance to the Australian economy, particularly our rural sector, with disease incursions having potential costs of billions of dollars.
Quarantine is also vital to human health and the natural environment.
Madam President, tonight's budget includes the $1.25 billion set aside to fund the Natural Heritage Trust over six years.

The Government was opposed tooth and nail by the Opposition and minor parties in establishing this, the largest restoration programme for our greatest natural asset—the environ ment. We have succeeded. The programme to restore our rivers, vegetation, and land will be of special benefit to rural and regional Australia. A separate statement covering these programmes is being released by the Environment Minister tonight.
Madam President, tonight's Budget will deliver significant savings in the cost of delivering Government programmes. In 1998‐99 savings measures amount to around $1.75 billion.

The Government has recently announced the Defence Reform Programme to carry out and add to the findings of the Defence Efficiency Review. The review identified ways we can enhance our defence capability. The Government will not reduce defence expenditure but we will get better defence capability by modernisation, enhanced training and reallocation of resources.

The Government has decided that its information technology infrastructure will be put out to competitive tendering, which is to be completed by the end of 1998‐99. This is expected to lead to substantial annual savings of around $100 million in future years.

Over the past year the Government has taken a number of steps to ensure the sustainability of the health system. Measures to combat unsustainable growth in pharmaceutical benefits expenditure will be introduced in 1997‐98.

The practice of price premiums will be extended beyond individual brands of drugs which have identical chemical make‐up to groups of medicines which have a similar clinical effect. This will build upon the generic pricing policy introduced by the previous Government in 1990.

From February 1 1998, there will be a base price determined by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee for a number of therapeutic groups containing very similar drugs. No patient need pay more. But a patient who chooses a brand more expensive than the base price will pay the difference. Based on experience with pricing of alternative brands, price differences are expected to settle in a narrow range of about $2 per prescription. This measure is expected to result in savings of around $560 million over four years.

The Government has also decided to delete from the Schedule a number of drugs used to treat less serious medical conditions, most of which can be obtained without a prescription, resulting in an estimated $112 million in savings over the next four years.

A National Prescriber Service will be established to help doctors improve the way they prescribe medicines. Around $22 million will be provided for this service over the next four years although this measure is expected to yield savings of around $24 million over the period through better and more appropriate prescribing.

The Government remains committed to the provision of assistance to low and middle income families so that they can obtain affordable childcare and parents can participate in the workforce should they choose to do so.

Planning benchmarks will be adopted to influence new long day Childcare Centres to locate in areas of greatest need, and the number of additional new private childcare places which will be eligible for Childcare Assistance will be 7,000 per annum in 1998 and 1999.

There will be a 20 hour per week limit on access to Childcare Assistance where parents use childcare for non‐work purposes. This measure will ensure Childcare Assistance is used for its primary goal: facilitating workforce participation by parents. There will be appropriate exemptions for families in crisis.
Without these measures, Childcare Assistance would not remain viable in the longer term. It will still remain one of the fastest growing areas of expenditure in the budget.

The Commonwealth will provide $975 million for public housing under the Commonwealth‐State Housing Agreement in the coming year. Efficiencies in public housing reform will yield savings of $50 million per year.
New Initiatives

This Government will not let down those genuinely requiring income support. We will guarantee a decent safety net for those who require it. And where possible, we will provide the opportunity for those on income support to give something back to the community.

This budget funds up to 10,000 places in 70 pilot projects to Work for the Dole. In the pilot phase, priority will be given to young people aged 18‐24 years who have been unemployed for at least six months. Projects will involve two to two and a half, six hour days per week.
This initiative will give young unemployed people a chance to add to their experience and develop their work ethic through participation in projects which are of lasting value to the community.

Projects will be focussed on regions with the highest levels of youth unemployment with an emphasis on non‐metropolitan areas in selecting suitable projects. The Government has allocated an additional $21 million over two years to fund these places from late this year.

In four years time, our nation will celebrate its centenary—100 years since federation. Naturally, it will be a time for remembering and marking our achievements. Tonight the Treasurer is announcing the establishment of a new fund—The Federation Fund—to comprise $1 billion to fund projects of national significance as part of the centenary activities.

It will fully fund projects, augment existing funding, or contribute on a matching basis with other Governments and the private sector. The projects are to be well advanced but not necessarily completed by the Centenary of Federation in 2001 and will be selected on the basis that they will create jobs in the construction phase and make a significant and ongoing contribution to Australia and the Australian economy.

There will be a geographic spread of projects around Australia. Projects will be selected by the Commonwealth Government in consultation with State and Territory Governments. The National Museum of Australia will be one of the projects. Funding will commence in 1998‐99 and it is expected to conclude in 2001‐2002.
This Budget continues the Government's commitment to reducing tax compliance costs for small business.

In March this year, the Prime Minister announced the Government's response to the recommendations of the Small Business Deregulation Task Force. That response included a number of taxation measures designed to assist small business. It built on measures to free small business from capital gains tax on rollover of assets or business. It provides a record keeping exemption available to up to half of small businesses paying fringe benefits tax.

Tonight, the Treasurer is pleased to announce changes to withholding tax arrangements to further reduce tax compliance costs for small business and reduce the frequency of transactions between business and the Australian Taxation Office. From 1 July 1998, businesses with an annual tax withholding obligation of $25,000 or less, under the Pay‐As‐ You‐Earn, Prescribed Payments and Reportable Payments systems, will have the option to remit these payments on a quarterly, rather than a monthly, basis. This measure will allow in excess of 300,000 small businesses the opportunity to defer the remittance of $500 million in withheld amounts in 1998‐99.

In addition, and in step with commercial trends, payments by large withholders (that is, those with annual withholding obligation in excess of $1 million) are to be made earlier and by electronic means. The revenue bring forward from this change will offset the revenue deferral costs associated with the new arrangements for small business and provide a one‐off gain in 1998‐99.

The Treasurer is announcing tonight a range of further measures to enhance tax system integrity. These are not measures to increase revenue but are designed to guard against the potential erosion of revenue in the future. For example, the Treasurer is announcing measures to protect the integrity of the company tax imputation system, to deal with dividend streaming and franking credit trading.

The Treasurer is also announcing tonight the Government has responded to submissions from small business and will ensure legislation dealing with use of trust losses does not adversely affect closely held family trusts utilising losses in the family group. However, it is now clear that the taxation of trusts must be considered more generally and the Government will release a discussion paper on this issue later this year setting out issues and possible ways of approaching them.

The Government will monitor taxation developments as they arise and will take whatever action is appropriate to preserve the integrity of the tax system, including the option of acting before the next budget.
Madam President, this year's Budget is forecasting excellent economic prospects.
Economic growth is expected to strengthen to 3¾ per cent in 1997‐98.
Underlying inflation is expected to remain low—at only 2 per cent through the year to June 1998.
The unemployment rate is expected to fall to 8 per cent over the course of 1997‐98 as employment growth accelerates.

The stronger outlook for 1997‐98 reflects stronger private consumption, the recovery in the housing sector and continued strong business investment. Private demand in total is expected to grow by 4¾ per cent. Business investment is expected to rise by around 8 per cent following exceptional growth in 1996‐97.
Public demand should grow at a modest rate, consistent with fiscal consolidation at both the Commonwealth and State levels.
The favourable outlook for world growth and expanding Australian capacity should support continued export growth. Imports will also continue to grow strongly as domestic demand strengthens.

Despite the expected pick‐up in activity and stronger investment, the current account deficit should increase only slightly as a share of GDP. That, in part, reflects the positive effect of the increase in public saving from Commonwealth deficit reduction.
Nevertheless, at around 4 per cent of GDP the current account deficit remains high, underscoring the need for the further savings outlined in this Budget.
Madam President, the Budget the Treasurer has brought down tonight takes us further down the path which will build a future of opportunity for Australia.
It continues and consolidates the strategy begun last year to turn around the Commonwealth's finances. It puts in place choice and incentives.
It provides consistency and certainty for business.
Together with structural reform of the Australilan economy, these policies will lift the pace of economic growth and create job opportunities.
I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the statement and documents.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin my adjournment speech tonight, I draw to the attention of the chamber the absence of the Greens and all of the Democrats during the budget speech tonight. It is a great disappointment that they were not here tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak tonight on the issue of the Hindmarsh Island Bridge, which was the focus of legislation passed in this place last night. Sadly it seems that this will still not be the end of the matter since we have learned today that a High Court challenge is still to be pursued. In South Australia, therefore, it seems that we are still looking at a bridge too far away.

This is an issue which has caused substantial division in my state and a good deal of personal anxiety within the communities of South Australia. Surely it was time this matter was resolved last night once and for all, not only for the federal and state governments but also for the wider community and, most importantly, for the Ngarrindjeri women themselves.

I had the very great privilege last year to meet three members of the Ngarrindjeri community—three of the so-called dissident women—when Dorothy, Dulcie and Jenny visited Canberra late last year to take part in the launch of a book which reveals the truth of this very sad matter. The so-called bridge debate has gone on in South Australia for over three years and has cost more than $4 million, taking into account the cost of the two state and two federal inquiries and associated legal actions.

Three of the inquiries found that the bridge should go ahead. The other was effectively overturned on appeal. Moreover, without this legislation, another report—the fifth—may have been needed. What a travesty and what a terrible waste of money. Given the history of litigation surrounding this issue, there is no guarantee that another report would lead to a finalisation of the matter without yesterday's legislation. What a truly amazing saga for a stretch of water that the fitter members of this place could swim across with ease.

The previous government is guilty of gross mismanagement and incompetence on this matter. The issue of the Hindmarsh Island Bridge has raised questions about the ability of governments to deal sensibly with indigenous heritage issues. Quite clearly, the time had come for the debate over the bridge to be ended once and for all. This was clearly an exceptional case. The use of the legislation that was passed last night is a crucial step in this very important process, not only for South Australia but for those courageous dissident women.

Whether or not the area on which the Hindmarsh Island Bridge will be built is a sacred site depends crucially on the veracity of the so‐called `secret women's business'. The royal commission found that this claim was a fabrication, a recent invention. Four reports have now been prepared into the Hindmarsh Island Bridge and only one supported the evidence of the secret women's business.

This report, by Professor Cheryl Saunders, was quashed by the Federal Court. Moreover, it was clear that her report was fundamentally flawed. For example, it appears that she never once visited the South Australian Museum, which holds considerable knowledge on these sorts of matters. Justice Matthews, in the most recent report on the matter, found that there was insufficient evidence to indicate that the Hindmarsh Island Bridge area was in fact a sacred site.

The facts totally discredited the main proponent of the secret women's business, Doreen Kartinyeri. In the process of her very public and damaging campaign, which has cost a great deal of money, a handful of very courageous indigenous women found the strength to speak out and to tell the truth about this very important issue. They have endured many months of personal torture and have been ostracised by their communities. During their visit to Canberra, one of them told me that she does not expect to be reconciled with the community in her lifetime. What a tragedy this is for those women and for all South Australians.

Labor, at last, sensibly agreed last night, by its support for the government's position, that the Hindmarsh Island Bridge saga should be brought to an end and that the bridge should be allowed to go ahead. So I am puzzled as to why the opposition spokesperson on justice was absent from the final vote on the bill last night, having said during the debate that he actually supported it.

It is also puzzling and, I must say, disappointing to learn that Mrs Kartinyeri has announced, through her lawyer, that she intends to launch a High Court action against last night's Hindmarsh Island Bridge legislation. It is almost unbelievable to South Australians that, once again, we have to go through another divisive community debate on this issue. Just when all South Australians thought that they could breathe a sigh of relief that the final chapter of this unfortunate saga had been written, we find that even more money, time and community division is to be expended on a bridge that sadly still seems to be too far away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin my adjournment speech on the issue of education and university enrolments, I would like to acknowledge the comments by Senator Ferris regarding the absence of the Australian Democrats from the chamber during the budget speech. I only wish that I had the luxury of being able to sit in this chamber and listen to the budget being handed down, as opposed to having to juggle responses to at least seven portfolios, unlike Senator Ferris. So I think that explains the absence of my colleagues and me. But we did watch the broadcast of the budget being handed down and we gave it the attention it deserved, as you will no doubt see over the next few hours.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, I was misrepresented in the chamber by two senators—the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Amanda Vanstone, and Senator Eric Abetz in a question that he posed to the minister. He claimed I had stated that enrolments for universities had declined. In fact, what I stated all along has been that enrolment applications have declined.

I am also correct in that assumption and that claim. Indeed, Senator Abetz referred to a press release of 7 February, which I tabled earlier today, in which I discussed the minister's own department's findings—that is, that enrolment applications had declined across the nation.There is a very clear distinction between enrolments and enrolment applications.

I would like to put on record the total number of university enrolment applications that had declined at that time. In Queensland, they were down by three per cent; in Western Australia, they were down by five per cent; in Victoria, there was a decline of six per cent; in New South Wales, six per cent also; in South Australia, seven per cent; and eight per cent in Tasmania.

The truly terrible statistics were in relation to applications for enrolment by mature age students. They had declined by 12 per cent in South Australia, 13 per cent in Victoria, 15 per cent in Tasmania, 17 per cent in Western Australia and 19 per cent in New South Wales. It is a very clear and important distinction that if you are a commentator in the higher education debate, you cannot afford to confuse. For that reason, I am absolutely astounded that the minister made that mistake. I can only question whether or not she made that confusion deliberately, in a blatant attempt to demonstrate that her higher education reforms, unprecedented and regressive as they are, have not had the negative impact that they indeed have had, or whether or not it was an ignorant claim by the minister and Senator Eric Abetz in an attempt to point score.

I also took offence at the personal reflections made by the minister in this place. She may think it is funny to refer to hair colour, hair care or the appearance of Democrat senators, but I suggest it is rather a double standard, considering the debate that raged around the comments of a rather, shall we say, flustered backbencher, the member for Lindsay, Ms Jackie Kelly, in a debate at the Tertiary Presidents' Conference. At that debate, it was made very clear that comments, personal reflections, on the appearance of women in this place are inappropriate. I suggest that the minister and her colleagues should also stick to commenting on policies and record and not on the appearance of people in this place.

The minister also made comments today about overseas students. I believe she accused me of claiming that the overseas student market would be hit as a consequence of the higher education changes. Indeed, we are led to understand that there has been a dampening and a decline in overseas student enrolment applications. Unfortunately, some institutions have not released those figures, but I am sure that the government knows what is going on and I look forward to seeing some kind of tabling or provision of information by the minister's own department in that area.

Certainly on Meet the Press on the weekend the minister made clear that she thought that there had been some impact on campuses as a result of the race debate inspired, perhaps, by the discussions of the member for Oxley (Mrs Hanson). Certainly, surveys from universities, such as the University of South Australia, demonstrate that those students who have come here from different countries—international students—are concerned about not only the quality of higher education in this country and the impact of the changes that took place in last year's budget but also their safety on campuses. I am not making that up. There are surveys to prove it.

A press release from the Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee of 6 May was headed `Vice‐Chancellors: new overseas promotions agency would help counter negative impact of Hanson'. Given that the minister affords more credibility to the comments of the AVCC than certainly to me or my colleagues' comments in this area, perhaps she would read that press release and take note of their concerns about the comments of the member for Oxley regarding students from different countries or race relations in general. They believe that there is a problem. Given that our export education market in this country makes more money for this country than do wheat exports, the minister should certainly be paying attention to their concerns and recommendation.

The minister also implied that we argued that departments would be harshly hit by the budget measures. Indeed, they have been. I thought it was ironic that the minister gave a speech at the graduation, that is, the commemoration ceremony, of law and performing arts students of the University of Adelaide. Never mind the fact that law students are now going to be hit with the highest HECS charge, and that the performing arts faculty from that campus has now closed as a consequence of the minister's education changes. They were some of the last graduates who will be leaving that campus. I am sure they were thrilled to have the minister addressing their commemoration ceremony. Perhaps that is why they were wearing black armbands.

BREAK.PARA: The minister has asked me for an apology for allegedly misleading the community by claiming that enrolments were down. That is not what I said; I said enrolment applications were down and I supported that with evidence from the minister's department provided at estimates when I questioned the minister on this in February and since then. So I, in fact, asked the minister for an apology. As I made clear, she may be used to making mistakes in her portfolio, she may be used to blunders like the actual means test debacle, and she may be unconcerned about mistakes like the so‐called `Wright family' when discussing issues such as Austudy, but the Democrats do not like making errors, and will admit when we make them, but in this area we have not made an error. So how dare the minister ask me or any other of my colleagues to make an apology that is not due?

I look forward to the minister coming into this place, preferably tomorrow—and I would not mind if Senator Abetz came in too—to apologise for misleading this parliament and for misleading the community on a broadcast day, and also to make clear that enrolment applications have declined. Enrolments remain stable, and no‐one is denying that. Demand has been up for some years, anyway, so it is not surprising that they remain stable. But enrolment applications have declined. And that is where you determine whether those who have been turned off, be they students already or student aspirants, have been turned off university or higher education as a consequence of regressive measures such as up-front full cost fees or HECS hikes.
