QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 4 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the report by Professor Margaret Allars on the inquiry into the use of pituitary derived hormones in Australia and Creutzfeldt‐Jakob disease, which was presented to the former Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) in June 1994:

(1) Did Professor Allars say in her report that: (a) the conduct of the human pituitary hormone program was unlawful; (b) the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (CSL) which manufactured and distributed the pituitary hormones had not met all the requirements of the Australian regulatory authorities to manufacture and distribute the hormones; (c) batches of the hormone tested positive for hepatitis B, but that the level was not sufficient to cause the batch to fail quality control; if so:(i) what is considered to be a safe level for hepatitis B in an injection intended for humans, and (ii) how many batches tested positive for hepatitis B; (d) 171 091 pituitary glands were collected from dead Australians; if so: (i) was prior consent, or the consent of relatives, obtained before all of these glands were removed from the bodies, (ii) were all the glands removed by medically qualified pathologists, or were most glands removed by mortuary attendants, and (iii) were the mortuary attendants paid a fee for each gland they removed; if so, how much; and (e) Dr P Schiff of CSL advised the gland collectors that `unless the body is badly decomposed it is never too late to take the gland', and at the time he gave this advice, was Dr Schiff the CSL representative on the Human Pituitary Hormone Advisory Committee (HPAC), the committee responsible to the Minister for Health in overseeing the program.

(2) Did a number of recipients and the families of people who had died as a result of receiving the pituitary hormones commence legal proceedings against the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services and the CSL in May 1993.

(3) Did Professor Allars also say in her report that, in order to maintain and enhance its independ ence, the inquiry proposed to Dr Lawrence that it was desirable for its records to be transferred to the custody of Australian Archives rather than to the department.
(4) Did Dr Lawrence agree with this request and were the inquiry documents deposited in the Sydney repository of the Australian Archives.
(5) (a) Has the department removed the inquiry documents from Archives; if so, why; and (b) where are the documents now.
(6) Did Professor Allars say that the inquiry documents would be available in legal proceedings.

(7) (a) Is the department refusing to allow the lawyers acting for the plaintiffs, and their advisers, access to the inquiry documents, which are necessary for them to prepare the plaintiff's cases; and (b) is this refusal seriously inhibiting the preparation of the plaintiff's cases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I refer the honourable senator to the Report of the Inquiry into the Use of Pituitary Derived Hormones in Australia and Creutzfeldt‐Jakob disease ("the Allars Inquiry Report") which was tabled in Parliament by the then Minister for Human Services and Health on 28 June 1994.
(2) Legal proceedings against the Commonwealth and the CSL in relation to the Australian Human Pituitary Hormone Program first commenced in May 1993
(3) & (4) I refer the honourable senator to the Allars Inquiry Report which indicates that
arrangements were made for inquiry materials to be directly deposited into Archives.

(5) In response to a procedure commenced by lawyers involved in legal proceedings referred to in my answer at (2) above, Allars Inquiry documents were required to be transferred from Australian Archives in Sydney to Australian Archives in Melbourne and from there a large number of the Allars Inquiry documents were required to be transferred from Australian Archives in Melbourne to the Australian Government Solicitor, Melbourne. After consideration of the application of the secrecy provisions of the National Health Act 1953 to the Allars Inquiry documents, an agreement was reached between the legal firm, Rennick Briggs, acting on the behalf of the majority of the plaintiffs and the Australian Government Solicitor as to the provision of a large of number of Allars Inquiry documents to those lawyers. This agreed procedure has been in place for some time. I am advised by the Australian Government Solicitor that in terms of the request for Allars materials by lawyers for the plaintiffs, Rennick Briggs, there are presently no further documents being sought.

I am advised that my Department only sought access to five Allars Inquiry files relating to individuals as a direct result of requests made by those individuals under the Freedom of Information Act 1982. I am advised by the Australian Government Solicitor, that all other Allars Inquiry documents are with Australian Archives in Melbourne. 3.

(6) I refer the honourable senator to the Allars Inquiry Report which indicates that in letters from the Inquiry to interviewees, reference was made to the possibility of disclosure by discovery or subpoena.

Whilst Professors Allars did warn interviewees about the possibility of disclosure by discovery or subpoena, she was also concerned for the privacy of individuals, in particular human pituitary hormone recipients. Professor Allars, in several instances, used non‐identifying descriptions of individuals in her report.
(7) I refer to my answer at (5) above and the arrangement in place as agreed to by lawyers for the Plaintiffs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 April 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Sandline International mercenary cargo unloaded from an Antonov 124 Russian cargo plane on 27 March 1997, and currently under guard at the Royal Australian Air Force base at Tindal, near Katherine in the Northern Territory:
(1) What is the full inventory of the cargo items.
(2) Who is the owner of this cargo.

(3) If the answer to (2) is the Papua New Guinea (PNG) Government: (a) what Australian‐derived funds, either public or private, if any, were used by the PNG Government to purchase this cargo; (b) will the Australian Government ask the PNG Government if the material will now be used, in full or in part, in pursuing armed conflict in Bougainville; and (c) what conditions, if any, will the Australian Government require to be satisfied before it relinquishes the equipment to the PNG Government.
(4) If the answer to (2) is Sandline International, does the Government plan to decommission all weapons in the cargo.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Customs Service, in accordance with its powers under the Customs Act, has examined the cargo. Details of the inventory are a matter between Customs and the owner, and any disclosure of the detail would need to be considered in light of the owner's views and Australia's international obligations. As the ownership of the cargo is still in the process of being determined, I am not at liberty to provide details of the inventory at this time.
(2) The matter of ownership is one for the parties to the transaction to resolve. In these circumstances the Government is not in a position to comment on the ownership issue.
(3) Not applicable.
(4) Not applicable.
